Looks like a ton of straw on the field -- I wonder if that was done to preserve the field during practice, or to keep it from turning into a mud puddle during the game?

Irish-born Tammany Hall boss Richard Eyre Croker (1843-1922) was 71 in 1914, when he married Beulah Benton (or Benson) Edmonson (or Edmondson) (1884-1957), who was 1/16 Cherokee and an alumna of the Cherokee National Female Seminary, shortly after his first wife's passing. He left his fortune to this second wife, and not to his children; Croker's children tried to claim that the Croker-Edmonson marriage wasn't valid, but they were unsuccessful in proving their claims. The will was still being contested as late as 1937. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Croker She's buried in West Palm Beach, FL, where she owned a lot of beachfront property in later life: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=62332174
Amazing man BossCroker what a life   Absolute legend

Helped all the Irish landing in New York to start new lives   wpuld love to know more.  Don't know why on earth he left nothing to his kids though apart from Florence he left her the equivalent of 5 million in today's terms of value but he left his new wife 300 million
Died in Dublin and is buried in Stepaside

LoC has some photos of a J.H. Hammond home, (2221 Kalorama, now the residence of the French ambassador) but I'm not convinced it's the same building. www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=j.h.%20hammond%20home&...
Cool

However, it does seem likely that the J.H. Hammond is John Hays Hammond, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Hays_Hammond who was frequently in the news. His son, John Hays Hammond, Jr. [ en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Hays_Hammond,_Jr. ] who was experimenting with wireless control of unmanned boats, also made the news, but looks to have been based in Gloucester, MA at this time.

According to www.tiltonbernstein.com/properties/lebourget/history.pdf 2221 Kalorama was built in 1910 for another mining magnate, William W. Lawrence. "In 1910, the largest house in Sheridan-Kalorama was constructed. Designed by Jules Henri De Sibour, 2221 Kalorama Road was built for mining magnate William W. Lawrence in the Jacobean Revival style. It was later owned by another mining magnate, John Hays Hammond, who sold it to the French government in 1936 for use as an Embassy..." So it may be that this picture is of a house Hammond lived in before he moved to 2221 Kalorama. users.starpower.net/oshel/latrobe.html refers to 2221 Kalorama as "the William Watson Lawrence house, now the French Embassy, at 2221 Kalorama Road, N.W." William Watson Lawrence died in 1916. See, for example, books.google.com/books?id=NRgUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA95&lp... More likely that this is a different house.

See also In comments on that picture RockCreek (definitely an expert on DC buildings) reckoned this might be 1500 Rhode Island Avenue. www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2004006120/ a Bain photo not yet uploaded, was clearly taken at the same house.

In April 1913, they lived at 2315 Massachusetts Avenue, according to The Washington herald., April 29, 1913, Page 5, midway down 2nd column chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1913-04-29/ed-... By January 1916, a Mrs. Francois B. Moran lived at 2315 Massachusetts Avenue. See The Washington times., January 01, 1916, HOME EDITION, Page 7 (box near top center) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1916-01-01/ed-...

This would seem to be a celebration of the 25th anniversary of the accession to the Bulgarian throne of Ferdinand I, who by 1912 was styled Tsar, a title he bestowed upon himself. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_I_of_Bulgaria Medals and stamps were also issued to mark the occasion. Another Bain collection photo shows a procession going through a very similar arch. Maybe it's the same arch, other side. The words on the arch are different, however. Other Bain photos show royal celebrations of the Crown Prince's Boris' 21st birthday, also in 1912.

Thanks artolog for your research. The dates seem to match other images related to Ferdinand I, and his declaring himself czar in 1912.  I think that we'll leave this one as is to see if any more information comes in.

HMS Edgar was a first class cruiser of the Royal Navy, and lead ship of the Edgar class. She was built at Devonport and launched on 24 November 1890. She served in the First World War in the Gallipoli Campaign, along with her sisters Endymion, Grafton and Theseus. Edgar was damaged in an attack by the Austro-Hungarian submarine SM U-29 on 4 April 1918 near position 35°06′N 14°24′E.[1] Edgar was sold on 9 May 1921. She arrived at Morecambe on 24 April 1923 for breaking up. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Edgar_(1890)

Mrs. Andrew McKinney, the former Ida Blackstone Riley (1880-1935). She was involved in a newsy society divorce in late 1914. Her wealthy Wall Street broker husband was caught in a hotel room with his pink-pajama-clad girlfriend by their butler, while Ida sat in the limo outside. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F5071EFF3F5C13738... Ida later married Samuel Willets, another Long Island society figure (he was also divorced).

pennylrichardsca,

Elswick Ordnance Company was a major arms developer before and during World War I. The ordnance and ammunition it manufactured for the British Government were stamped EOC, while guns made for export were usually marked "W.G. Armstrong". en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elswick_Ordnance_Company#Elswick_Or...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Weddigen "On 22 September 1914, while patrolling in the region of the southern North Sea known to the British as the "Broad Fourteens", U-9 intercepted the three warships of the Seventh Cruiser Squadron, also known as the Live Bait Squadron. Weddigen fired off all six of his torpedoes, reloaded while submerged, and in less than an hour sank the three British armoured cruisers HMS Aboukir, HMS Hogue and HMS Cressy. Sixty two officers and 1,397 men were killed, only 837 survived." But Weddigen's career was soon cut short. The following March HMS Dreadnought cut the U-Boat he was commanding, U29, in two. There were no survivors.

A silent movie was made in 1927 about the U-9 and Weddigen www.imdb.com/title/tt0018521/ www.firstworldwar.com/bio/weddigen.htm confirms that Weddigen is third from left in the seated row. submarine.50megs.com/ottow.html includes another copy of this picture (perhaps a postcard) with the caption "Unsere Helden", "Our Heroes." Weddigen wrote his own account of the incident. A translation is at www.gwpda.org/1914/u-9.html and lots more photos and another copy of his account are at angloboerwarmuseum.com/Boer13_plates2_u9.html
Sad story my friend, god bless you, lovely photo of some great men

More detail on the German Concession of Kiautschou (1898-1914) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiautschou_Bay_concession "The Siege of Tsingtao was the attack on the German-controlled port of Tsingtao (now Qingdao) in China during World War I by Imperial Japan and the United Kingdom. It took place between 31 October and 7 November 1914 and was fought by Imperial Japan and the United Kingdom against Germany. It was the first encounter between Japanese and German forces, and also the first Anglo-Japanese operation during the war." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Tsingtao The Germans surrendered the Concession to the Allies on November, 16, 1914

@Mark in NOVA: I remember queuing for standing room and the cheapest seats for the ballet and opera in London a long time after there was TV.  But the crowd was more scruffily dressed -- no hats unless it was cold enough to need a woolly hat!

The building does appear to be the old Opera House: www.nycvintageimages.com/content/old-met-c-1885 This still looks to me more like a line for tickets to a boxing match, but maybe opera had a wider appeal back then.

"Oskar Potiorek (20 November 1853, Bad Bleiberg, Carinthia (now Austria) – 17 December 1933) was an Austrian general who served as the Austro-Hungarian governor of Bosnia and Herzegovina between 1911 and 1914. Potiorek was a co-passenger in the car carrying Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria and his wife Countess Sophie Chotek when they were assassinated in Sarajevo on 28 June 1914, in an event which is seen as the start of World War I." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oskar_Potiorek

Yes, it is him. In November 1914, Columbia, which had banned football revived it for a day!! and Arthur Howe of Yale and Charley Hann of Harvard provided coaching. See NYT of November 25, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60910FB355A15738...

"Eleven"

Seems to be Victoria Adelaide (1885-1970) and Charles Edward (1884-1954). The couple had five children; they were forced to abdicate from his "ducal throne" in 1918, after WWI. Charles, a grandson of Queen Victoria, later joined the Nazi Party and was head of the German Red Cross. They are maternal grandparents to the current King of Sweden. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Victoria_Adelaide_of_Schle... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Edward,_Duke_of_Saxe-Coburg...

Charles sided with Germany in WWI and was in the news in November 1914 because he narrowly escaped being killed by a shell that exploded near him, See NYT of November 25, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D03E2DA1E3EE033A...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carl_Eduard_Sachsen_Coburg_und... is a 1905 picture of him. I think the photo here must date from about the same period, which is both when he became the Duke and when he and Victoria married.

Thanks pennyrichardsca for providing the link to their individual stories, and thanks swanq, for finding the article describing the incident for which he may have been in the news.  I'll untangle the spelling of the name the next time we update the record.

I see there's also a Millicent, Duchess of Sutherland. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=950CE4D71638E633A... She married in October, 1914. Could this be her?

Looked at that, but Millicent was born in 1867, so she would have been 47 in 1914 (for her second marriage).  This looks more like a woman in her early 20s, as Eileen Sutherland-Leveson-Gower would have been that year.  (Millicent would have been Eileen's mother-in-law--Eileen married Millicent's son, the 5th Duke of Sutherland.)

Unless it's an older portrait than the 1914 part of the collection, which was sometimes the case with Bain portraits. By the way, there is a famous and beautiful 1904 John Singer Sargent painting of Duchess Millicent (which she sold when short of funds in the early 20's: jssgallery.org/Paintings/Millicent_Duchess_of_Sutherland.htm She and her 4 sisters were described as "all famous beauties" in her mother's obituary in 1933.

I agree that this is probably Eileen, See www.clanmacfarlanegenealogy.info/genealogy/TNGWebsite/sho... for a picture of Eileen in 1912, when she married the Marquis of Stafford, who became the 5th Duke of Sutherland in 1913 on the death of his father. But MIllicent was certainly a beauty. www.prints-online.com/r2/tatler_cover_duchess_of_sutherla... shows her on the front page of the Tatler in 1901.
Agreed!  They were both quite beautiful.

Yeah, no doubt it's Eileen.  The more I read about this family, the more Downton Abbey looks like a reality show. Millicent's daughter was ruled out as a match for one of the King's sons due to her mother's divorce and other activities.
Thanks to all of you for determining the proper duchess. We'll add some of the information for Eileen to the record the next time we update.

WITH six new shows opening in as many of the larger theatres last week it is strange that the coming week is to be given over entirely to the opening of the smallest theatre in the city, but on Tuesday night the new Punch and Judy Theatre, on Forty-ninth Street, near Broadway, will throw open its doors, when "The Marriage of Columbine," a new comedy in four acts, by Harold Chapin, will be the attraction. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60C16FE3B5916738... >>Grand Duchess Maria Georgianna This would be Maria or Marie Georgievna (perhaps a spelling variant), Princess of Greece and Denmark (Greek: Πριγκίπισσα Μαρία της Ελλάδας και Δανίας) (1876 - 1940). She was the fifth child and second daughter of George I of Greece and Olga Konstantinovna of Russia and as such, a family member of the House of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Glücksburg. "On April 30, 1900, Maria was married to Grand Duke George Mikhailovich of Russia in Corfu. George chased after Maria, who was nicknamed "Greek Minny" to tell her apart from the Dowager Empress Maria of Russia. She refused to marry unless her place in the line of succession to the Greek and Danish thrones was secured. She made it clear that she was not in love with him when she married him, but the Grand Duke hoped that feelings might grow in time. "The couple had two daughters:Nina, born June 7, 1901, and Xenia, born August 9, 1903. As they grew older, Maria seized the opportunity to spend more time abroad, ostensibly for her daughters' health, but also to spend more time away from her husband. She was in Great Britain when World War I broke out and chose not return to Russia" [1]   There are several photographs of The Grand Duke in the LOC Bain Collection on Flickr, here.
This forum has some more pictures of her: forum.alexanderpalace.org/index.php?topic=3936.0 and here's another: www.librarything.com/author/georgegrandduchessof

I don't think it is a spelling variant, as I haven't seen it except in connection with this photo.
I believe "Georgievna" is a patronimic, indicating she is the daughter of George.

Correct: should be Shah.  

From A Chinese student publication from 1914: He was a foreign minister from China.  Earlier a student at Columbia University.  Arrived in New York on his way to Washington DC, with his wife, five children and sixteen servants.

He is Kai Fu Shah (Xia Xiefu), and had been China's Consul General in New York from 1903 to 1908. During that period, he was mentioned regularly in the New York newspapers. In 1914, he arrived in Washington, via New York, as the first envoy to the U.S. of the newly recognized Chinese Republic, and this seems to be the press photo opportunity of April 14, 1914 on the occasion (in Washington) of the presentation of his credentials as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary, Chinese Legation, to the State Department. www.state.gov/s/cpr/91588.htm There are multiple photos from this event in the LOC"s Harris & Ewing collection: www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=kai%20fu%20shah This shot was taken by the Clinedinst Studio of Washington, D.C., a prominent studio so ubiquitous in its Federal Government portraits and subjects that it was sometimes referred to as the Court Photographer of Washington. 19thcenturybaltimore.wordpress.com/2010/07/06/barnett-m-c...

Claudia Carlstedt was an actress who married Albert Gallatin Wheeler Jr., the son of a wealthy capitalist who built the freight tunnels under Chicago query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F40F11F93B5E11... They were divorced in 1912 query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F60B13FC345517... and she then spent many years trying to get him to pay the alimony she had been awarded. Her long and scandalous quest is mentioned several times in the New York Times query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F00A11F63F5C1B... until 1922 when she finally had him arrested and served a court order requiring him to pay up query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FA0B10F93B5D1A... I can't tell from the newspapers whether she ever wound up getting the money.

Here's a little more info. She returned to the New York stage in 1934, appearing in "Big Hearted Herbert" news.google.com/newspapers?id=eMRBAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0qkMA... She died in 1953 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30A13FA3D59107A... Her obituary mentions her early roles in "The Mandarin" and some Victor Herbert operettas and her famous divorce. At the time of her death she lived in Mattituck, Long Island and was married to Frederick Kistler.

An interesting cartoon.  Reims Cathedral was hit by German artillery fire in World War One and sizable portions of the structure were burned, damaged and destroyed.  "Kultur" was a German term used to indicate the whole mass of customs, conventions, usages, laws, institutions, and language from which the Prussian people derived its outlook.  "Krupp" was the name of the business that manufactured German artillery and ammunition (among other war material) during World War One.  The black eagle was used on the Prussian flag.

Essential this cartoon saying that Prussian culture is violent, militaristic, and is anathema to high culture (the Reims Cathedral).

Funny how it's always the other guys who are evil...  The German cathedral at Speyer was ransacked and nearly destroyed by French troops, at least twice -- once under Louis XIV and again under Napoleon.
www.dcfa.com/Prints/Robida/slides/1969.shtml indicates that the cartoon is by ALBERT ROBIDA (1848-1926).
swanq: Thank you for finding the artist of this cartoon.  We'll include his name next time we update the description.

Middle initial should be "F." not "A." This is a photo of John F. Hurley, Mayor of Salem, Massachusetts. He was mayor during "The Great Salem Fire of 1914" which occurred June 25th of that year. While relatively few lives were reportedly lost, the fire destroyed over 1,300 buildings, leaving approximately 20,000 people homeless and 10,000 jobless. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Salem_Fire_of_1914 A panoramic photo of the resulting devastation (Photo credit: Wikipedia Commons):

The Atlantic Cat Club annual show at the Waldorf Astoria, Nov. 17-18, 1914? query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D00E5DA1738E633A... No mention of this pair in the Times article, but Mrs. A.M. McAllister is listed as having a winning orange tabby in the New York Herald of 11/18/14.

Unusual to identify the cat as well as the owner, but this is probably Alcyone, the prize-winning Smoke Persian of New York's Mrs. Anna M. McAllister. Alcyone was the subject of a heartwarming story in the Evening Telegram of 12/8/14. The story includes a picture of Alcyone. Here is an excerpt: "Alcyone, Beautiful Persian, Shows He Can Do More than Win Blue Ribbons. - • • - OWNER IS PARALYZED AND WAITING FOR DEATH -•••••- Finds Amusement, Relaxation and Comfort in Antics and Loyalty of Pet Nestling upon the lap of his atrophied patient, amusing the ill man with his antics at play, or running to call the mistress of the household when her presence is needed, Alcyone, John. McAllister's pet, companion, friend and attendant, illustrates the fact that a cat is some good in the world in other ways than as a mouse catcher or a prize winner. Alcyone is a beautiful smoke Persian, winner of two prizes in the recent cat show in Grand Central Palace and a highly intelligent animal, but he is more highly prized for his faithfulness and loyalty to his owner, condemned by slowly increasing paralysis to pass the greater part of his time for five years in bed. If it were not for Alcyone, as well as for the devotion of Mrs. McAllister, Mr. McAllister might long ago have become desperate." fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/New%20York%20NY%20Evenin... Alcyone is also listed, along with her owners and prizes, in the 1913 Cat Fanciers Association Stud Book and Register" books.google.com/books?id=eEwuAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA4&dq=...
It looks like Persians were less flat-faced then. Probably could breathe better...

This is a photo of HMS Hibernia and a Short Improved S.27 biplane, likely taken in May 1912, when Hibernia was engaged in various test flights conducted by Commander Charles Samson (RN) flying the aircraft from a makeshift flight deck placed upon the forward portion of the ship. The deck was removed from Hibernia after the trials were completed. See: HMS Hibernia (1905) - Early Career

This appears to be the barrel segment (it was transported in three parts) of the Skoda 305 mm Model 1911 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skoda_305_mm_Model_1911. 8 were loaned to the German army in August, 1914 by the Austro-Hungarian Army for use in destroying Belgian fortifications at Liege and elsewhere. One account states that Austro-Hungarian soldiers operated these in Belgium. An extremely detailed, illustrated article on this weapon: www.landships.freeservers.com/305mm_morser_m11.htm

Back to the flag issue. I've found a Russian flag that looks a bit like this. See www.vexillographia.ru/russia/index.htm The Google translation about it is, "The Museum of the Armed Forces in Moscow is stored as a flag of Military Operations Division Centrobalt - pre-revolutionary flag fleet commander with sewn on the bottom of the flag in red letters "SF RR" (Free Fleet of the Russian Republic)." A Google image search yielded www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/ru~xix.html which has the flag without the letters mentioned above. It is identified as "Flag of the fleet commander (1899-1917)" Both these flags have a big blue diagonal cross which I don't see in the Bain photo. But that could be what represents the high rank (judging from other flags on the crwflags page). That page points to another Russian page, www.navy.ru/symbols/anflag.htm , this one looking to be an official Russian Navy page. It includes flags which just have the top left quadrant with either a plain red or plain blue background. So I'm coming to the conclusion that the flag here is a Russian flag after all. www.vexillographia.ru/russia/index.htm has a bunch of flags of this general form, with the same top left quadrant, a white background, and some additional symbol. I don't see a symbol that matches what I see in this picture, and these were apparently approved in 1916. But I'm even more convinced this is a Russian flag.
Wow, good research. Yes, the flag in the photo does bear much more resemblance to the Russian division flags than to anything British. It would also make sense, considering the context of the photo.

Found it! The airforce was originally a branch of the Imperial Russian Navy, hence the anchor

it is unlikely that this would be 1910 if it is a "captured" Russian airplane (by the Germans).  The war did not start until 1914, and the two countries were at peace up until then.
The next question is...  what was it?  The engine, unless I'm mistaken, Gnome Monosoupe 9.  No machine gun interrupt, you can see the the bolts holding on the deflector plates on the propeller.

The gnome engine of that period had an odd number of cylinders usually 5 7 or 9.  This engine has 8 cylinders which makes it a virtual certainty that could only be one engine from that period (and this plane is actually German?). What is that white banner across the top of the photo?

Actually, all rotary engines had odd numbers, and if you look at the positioning of the cylinders, you will see that there is a cylinder behind the propeller.  And by "banner", do you mean the white steak where it looks like tape was once attached to the photo, preventing the emulsion in that area from greying, like it otherwise has?

Yes. I was wondering "what's hidden behind the banner.  With regard to engines- four stroke radials are always odd in cylinder count. But two stroke engines have even cylinder counts and are lighter (ie good for early aircraft) and simpler than four stroke engines. However I will recount the cylinders.  I thought I was including the hidden ones, but perhaps not.

Rotary and single bank radial engines did not use counterbalancing cylinder action, and were all odd numbers, example, the 9 cylinder Wright R-1820, the engine used in the B-17 bomber and many other applications in WW2. To understand how a rotary engine is put together and works, Vintage Aviator has many pictures of their new Oberursel engine construction, which was a copy of the Le Rhone engine of the same period (thevintageaviator.co.nz/files/images/ur2-assembly/screens...). Notice how the crank has only a single offset, with all the cylinder rods attaching at the same point.

An account of the mission and sendoff of the Christmas Ship Jason in the World Almanac, 1915: THE SANTA CLAUS SHIP. The World co-operated to the fullest extent with the Chicago Herald and perhaps 150 other newspapers of the United States to this end—that the children of Europe, whose fathers have been killed in the war might be remembered by Santa Claus on Christmas. The Idea originated with James Keeley, publisher of the Chicago Herald. Generous response to the call on behalf of the children was made. The World established sixty-four receiving depots In New York. A general receiving station was established through the co-operation of Dock Commissioner R.A.C. Smith. This station was on the upper deck of Pier No. 1, North River. Its use was given to Commissioner Smith on behalf of the Christmas Ship by the lessees, the Iron Steamboat Company. The American Red Cross, under the guidance of` Miss Mabel T. Boardman, co-operated by offering to convey and deliver gifts to the children. This co-operation meant a wide and impartial distribution. Irving T. Bush, President of the Bush Terminal Company, offered the use, without cost, of the Bush Terminal stores. Gifts were handled there as well as at the Iron Steamboat Pier. The collier Jason was given by Secretary of the Navy Josephus Daniels to carry the Christmas presents to Europe. The quantity of merchandise that was sent in response to The World's call for help for the orphan children was great. The pier was strung with electric lights and the work of preparing the cargo for shipment was rushed night and day. The soldiers from Fort Hamilton worked under Major Lawton of the Quartermaster's Department assorting the gifts. A company of marines helped the Red Cross representatives. The wives and daughters of the officers on Governor's Island and many others worked each day until the gifts were all stowed away in the big collier. When she steamed away, Lieutenant-Commander C. E. Courtney commanding, she bore 6,000,000 gifts. It was probably the most remarkable cargo that any ship ever carried from this or any other port. She was given a great send-off. Mayor Mitchel sent a letter and Mr. McAneny as his representative to see her sail. John Callan O'Laughlin, representing the Chicago Herald, went with the ship as American Commissioner. All paid tribute to the work of The World to the end that the undertaking might be a success and bring Joy, or at least a measure of comfort, to the helpless children, sufferers because of the war. books.google.com/books?id=-GQ3AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA25&lp...

According to Wikipedia, "Count Viktor Dankl von Krasnik (German: Viktor Graf Dankl von Krasnik, born as Viktor Dankl on September 18, 1854, in Udine, died January 8, 1941 in Innsbruck) was a highly decorated career Austro-Hungarian officer who reached the pinnacle of his service during World War I with promotion to the rare rank of Colonel General (Generaloberst). His successful career met an abrupt end in 1916 due to both his performance on the Italian front and health issues. After the war he would be a vocal apologist for both his country's war record and the dethroned Habsburg monarchy."

Henrietta Rodman was a feminist and teacher in New York City, vice president of the League for the Civic Service of Women, who protested the ban on married women teachers by marrying a friend in 1914, SOLELY to challenge the law (her husband's girlfriend was cool with this plan). Friend Floyd Dell noted wryly, “she couldn’t even do so conventional a thing as get married, without creating a terrific sensation.” She was suspended for more than a year. The clothing above was typical of her dress-reform style -- heavy sack-like tunics and boots (linen sacks and sandals in the summertime). Sources on Henrietta Rodman include: Julie C. Laible, “Henrietta Rodman and Other Modern Feminists: Redefining the New Professional Teacher,” Journal of the Midwest History of Education Society 22(1995): 229-239; June Sochen, “Henrietta Rodman and the Feminist Alliance, 1914-1917,” Journal of Popular Culture 4(1)(Summer 1970): 57-65.

Thanks, pennylrichardsca, for the information and sources. 1914 seems to have been a big year for challenging the status quo in the New York City school system, given the information you and swanq also supplied about Mrs. Lora Wagner ( flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6358159445 ).

Indeed!  I ran into Henrietta Rodman in an earlier project on the married-women-teachers ban, so I was excited to see her come up, and it was easy to find my old sources on her to share here.  She's quite a character, plenty of news stories about her doings.  And she knew a lot of the 1910s bohemian set in Greenwich Village, so she turns up on the margins of a lot of biographies and memoirs covering that era.   If I get a chance, I'll gin up a wikipedia entry for her soon.

Mrs. Lora Wagner was a married New York City teacher who protested the New York City policy of suspending teachers who became mothers. She gave birth just 13 hours after leaving the classroom; while still recovering, she wrote to the mayor, asking him to direct the Board of Education to change their policies about teachers and maternity leave. See: Patricia Carter, "Becoming the 'New Women': the Equal Rights Campaigns of New York City Schoolteachers, 1900-1920," in Richard Altenbaugh, ed., The Teacher's Voice: A Social History of Teaching in Twentieth-Century America (Psychology Press 1992): 54.

That's all I got here: JB MDL Dix (Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst Dix), better known as Fort Dix, is a United States Army base located approximately 16.1 miles (25.9 km) south-southeast of Trenton, New Jersey. Dix is under the jurisdiction of the United States Army Reserve Command (USARC). It became part of Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst (JB MDL) on 1 October 2009. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JB_MDL_Dix I sometimes wonder if it's possible to control the upload order on Flickr Commons? There's been cases in the past when amazing sets have gone largely unnoticed because the last picture uploaded (the one that appears in most followers' contacts) is not as visually striking, at least in thumbnail, as some others.

Looking at the largest resolution version of this image, it appears the rifles being turned in are obsolete Krag-Jorgensen rifles.   By the beginning of World War I, the Krag had already been replaced in most front-line American units by the legendary Model 1903 Springfield rifle (M1903).  While the M1903 was selected to replaced the Krag, and had done so for the most part by the beginning of the war, it would be the lesser-known M1917 Enfield rifle that would equip 75% of the American Expeditionary Force (AEF) in Europe by the end of the war.

A few of the early arriving American units in Europe were equipped with the Krag, but it  saw an extremely limited amount of combat.  It is more likely the rifles photographed being turned in at Camp Dix (later Fort Dix) actually equipped a stateside-based unit and/or were used for training purposes during the First World War.

"In 1918, the German Army established its principal Headquarters in Spa, and it was from here that the delegates set out for the French lines to meet Marshal Foch and sue for peace in the consultations leading up to the Armistice which ended the First World War. In July 1920 it hosted the meeting of the Supreme Council. German delegates were invited to this to discuss war reparations." At 2020 hours four cars, with full headlights, displaying white flags and carrying a trumpeter sounding the cease fire approached the French lines at La Pierre d'Haudroy. It was pouring with rain and a thick mist hung over the ground." A couple of corrections are to be made.
1. This is not Ghent, but Deinze, a city at about 15 miles SW of Ghent.  The church is the Our Lady Church and the soldiers are crossing the river Leie (Lys).

Elbert H. Gary gdynets.webng.com/bio.htm and www.dupageheritage.org/yps/gary.html Gary, Indiana was named after him. He was "DuPage County Judge before the turn of the century, when it was considered a public service that prominent lawyers accepted. Mr. Gary was elected to a first term in 1884 and served a second term from 1888 until 1892. Curiously, for the remainder of his long life, he was always addressed as 'Judge Gary' even by his friend, President Theodore Roosevelt, and other national leaders." He was a principal in United States Steel Corporation when it was founded in 1901. "Judge" Gary remained the chief executive officer of the United States Steel Corporation until the day of his death more than twenty-six years later.
Quite the man! Wonderful portrait! Thanks for the fascinating history. -- Seen in my contacts' photos. (?)

Elbert Henry Gary (October 8, 1846 – August 15, 1927) was an American lawyer, county judge and corporate officer. He was a key founder of U.S. Steel in 1901, bringing together partners J. P. Morgan, Andrew Carnegie, and Charles M. Schwab. The city of Gary, Indiana, a steel town, was named for him when it was founded in 1906. When trust busting President Theodore Roosevelt said that Gary was head of the steel trust, Gary considered it a compliment. The two men communicated in a non-confrontational way unlike Roosevelt's relationship with leaders of other trusts. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elbert_Henry_Gary

John L. Billard of Meriden CT, coal dealer, president of a building supplies company, big stockholder in regional railroads. www.lyon-billard.com/lyon-billard-history.html
So picturesque man

His appearance in the Bain collection is probably in connection with his dealings in an infamous transaction which resulted in criminal and civil actions against him in October and November, 1914. He was accused of being the middleman in a case where one railroad had been ordered to divest its holdings in another. Being a wealthy coal merchant, but without a background in railroading, he claimed he offered to buy the holdings, which he did, then re-sold them to an affiliate of the seller for a $2.7 Million profit. Actually, Charles S. Mellen, the selling party for the Boston Maine Railroad, helped finance this collusive sale as a conspiratorial transaction to later re-acquire the divested shares. Both men were indicted by the government and subjected to a civil suit for restitution of the money gained in the transaction. One of the many stories on the scandal: "NEW HAVEN SUES BILLARD TO GET $3,828,147 BACK; Mellen and Five Others Also Defendants in Action Over Boston & Maine Sale. NOT A BONA FIDE TRANSFER Secret Trust Formed to Hide Real Ownership of Stock, New Management Alleges. DENIES CASH WAS BILLARD'S His Claim That It Was Called Fraudulent ;- Proceedings Prompted by Interstate Board Inquiry." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9507E6D71638E633A... On November 5th, the day before the Bain negative date, he had appeared in court in New York to answer the criminal indictment for conspiring to monopolize the transportation business in New England. "WM. ROCKEFELLER AND BILLARD PLEAD; Appear Personally in Court and Answer Not Guilty to New Haven Indictments. CAME EARLY TO AVOID CROWD Oil Man Seemed Nervous and Answered Clerk's Questions Indistinctly. BILLARD HAS OWN LAWYER Does Not Use Counsel Provided for Other Directors ;- Rockefeller Poses for Photographers." query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F0DE6DE1738E633A...

This appears to be one of several débutante announcement photographs of Margaret Resler Warren of New York City, who was introduced to society on December 9, 1913, with a reception, dinner and dance. A daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Elliott Warren, Margaret was a descendant of Revolutionary War General Warren of Bunker Hill. She was a graduate of The Spence School. Her father was President of the Lincoln National Bank. [1] [2] A different photograph of Miss Warren, by Campbell Studios, appeared in the October 19, 1913, New York Times, however the accompanying article seems to have been, perhaps, cut of débutante announcements. A variant of the above pose, by Mishkin Studios, is in the Bain Collection (shown below) of The Library of Congress, and will no doubt find its way to Flickr ;)                                     On January 22, 1921, Margaret Warren married Shannon Lord Meany (b.1892), the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Meany (b.1854) of Alnwick Hall, Convent, New Jersey. He was a graduate of Princeton and served as a captain during the war. Their engagement was announced in October, 1920. [3] [4] [5] [6] Margaret and Shannon Meany separated in 1939, and she was awarded a divorce in Reno in 1940. [7] [8]

This appears to be the former Estelle Barbour (1878-1960) who was born in Wethersfield, Connecticut, and grew up in Grosse Pointe Farms, near Detroit. The daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Barbour, her father was a Detroit manufacturer. [1] [2] Estelle Barbour married George S. Stillman of New York City, in Detroit on April 24, 1906. George Schley Stillman (1879–1907), a son of J.F. Stillman of New York City, "was an American football player and coach. He played college football at Yale University where he was selected as a first-team All-American at the tackle position in both 1899 and 1900. Stillman coached the 1901 Yale football team to a record of 11–1–1. The team was later recognized as a national champion by Parke H. Davis." –Wikipedia Married less than a year, George Stillman died of meningitis in 1907 after contracting typhoid fever. Twenty three years later Mrs. Estelle Barbour Stillman married Hobart C. Chatfield-Taylor (1865-1945) of Santa Barbara, California, on June 23, 1920. She was 45 at the time, he was 55. Long prominent in Chicago society, Hobart Chatfield-Taylor was an author of several novels. His first wife, the late Rose Farwell, was the daughter of the late United States Senator Farwell, of Illinois, and Rose and Estelle were long-time friends. A wedding-day photograph of Mr. and Mrs. Hobart C. Chatfield-Taylor taken as they left the church appeared in The New York Tribune. –LOC Chronicling America, [3]
Thanks Pixel Wrangler for the additional information. We will update our records with her full name.

Bucknam Pasha or Pacha (1869-1915) was a Canadian-born American citizen, Ransford Dodsworth Bucknam, who served as a Rear Admiral in the Turkish Navy. He was working as an officer at a shipbuilding company in Philadelphia; he delivered a war ship to Constantinople, and became a favorite of the Sultan's. He later formed the Ottoman Anglo-American Company. maviboncuk.blogspot.com/2010/03/bucknam-pasha-of-ottoman-... yesteryearsnews.wordpress.com/tag/ransford-d-bucknam/

I found mention in Aerial Age Weekly of a General Liu Tsching-En of the Chinese Army, director of the Hanyang Arsenal at Hupeh China, visiting the Curtiss factory at Buffalo in 1915...from there, worked out that he's General T. E. Liu, who contracted with Pratt and Whitney to produce prototypes of his rifle design in Connecticut. The "Liu Rifle" is a rarity because much of the initial shipment was lost at sea, and it was never put into production in China. Video here about the Liu Rifle talks about General Liu: www.forgottenweapons.com/bin-shih-and-the-general-liu-rifle

Fielding Harris Yost (1871–1946) was an American football player, coach, and college athletics administrator. "After four single-season stints at Ohio Wesleyan, Nebraska, Kansas, Stanford and San Jose State (as interim coach), Yost was hired in 1901 as the head football coach for the Michigan Wolverines football team (1901–1923, 1925–1926), compiling a career college football record of 198–35–12. "During his 25 seasons as the head football coach in Ann Arbor, Yost's Michigan Wolverines won six national championships, captured ten Big Ten Conference titles, and amassed a record of 165–29–10. "Yost invented the position of linebacker, co-created the first ever bowl game, the 1902 Rose Bowl, with then legendary UM athletic director Charles Baird, invented the fieldhouse concept that bears his name, and supervised the building of the first on-campus building dedicated to intramural sports" — compiled Wikipedia                                                    ———————   In 1908, William P. "Big Bill" Edmunds was a student under Coach Yost at Michigan for the first few weeks of the early practice season. [1]   It would appear that the above photograph was taken during this short time. Edmunds later became Head Football Coach at Washington University in St. Louis from 1913-1916. On November 4, 1916, Washington University, coached by Bill Edmunds, played Michigan at Ann Arbor -- coached by Yost. Michigan edged out Washington in that game 66-7. [2]

Yost is buried in Forest Hill Cemetery, here in Ann Arbor. Don't know about Edmunds.

William Cameron "Gib" Cool, (1894-1933), Class of 1916, played Center (Number 4) for Cornell University football, in this game against Brown University, October 24, 1914, at the Polo Grounds (Brush Stadium) in New York. Cornell toppled defeated Brown 28 - 7. Cool was selected as an All-American after his senior year in 1915. He was inducted [posthumously] into the Cornell Athletic Hall of Fame in 1981. After graduation from Cornell, Cool coached the University of Tennessee football team for one year. During World War I, Cool enlisted in the U.S. Army, serving as an instructor in the School of Fire at Fort Sill, Oklahoma. — [1] [2] [3]

Al Sharpe, coach of the Cornell University 'Varsity 11, in this game against Brown University, October 24, 1914, at the Polo Grounds (Brush Stadium) in New York. Cornell defeated Brown 28-7. "Dr. Albert Hayes Sharpe (1877–1966) was an All-American football player, coach and athletic director and medical doctor. He played football for Yale University and was selected as a halfback for the 1899 College Football All-America Team. Sharpe was also a star basketball player in the early years of the college game. Sharpe also excelled in baseball, gymnastics, rowing and track. In 1915, Sharpe was selected by one sporting expert as the greatest living athlete in the United States. He later served as a coach and administrator at Cornell University, Yale, the Ithaca School of Physical Education and Washington University in St. Louis." — Wikipedia

NYT of Oct 18, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0CE4D6133DE333A... indicates that numbering jerseys was still the exception. "Brown University has adopted the numbering system for identification of its players on the field in the football game with Cornell at the Polo Grounds next Saturday. As the Ithacans agreed to have their representatives on the gridiron wear numerals, spectators at the only big college game of the season in New York will be able to follow each play with personal interest in the chief figures in the contest. " Numbering was clearly controversial for several years. Brown and Cornell were clearly already in favor. Brown suggested using numbers for this 1914 game. See NYT of Feb10, 1913 for support for numbering from Sharpe, the Cornell coach. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60717F6355E1373... In contrast, Yale (as an institution) argued against it. See NYT of Nov 7, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B04E7D8113CE633A... "The officials at the university feel that labeling the undergraduates savors too much of hippodroming." From what I can see, by 1919 Harvard, Princeton, and Yale were coming round to the idea. By late 1922, it was described as "almost universal." See NYT of Dec 21, 1922 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60A10FE3D551B7A...

I believe this is actually Forêt de l'Aigle ,which I think is now Forêt Domaniale de Laigue located outside Choisy-au-Bac and Compiegne. From The Literary Digest History of the World War: "SOISSONS AND THE BOMBARDMENT OF REIMS - TRENCH WARFARE September 13, 1914—September 27, 1914 SUNDAY, September 13, was the first day of the great frontal battle on the Aisne. A more detailed account of it must be given here. The German army had then crossed and taken up positions on the north bank between Compiegne and Soissons and toward Reims. Heavy artillery had been rushed down from the north and placed on various strategic points, notably in the quarries behind Soissons, at Vic-sur-Aisne, and at Attichy. On the right the army was protected by the Forest of l'Aigle and the Oise, which descends almost due south from Noyon. It was an extremely strong position, capable only of frontal attack. It was clear from the outset that these fortified positions must be fought for and taken, no matter how great the effort, how terrible the sacrifice." books.google.com/books?id=Q58MAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA128&...

Non ? Peut-être… Gruault "l'espion" a bien été envoyé au bagne. Or on lit dans l'article "Détective", crime et bon sentiment d'Olivier Costemalle dans Libération du 17 février 2001 : La rédaction fait campagne contre la guillotine, contre le bagne. Un beau jour, un homme se présente dans les bureaux, au 35 de la rue Madame. Il se nomme Paul Gruault, et vient tout juste d'être libéré de Cayenne. «Vous prétendez vous battre pour qu'on en finisse avec le bagne, mais pour les bagnards, que faites-vous?» Gaston Gallimard le prend au mot, et l'embauche comme comptable. The man who appeared at the offices of Gallimard 15 years later, after being released from the Cayenne penal colony, Paul Gruault, might be the same Corporal Grualt or Gruault in the picture above. www.liberation.fr/medias/0101364359-detective-crime-et-bo... I could not find his first name or any details of his sentence, except that the article posted by rjones086 above says Groualt was sentenced to death. That's why I think it is only possible, not probable, that Paul Gruault of Gallimard is the man in the photo above.

I cannot find any articles that give the first name of Corporal Gruault (The contemporary newspaper articles spell his name this way so Bain's "Grualt" is incorrect). I did find an article from December 28, 1913 about a Paul Gruault, age 28, a bookkeeper, convicted of stealing jewels from the jewelry store where he worked. His name and occupation match those of the man who later worked for Gallimard after 15 years in the penal colony of Cayenne, so I am inclined to think that it was this Gruault, not the soldier in the photo accused of espionage who was Gallimard's employee. Here is the URL of the article, from the newspaper L'Ouest-Éclair (Éd. de Caen): gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k492391x (The article is at lower left on the page) A crude translation, via Google Translate, tells the story: "A NICE "CLEAN" JEWELRY OR HIT THE WINDOW Paris, December 28. Paul Gruault, 28 years, residing 101 rue Saint Dominique, was employed as an accountant in expeditionary a jeweler of the Rue de la Paix which was in high esteem. Most recently, the jeweler looked in vain for a pair of earrings. At one point, he approached Paul Gruault and said kindly: Could you help me in my research? Paul Gruault hesitated, turned pale and asked leave of absence. The next day, he did not come to the store. He was thought ill, they would learn at his home. He had not returned since twenty-four hours. The jeweler continued his research and found that he was missing pins, rings, necklaces, pendant,two pearls, a wrist bracelet, etc.., in all for 20,000 francs of jewelry. He noticed Paul Gruault was not the only one guilty of embezzlement. A polisher, Widow Riviere, 48, 11 rue Louis-le-Grand, had contributed. Here's how the two employees infidels: when the jewelry out to clean the windows, they announced a couple of articles less. They brought out seventeen, for example, and they said there were only fifteen or sixteen. Their boss believed that the items were also in the store and did not realize the theft. The stolen jewels were then pawned or sold. After an investigation by highly skilled police, the two thieves were arrested and yesterday they appeared before Mr. Judge Bouchardon. They both said they had acted in moments of madness. Paul Gruault said, bursting into tears, I went to the richest young people me, I wanted to spend like them, I wanted to shine, I'm unhappy. Paul Gruault and the widow Riviere committed their flights independently from each other they were not associated, and their surprise was great to be together at the judge. Gruault stated that since leaving the store, he erred through the streets with the thought of suicide,but courage had failed him."

This appears to be a photo of a painting

Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener. Commanded British troops at the beginning of World War I until his death in 1916 when the ship he was aboard struck a German mine. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Kitchener,_1st_Earl_Kitchener

www.royalcollection.org.uk/egallery/object.asp?maker=1266.... May be the portrait although the reproduction on the Royal Collection website is very dark. If so, the painting is by Heinrich von Angeli and was painted by request of Queen Victoria around 1898-90. See books.google.com/books?id=Qi4OAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA117&l... for circumstances of the sitting for Heinrich von Angeli and a photo that might well have been taken at the same time on page 116. That would date the sitting to July 1899 and locate it in Buckingham Palace. He was in the news in October 1914, because he was Secretary of State for War.

NYPL has a copy that looks to come from a book or newspaper and a search for the caption yields www.oldimprints.com/OldImprints/search.cfm?UR=47258&s... which indicates that the picture was in a supplement to the Illustrated London News. It mentions Angelo [sic] as the artist.
www.gac.culture.gov.uk/work.aspx?obj=31594 shows another portrait in same uniform and at similar age, a photogravure published in 1900 from a painting by Arthur Cope.

The New York Times reported on 10/26/14 that the ship (one of the most powerful in the world at that time) was in New York for painting at the (Brooklyn) Navy Yard and had left the day before for sea trial. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E05E1D91430E733A...

LOC: Given this info, the 1910 date should be changed. Dry dock No. 4 at the Brooklyn Navy Yard had been recently completed. Here is some of its history from Engineering News of 1912: "Dry Dock No. 4, at the Brooklyn U. S. Navy Yard, has finally been completed after seven years' labor, during which three different contractors have successively taken over the contract. The dock is of concrete construction, 695 ft.long, 139 ft. wide and 31ft. deep, providing dockage for the largest naval vessels now contemplated. The contract for its construction was first let in 1905 to George Spearin, but the immense difficulties in foundation construction, resulting from the soft bottom encountered, caused that firm to abandon the job, and in 1907 it was relet to the Williams Engineering Co. Soon after, when only 15% of the work had been completed, that firm, too, was forced to abandon the contract. It was then thought that the Government would have to continue the work by day labor, but this was decided against and bids were asked for the completion of the work from private companies, plans for its prosecution to be submitted with the bid. Under this arrangement the contract was awarded in October, 1909, to Holbrook, Cabot & Rollins, of Boston, Mass. This firm carried the construction to a successful conclusion, and on May 10, 1912 it was emptied to allow the docking of the 22,000-ton U. S. battleship "Utah." The operation proved successful. The original appropriation for the construction was $1,500,000, of which $240,000 was expended in the first two attempts at construction. The final bid was $1,390,000, which was subsequently Increased to $2,750,000." books.google.com/books?id=YeMRAQAAMAAJ&vq=944&lr&... I believe it is the only dry dock at the Brooklyn yard with a round end, and there appear to be many pictures of ships docked in it in the Bain collection.

Thanks artolog for the interesting tale of the building of this drydock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and for catching the date written on the negative.  While 1910 to 1915 is the general date for these negatives, we are glad when people identify more specific dates which provide better context. In this case, the date written on the negative "10/23/14", closely matches the date of  the New York Times article of 10/26/14 which reports on the painting of the Moreno  at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Thus we can add a location as well as a more specific date to our image description to assist future researchers

THE IRON RING IS WORN BY 10,000 NEW YORKERS OF GERMAN BLOOD For the Sake of the Fatherland These People Are Giving Their Gold and Other Valuables in Exchange for the Historic Ring of Loyalty. October 14, 1914 New York Times "LOYALTY to the Fatherland to evidence, gave I, in troublous time, gold for this iron." One hundred years ago many German women were wearing rings of iron engraved with this inscription. These were the rings issued during the Napoleonic wars, a "troublous time," indeed, and they signified that the wearer had pledged her gold or her jewels in the cause of Germany. Today over ten thousand in New York City are wearing iron rings engraved with this same inscription. It has been done so quietly that the public has not realized it. Yet since the first of September there has been a steady stream of the Germans of this city to a little kodak and phonograph shop far up on Second Avenue. Here the women have been bringing their jewels, their heirlooms, the men their watches, their musical instruments and money, to receive in return their iron ring.

Annette Abbott Adams From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annette_Abbott_Adams Annette Abbott Adams Annette Abbott Adams (12 March 1877 – 26 October 1956) was an American lawyer and judge. Born Annette Grace Abbot in Prattville, California, Adams was educated at the Chico State Normal School and the University of California, where she obtained her undergraduate degree in 1904, and her law degree in 1912. Before beginning her legal career, she taught grammar school and was one of the first female school principals in California, at Modoc County High School, in Alturas. In 1912, she was admitted to the State Bar of California.[1] She campaigned for Woodrow Wilson in California, and was rewarded after his election with an appointment as an Assistant United States Attorney in the Northern District of California, 1914–1919. In 1918–1920 she was attorney in the same district. In 1920 she was appointed as the first female Assistant Attorney General of the United States, an office which she resigned in 1921. Adams ran unsuccessfully for a seat on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors in 1923. She had a successful private law practice until 1935, when she was appointed Assistant Special Counsel of U.S. Oil litigation. In 1942, California Governor Culbert Olson appointed her as Presiding Justice of the California Court of Appeal for the Third District in Sacramento. That court was, at the time, one of four intermediate appellate courts in California--intermediate, that is, between the trial courts located in every county, and the California Supreme Court. As the Presiding Justice for the Third District, Justice Adams was thus one of the four highest-ranking judges in the state after the Justices of the Supreme Court. She won election to a twelve-year term on the court of appeal later in 1942, but retired in 1952 for health reasons. In her time on the court, she wrote over 350 opinions. In 1950, she served by special assignment on one case in the California Supreme Court, becoming the first woman to sit on that court (Gardner v. Jonathon Club (1950) 35 Cal.2d 343) [2] Adams died at her home in Sacramento in 1956.
Interesting :)

Her official biography from the California courts website is as follows, and is a little different as to some details than the wikipedia account above: "Annette Abbott Adams (March 12, 1877 - October 26, 1956) Presiding Justice, May 1942 - November 1952 An extraordinary woman and true trailblazer, Annette Abbott Adams was one of the first women school principals in California, one of the first two women to receive a law degree from the University of California, one of the first women to be admitted to the California Bar, the first woman to serve as a U.S. Attorney, the first woman appointed Assistant U.S. Attorney General, and the first woman to serve as an appellate court justice in California. She was born March 12, 1877, in Prattville, Plumas County, and attended Chico State Normal School, University of California, Berkeley (BL, 1904), and Boalt Hall (JD, 1912). Adams taught grammar school and was principal of Modoc County High School, Alturas, prior to her career in law. Admitted to the California Bar in 1912, she practiced law in Quincy, and then in San Francisco, before becoming Assistant U.S. Attorney, 1914-18, and U.S. Attorney, 1918-20. After serving as Assistant U.S. Attorney General, 1920-21, she returned to San Francisco and practiced law there until 1935, when she was appointed Assistant Special Counsel of U.S. oil litigation. In March 1942, she became California's first female appellate justice when Governor Olson appointed her Presiding Justice of the Court of Appeal, Third Appellate District. Justice Adams retired December 1952; she died at her Sacramento home four years later, October 26, 1956." www.courts.ca.gov/2673.htm

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_I_of_Belgium and from that article: Post-War trip to the United States of America From September 23rd till November 13th, 1919, the King together with the Queen Elisabeth of Bavaria and Prince Léopold undertook an official visit to the United States of America. During a journey in the historic Indian pueblo of Isleta in New Mexico, the King decorates of the Order of Léopold father Anton Docher,[8] which offers him a turquoise cross mounted in silver made by the Indians Tiwas.[9] 10 000 persons journeyed to Isleta for the occasion.

If this was related to a 1919 visit, it is another example of Bain's negatives being out of order. NYT of September 17, 1911 suggested that Albert would come to the US soon. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A04E0DD163CE633A... But so far I have not found mention of a visit before WWI. According to this NYT piece he was a journalist before he ascended the throne and used to travel incognito. So maybe he was in the US earlier, although the piece implies not. This does not look to be an official royal photo. It also looks to be a photo of Albert as a young man. emily-chauviere.suite101.com/the-marriage-of-king-albert-... has a photo of him, looking very similar. That photo was probably taken in 1900 about the time of his marriage. Another 1900 picture is on eBay (at least for now) -- www.ebay.com/itm/BELGIUM-LE-PRINCE-ALBERT-BELGIQUE-R-PHOT...

So, looking now for a visit to the United States as prince, I find that he came in 1898. NYT of March 9, 1898 announced that he arrived the day before. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=950DE4D6123CE433A... So, my guess is that this photo was taken by "A. Dupont" (?) during that visit and re-photographed and labeled after he became king in 1909.

Now chasing the photographer... www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/cph.3a23126/ is a 1900 picture copyrighted by an Aime Dupont in New York. The signature is similar. american-miniatures20c.blogspot.com/2006/04/wilmot-alta-e... suggests that "Aime Dupont, a Belgian sculptor turned photographer and his wife, photographer Etta Greer had both moved to New York, after having established a reputation as a portraitist of opera singers in Paris." It also indicates that Dupont died in 1903. It seems likely that a Belgian photographer in New York might take a photo of the Belgian prince when he visited the city.
Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Photo Shapes and I'd love you to join and add this photo to my group! Plus any other suitable photos you'd like to add. Thanks!
@swanq: neat detective work, as usual!

swanq:

What thorough research, thank you!  It does seem that Bain had a habit of finding earlier photographs - often of European royals - for use in the paper when something significant happened, like a crowning or other event.  

The sticker on the upper left corner of this image has a very faint 1914 date and perhaps October or November as the month. King Albert of Belgium was in the news quite a bit in the last part of 1914 as he was personally leading the Belgian army in their battle against the invading German forces.  Numerous articles in U.S. newspapers speak about the battles fought, his injuries and his heroics, so it is not surprising this image might have appeared in the papers. (For example, a Nov. 12, 1914 article in the Chicago Tribune is titled King Albert of Belgium a Hero of All Europe.)

I checked the original photograph of Anna Held you cited with the name of the photographer and completely agree that this is the same signature, and is for Aime Dupont.  King Albert would have been a 22 year old prince in 1898, which does seem right for the photo here, and that Dupont was a Belgian photographer is a good point. 

With all of this in mind, we will add more information to the record.  Thanks again for the diligent research!

Renaud Camus:

Thank you for your comment, and close attention!  You are right, considering that Princess Ileana was born in January 1909 and is clearly still quite young in this photo, so her mother was Crown Princess Marie at the time, not Queen.  This photograph was likely acquired by the Bain News Service in October 1914 when she became Queen of Romania. It was not uncommon for Bain to use older portrait photographs in this way.  In the interest of preserving the archival record, we try to leave Bain's given titles (in this case, Queen of Rumania), but we can add more information to the record to clarify that this photo dates from an earlier year.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress] As per Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_Athletics#Elephant_mascot Elephant mascot After New York Giants' manager John McGraw told reporters that Philadelphia manufacturer Benjamin Shibe, who owned the controlling interest in the new team, had a "white elephant on his hands," Mack defiantly adopted the white elephant as the team mascot, and presented McGraw with a stuffed toy elephant at the start of the 1905 World Series. McGraw and Mack had known each other for years, and McGraw accepted it graciously. By 1909, the A's were wearing an elephant logo on their sweaters, and in 1918 it turned up on the regular uniform jersey for the first time. Over the years the elephant has appeared in several different colors. It is currently forest green. The A’s are still sometimes, though infrequently, referred to as the "Elephants" or "White Elephants." The elephant was retired as team mascot in 1963 by then-owner Charles O. Finley in favor of a Missouri mule (it was also rumored to have been done by Finley in order to attract fans from the then heavily Democratic constituents of Missouri by replacing the traditional Republican mascot to one associated with Democrats). In 1988, the elephant was restored as the symbol of the Athletics and currently adorns the left sleeve of home and road uniforms. The Elephant Mascot returned briefly in the mid-'80s, under the name Harry Elephante. In 1997, the elephant returned, taking its current form: Stomper.

James Rudolph Garfield (1865-1950) was a son of the assassinated U. S. President James Abram Garfield. An Ohio lawyer and politician, he was Secretary of the Interior under President Theodore Roosevelt from 1907-09. He was a strong supporter of Roosevelt's (unsuccesful) 1912 bid for a third term as President, on the Progressive Party ticket. In the fall of 1914, when this photo was taken, Garfield was running for Lieutenant Governor of Ohio on the Progressive ticket. Former President Roosevelt, recently returned from a harrowing exploration of the Amazon jungle, apparently was campaigining for him. (Garfield lost the election.) Wikipedia on James Rudolph Garfield: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Rudolph_Garfield Arthur L. Garford, millionaire Ohio industrialist, was born in Elyria, Ohio -- near Cleveland, Garfield's home town. In 1892, Garford patented an improved bicycle saddle: a padded seat for the new "safety" bicycles, with much more comfort that the primitive seats on the old high-wheelers. Soon his company was selling a million bicycle seats a year. In the early 1900s, he partnered with Studebaker to manufacture an automobile, the Studebaker-Garford, but it ceased production in 1911. Garford may have been in this photo because he was bankrolling Garfield's political bid.

October 13, 1914 was the last day of the World Series, won by the Boston Braves in a four-game sweep. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1914_World_Series

This was apparently taken at an earlier time, though, when the Braves were playing at the Polo Grounds in New York. Gowdy was the hero of the Series that year for Boston. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hank_Gowdy

According to www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1914/VNY101914.htm, the last game the Boston Braves played against NY at the Polo Grounds was on 10/3/1914. Perhaps the dates on the negative is when the photographer developed and printed the image.

..or when Bain acquired the picture for its archive? Anyway, I see that the Braves were in New York for a six game homestand just before the end of the season, and that they had already clinched the pennant at that point (they ended up with a 10 1/2 game lead over the second place Giants. It would have been logical for Bain, a New York outfit, to order up photos of the Braves players then. www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1914/Y_1914.htm
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Yes, that was the year of the "Miracle Braves"...

From Wikipedia: The tirailleurs from Algeria subsequently served in the Crimean War, the Second Italian War of Independence, the French intervention in Mexico and the Franco-Prussian War (1870), as well as in various French colonial campaigns in Tunisia, Indochina, Morocco, Madagascar and Algeria itself. During the Crimean War the Algerian tirailleurs acquired the nickname of "Turcos" (Turks) by which they were widely known over the next hundred years. The name reportedly arose from comparisons between the Algerian troops and the Turkish allies serving alongside the French and British forces at the siege of Sebastopol.[2] The Turks (from Turkey) were allies of the Germans in WWI.

From cnparm.home.texas.net/Wars/Marne/MarneBios.htm "Ferdinand Foch (1851-1929) - Commander of XX Corps in Lorraine, Aug.1914; commander of French 9th Army, Aug-Oct.1914. Before the war he was a highly influential instructor and administrator at the École de Guerre who promoted the ‘offensive spirit’ doctrine that would become French military dogma by 1914, but he also more sensibly encouraged flexibility and adaptability. Though he’d never been in combat before, he successfully endured desperate fighting in Lorraine in Aug.1914 and in the Battle of the Marne in Sep. Commanded Army Group North, Jan.1915-Dec.1916. After a brief hiatus, became Chief of Staff to Pétain in May.1917; organized Allied relief to Italy, fall 1917; named Allied Supreme Commander in spring 1918, though with limited powers. Credited as the mastermind behind the successful Allied offensives in the last months of the war. Foch favored a tough settlement with Germany, and predicted a second world war when one was not imposed. Intelligent, resolute, cool, and supremely aggressive. One of the most remarkable personalities of WWI. "

French aviator Eugene Gilbert (b. 1889 - d. 1918) who was the subject of some controversy during the First World War. - First there was the imposter... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0813FC3D5C13738... POSED AS FRENCH AVIATOR - Mme. Gilbert Exposes Impostor - Airmen Escape After Breakdown New York Times September 3, 1914 PARIS, Sept. 2. - Mme. Gilbert, wife of the famous aviator, was recently arrested near Clermont-Ferrand at the Village of Parlay-le-Monial, where she was informed her husband was being feted on his return from a successful raid. On her arrival she found her alleged husband an imposter - a warrant has been issued for his arrest, since the real Gilbert is at Dole - and she was challenged by a gendarme when trying to return home. Finding her without papers and carrying German uniform buttons, which she bought from prisoners as souvenirs, he promptly arrested her. Release was obtained with difficulty on the arrival of her father-in-law with the necessary information. - Then there was his internment in Switzerland... Gilbert engaged in a bombing mission on June 27, 1915, when he dropped five bombs from his aircraft upon the Zeppelin works at Freidrichshafen, Germany on Lake Constance. It was during this raid, however, that his aircraft was struck by anti-aircraft fire. Gilbert was then forced to land his crippled aircraft near Rhinefelden, in neutral Switzerland, where he was interned as a belligerent (See: Flying, Volume 4, August 1915, Page 634, books.google.com/books?id=st1LAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA634&d... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30C11F83C5D17738... RETURN PRISONER TO SWISS; French Order Their Aviator Who Escaped to Give Himself Up. New York Times August 29, 1915 PARIS, Aug. 28. -- Eugene Gilbert, the French aviator who recently escaped from Switzerland after being interned there, returned to Switzerland and gave himself up to night by order of the French Government. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20811F63E5D16738... SWISS THANK FRANCE FOR GILBERT'S RETURN; Say Aviator Who Escaped Had Not Been Released from Terms of Promise. New York Times August 31, 1915 PARIS, Aug. 30. -- Eugene Gilbert, the French aviator whose return to Switzerland after his escape from internment in that country was ordered by the French Government, arrived in Berne yesterday escorted by Captain Dufour of the Swiss Army, according to a Havas News Agency dispatch from Berne. - Although Gilbert was returned to Switzerland for internment, he would once more escape Switzerland and rejoin the French air service later in the war. However, he would soon thereafter perish in a plane crash at Chilacoublay Aerodrome on May 16, 1918. (See: Navy air pilot and military aeronautic review, Volume 4, June 1918, Page 116, books.google.com/books?id=GUNTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA116&l... See also: Eugene Gilbert - Early Aviators earlyaviators.com/egilbert.htm

From cnparm.home.texas.net/Wars/Marne/MarneBios.htm "Joseph Jacques Césaire Joffre (1852-1931) - Commander of the French Army, 1911-1916. Engineering officer with extensive colonial experience; a protégé of Galliéni. Appointed chief of the General Staff over better-known colleagues, 1911; strongly encouraged the offensive doctrine that was in vogue at the time. In Aug.1914, his initial refusal to admit the failure of his opening offensives and to grasp the strength of the German invasion nearly cost France the war at the very outset, but in the crisis of the Long Retreat Joffre’s strengths emerged: he remained imperturbable, kept a tight grip on his armies, and struck back hard when an opportunity appeared. His victory at the Marne was incomplete - the Germans were stopped, but not broken - but it was enough to give the authoritarian Joffre the prestige to assume almost dictatorial powers for a time. His 1915 offensives were bloody failures, the German attack on Verdun in 1916 revealed serious deficiencies, and in Dec.1916, he was effectively removed from power by being kicked upstairs to ceremonial and figurehead roles. Joffre was purposeful, very strong-willed, and profoundly self-confident - but he was also stubborn, autocratic, and imperceptive. In the first weeks of the war, it can be said that he saved France, after putting France in the position of needing to be saved. "

From cnparm.home.texas.net/Wars/Marne/MarneBios.htm "Joseph Galliéni (1849-1916) - Military Governor of Paris, 1914-1915. Long and very distinguished career as a colonial soldier; declined the offer of command of the French Army due to ill health, in favor of Joffre, 1911. Energetically organized Paris’s defenses in the crisis of Aug-Sep 1914 and played a key role in French planning for the First Battle of the Marne. As War Minister, Oct.1915-Mar.1916, he clashed with Joffre but was forced to resign due to illness, dying soon afterwards. Resourceful, dynamic, and acute; one of France’s most able generals. "

Dick Rudolph apparently demonstrating the grip for his renowned curveball. See: bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&pid=12306&am... Dick Rudolph by Dick Leyden Though he stood only 5'9.5" and weighed just 160 lbs., Dick Rudolph was a large component of George Stallings' "Big Three" that helped lead the 1914 Boston Braves to their miraculous pennant and World Series sweep. "He was the bellwether of the pitching staff," said Braves coach Fred Mitchell, "and being a little fellow, I believe his success had much to do with big Bill James and George Tyler putting out that little extra effort to keep pace with the cocky kid from the Bronx." Unlike the hard-throwing James and Tyler, Rudolph was a "pitching cutie" who relied on his great curveball and spectacular control. He also threw a spitball, but "about the best you could say for it was that it was wet," recalled his catcher Hank Gowdy.

Amiens (French pronunciation: [amjɛ̃]) is a city and commune in northern France, 120 km (75 mi) north of Paris and 100 km (62 mi) south-west of Lille. It is the capital of the Somme department in Picardy. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amiens The Battle of Amiens (also known as the Third Battle of Picardy (French: 3ème Bataille de Picardie)), which began on 8 August 1918, was the opening phase of the Allied offensive later known as the Hundred Days Offensive that ultimately led to the end of the First World War. Allied forces advanced over seven miles on the first day, one of the greatest advances of the war, with Henry Rawlinson's British Fourth Army playing the decisive role. The battle is also notable for its effects on both sides' morale and the large number of surrendering German forces. This led Erich Ludendorff to describe the first day of the battle as "the black day of the German Army." Amiens was one of the first major battles involving armoured warfare and marked the end of trench warfare on the Western Front; fighting becoming mobile once again until the armistice was signed on 11 November 1918. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Amiens_(1918)

the very first bombs dropped by plane in WWI, along with leaflets advising the civilian poulace to flee Paris The first bomb to be dropped on Paris in the war fell at exactly 12.45 p.m. The second fell minutes later in the courtyard of 107 quai Valmy, a home for the aged and the third landed on the pavement outside 66 rue des Marais, not far from the Boulevard Magenta. The final explosive crashed through the skylight of 5 and 7 rue des Récollets and failed to explode. All the bombs landed within a few hundred metres of each other in the 10th arrondissement of Paris, the target probably being, despite the observer's stated concern for public safety, the two railway stations which were situated in this district of the capital, and which served, significantly, the north and east of France. www.psywarsoc.org/FallingLeaf/firstwwi.php
Per the falling leaf article, the bombing was on August 30, 1914.

Uhlans (in Polish: "Ułan"; "Ulan" in German) were Polish light cavalry armed with lances, sabres and pistols. The title was later used by lancer regiments in the Russian, Prussian, and Austrian armies. Uhlans typically wore a double-breasted jacket (kurta) with a coloured panel (plastron) at the front, a coloured sash, and a square-topped Polish lancer cap (czapka) also spelt 'chapka,' chapska and schapska. This cap or cavalry helmet was derived from a traditional design of Polish cap, made more formal and stylised for military use. Their lances usually had small, swallow-tailed flags (known as the lance pennon) just below the spearhead. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uhlan On Guelzin I find Le Port Ecluse Guelzin, which leads me to Condé-sur-l'Escaut: Condé-sur-l'Escaut is a commune of the Nord department in northern France. It lies on the border with Belgium. The population in 1999 was 10,527. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Condé-sur-l'Escaut An alternative is Gœulzin: Gœulzin is a commune in the Nord department in northern France. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gœulzin Both are on the Belgian border, so both likely saw action in the early stages of the war.

After looking at tons of photos of the Polo Grounds, there are some identifiable characteristics of the ballpark that enable one to identify the ballpark as the Polo Grounds with a considerable degree of certainty.  Some of those include the fencing and seating along the backstop, the cement dividers of the box seats, the three parallel wood runners that line the backwall of the dugouts, the arrangement of the columns holding up the upper deck, the advertisements along the outfield wall, and, after the fire, the unique facing on the outside of the ballpark's second deck.  

You will also note that a number of the baseball photos in the Bain photostream were taken at the Yankees' former home field at Hilltop Park, and (then new) Ebbets Field.  This is largely due to George Grantham Bain, and the Bain offices themselves, being based in New York City.  Also, in 1914, both the New York Yankees and New York Giants played at the Polo Grounds.  This is another reason why there are photos of American League and National League visiting teams and players at the ballpark.

By October 1914, Germany and Russia were at war. And judging from coverage in NYT, relations had been poor in the Spring of 1914. My suspicion is that this picture was taken earlier, perhaps in May 1913, when Europe's royalty assembled in Berlin for the marriage of the Kaiser's daughter Viktoria Luise. NYT of May 23, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990CEFDE143FE633A... which mentions that the Kaiser took the Czar for a drive in a motor car -- so that wasn't the occasion for this picture.

Interesting article.  The czar and and the king of England both dressed in Prussian military uniforms for the banquet.  Quite a shock in light of later events.
However, one source says this was a custom of royalty of the era, dressing in each other's uniforms.

Some sources I found say the May, 1913 meeting was their last: "On May 24, 1913, Wilhelm's daughter, Viktoria Louise, was married to Prince Ernest August of Hanover, and the Kaiser invited his cousins, King George V of England and Tsar Nicholas II; this would be the last time the Royal cousins saw each other. " www.geocities.ws/kaiser_prussia/biography_wilhelm2_2.html Bain's photo is a heavily-cropped version of this: www.gwpda.org/wwi-www/willnick/pair2.jpg

Ulanen Regiment Wilhelm II, Deutscher Kaiser und König von Preussen. 1.Garde Feld Artillerie Regiment . 1. Garde Regiment zu Fuss. Grenadier Regiment König Friedrich Wilhelm IV (1. IR Kaiser Wilhelm (2. Grossherz. Hessisches) Nr 116 . IR Kaiser Wilhelm, König von Preussen (2. Württembergisches) Nr 120 . Kgl. Bayerisches 6. IR Wilhelm, Deutscher Kaiser und König von Preussen . The British 1st Royal Dragoons 1894-1914 The Austro-Hungarian Husaren Regiment Wilhelm II, Deutscher Kaiser und König von Preussen Nr 7 The Austro-Hungarian Infanterie Regiment Wilhelm I, Deutscher Kaiser und König von Preussen Nr 34.
