Can someone explain the purpose of the two masts? They look vaguely like they might be used for sails, for auxiliary propulsion. But, I'm guessing the more likely explanation is that they are radio antennas.

the highest portion is called the top mast.  It was indeed used for radio transmitting (higher = farther range to send and receive)  When it was clear the German High Seas Fleet would remain in the North Sea only, most British ships struck the top mast. The medium level masts and yard arms were primarily used for signal flags.  In the Battles of Jutland and Dogger Bank, British problems with using and seeing flag signals played an important part in the Germans not being heavily defeated both times.  At Jutland, 4 of the strongest battleships in the world were left 5 miles behind the battle against the German battle cruisers because of the way the flags were handled. In the directly ensuing battle, 2 British battle cruisers were sunk.   At Dogger Bank, a poorly worded signal caused the heavy British ships to all attack already lost Blucher instead of pursuing the other German  sips.

poor Blucher. the epitome of an armored cruiser, she was too far along in construction when the British plans for battle cruisers were discovered. She was too slow to out run them, and too lightly armed/gunned to fight them. The decision to include her in the line meant the end of her at the battle of Dogger Bank. A misunderstood British signal led to her destruction by overwhelming forces while allowing the rest of the German battle cruiser squadron to escape. She fought bravely until the very end, earning the admiration of the British. The loss of Blucher and severe damage to Seydlitz was to have long term consequences for the German fleet because of the Kaiser's reaction. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMS_Bl%C3%BCcher

Interesting photo. Although there is a 1914 date on the glass negative, this appears to be the torpedo boat USS Porter (TB-6). The next USS Porter (DD-59) was a larger ship, a torpedo boat destroyer (or simply, a "destroyer") which had its keel laid down at William Cramp & Sons shipyard in Philadelphia in August 1914. USS Porter was launched in August 1915 and commissioned in April 1916. The construction of the ship in the photo, and its much narrower beam (17-ft for TB-6 vs. 30-ft for DD-59), not to mention the date on the negative, suggests this is a photo of the torpedo boat USS Porter (TB-6). Making things even murkier is the fact that the same photo is described as "Civilian Norfolk Navy Yard workers are busy making repairs on the torpedo boat USS Porter (TB-6) circa 1905," at the NavSource history site. (See: www.navsource.org/archives/05/tb/050306.htm and www.navsource.org/archives/05/tb/05030619.jpg). My guess is that this photo of USS Porter (TB-6) was used in conjunction with the news of the laying of the keel and/or building of the destroyer USS Porter (DD-59) in 1914. It is also possible that NavSource's description of the photo is incorrect, and this is actually a photo of the torpedo-boat USS Porter's dismantling in New York sometime after it was decommissioned (November 1912) and sold (30 December 1912) to Andrew Olson of New York (see: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Porter_(TB-6)#Decommissioning_a....

This can't be DD-59, it's too small. Has to be TB-6. The building marked "Beard's" could be a clue but I can't find anything. There's a Beard's Wharf in London but that isn't it. I found a few photos of the Norfolk yard from that era and this could be it, but it could be just about any place else too.

NYT of September 19, 1914 reports that Elaine V Rosenthal, an 18-yr old from Chicago, had reached the final of the US Women's Golf Championship query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F5071FFA3F5C1A728... See chicagolandgolf.com/illinoiswomensopen/elainerosenthal.html which suggests she lost in the final. www.corbisimages.com/stock-photo/rights-managed/U19300INP... is another picture taken on the same day.

Looks like there is no Helene V. Rosenthal. ElaineV. Rosenthal, a top woman golfer of the era, won the Women's Western Golf Championship on 8/27/15 (the day after the date on the picture), at the age of 19. books.google.com/books?id=aOTWUl-9LQoC&pg=PA240&l... Held at Midlothian Country Club, Midlothian, IL midlothiancc.org/history/tournaments.html There is a short biographical account in "Sports in Chicago", Elliott J. Gorn, ed., which recaps her career and discusses the issue of her being a Jewish female athlete in that era. books.google.com/books?id=iY6BK0FZS-EC&printsec=front... pp. 69-70

The picture at Corbis is identified as taken on September 18, 1914.  She is wearing the same outfit as here, but that hardly makes it a certainty that the two pictures were taken on the same day.   But I do wonder whether the photo is from 1914 (in sync with the other photos in the current batches) and Bain dug it out and used it in 1915 when she won her first tournament.  Hard to tell.
Not impossible.  I don't know if there was a convention at Bain about what date to scratch onto the glass negative.
Elaine Virginia Rosenthal. Here is her marriage in Chicago. [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton/15629936144/]

Her page at the Illinois Golf Hall of Fame site: www.illinoisgolfhof.org/members/member.aspx?id=ecd8f136-4... She has no Wikipedia entry, but is mentioned in the entry on the Illinois Women's Open: "Each year's champion has her name added to the Elaine Rosenthal Memorial Trophy, which honors one of Chicago and the nation's early women's golf pioneers. Ms. Rosenthal played in many championships in the late 1910s through the mid-1930s, representing the Chicago area and playing out of Ravisloe Country Club in Homewood, Illinois. She volunteered her services as part of "The Dixie Kids" a foursome of talented teenage golfers who barnstormed the United States in 1917–18 playing exhibition matches. Those charity matches marked the first time in the history of golf that spectators paid for tickets to watch a golf event. In this case, the money raised went to the American Red Cross to buy medical supplies for use on the battlefields of Europe. Equally remarkable are the identities of the four teens: Elaine Rosenthal and Alexa Stirling were the women; Perry Adair and Bobby Jones were the men." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois_Women%27s_Open
Thanks for all the details, we'll revise the record.

Here is the Tribune's account of the funeral pictured in this and succeeding Bain pictures, noting that Sullivan founded the Public Schools Athletic League and that 28 of the city's most prominent men served as pallbearers: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1914-09-20/ed-...

James Edward Sullivan (November 18, 1862 – September 16, 1914) was an Irish American sports official. He was one of the founders of the Amateur Athletic Union (AAU) in 1888, serving as its secretary from 1889 until 1906 when he was elected as president from 1906 to 1909. He declined a fourth term and was re-elected to his former position as secretary-treasurer until his sudden death which followed an emergency operation. Sullivan also served as the chairman of the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association in 1903 and on the New York City Board of Education from 1908 to 1912. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Edward_Sullivan Between fifty and sixty thousand boys, members of the Public Schools Athletic League, an organization originated and fostered by the late James E. Sullivan, will line the route to be taken by the funeral procession when the athletic leader's body is conveyed from his home, 540 West 114th Street, tomorrow morning to the Catholic Church of St. Aloyslus, 132d Street and Seventh Avenue, where a solemn high mass of requiem will be celebrated. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F0081EFA3D5C1373... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Aloysius_Gonzaga%27s_Church_(Ne... That's "Cucaracha." From the wikipedia article about the Gaillard (Culebra) Cut: "The first and largest major slide occurred in 1907 at Cucaracha. The initial crack was first noted on October 4, 1907, followed by the mass wasting of about 382,000 m³ (500,000 cubic yards) of clay. This slide caused many people to suggest the construction of the Panama Canal would be impossible; Gaillard described the slides as tropical glaciers, made of mud instead of ice. The clay was too soft to be excavated by the steam shovels, and it was therefore largely removed by sluicing it with water from a high level."

This appears to be a throng of well wishers from New York City's large Italian-American population, along with members of the press, awaiting the arrival of Ernesto Nathan (1848-1921), the former mayor of Rome (1907-1914), who arrived in New York aboard the Italian steamer Stampalia of the La Veloce Line, on May 25, 1914. There were so many delegates on hand from leading Masonic organizations in New York State, and from the Italian Societies in New York City to greet Signor Nathan's arrival that when the ship came alongside the pier at the foot of West Thirty Fourth Street, the wooden gangplank bridge creaked uncomfortably, and officials ordered the large crowd back to the area shown in the above photograph to prevent an accident. Signor Nathan was appointed by King Victor Emmanuel to be Royal Italian Commissioner representing Italy to the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition in San Francisco, and honorary Minister Plenipotentiary. Nathan departed New York City on the afternoon train to Washington, DC, where he met with President Wilson the following day, before traveling on to San Francisco. [1] [2] [3]
Thank you so much, pixel wrangler, for providing so many links related to Ernesto Nathan's visit to the U.S.  We'll add some of that information to the record the next time we update.

Nathan was arriving to supervise the construction of Italy's exhibit to the fair. The following year, he came for the opening of the fair, arriving in New York on the ocean liner America from Italy. The Bain collection has 2 photos from that arrival, too: Nathan was a controversial figure. Born in England of Jewish parents, he went on to be mayor of Rome for 6 years. His appointment to head Italy's representation in the Pan-American Exposition brought on a boycott of the fair by a number of U.S. Catholic organizations, who denounced him as anti-Catholic. In his defense, he said he opposed the Catholic political party in Italy, not the religion or its adherents.
LOC, no need to use all caps for Nathan in the caption.

Pixel Wrangler, Excellent research! Thanks for bringing so much more context to this very minimally captioned image. As you concluded, this is certainly the Harlem River Speedway, also referred to as the Harlem Speedway, and even just The Speedway. Most of our other views of the Speedway are not from right on the track like this one, so it's quite a shot! Comparing this photo to a circa 1905 photo of the Speedway gives us a chance to match details, especially when looking at the largest digital TIFF files of each image. (Go here for a link to the TIFF file for this image.) Amongst other details which match - like the fixtures along the speedway, the signs and buildings on the opposite shoreline - the most compelling is the distant view in both images of the domed library of the old uptown campus of New York University, designed by Stanford White and built in 1899. (See a 1904 photo of the library from our collections.) It is now part of Bronx Community College. (For more on the history of this building, read Christopher Gray's 1996 New York Times article.) Between the articles you cite about Denver's track exploits and the script caption up the side of the photograph reading 'Denver coming along Speedway', we can certainly confirm that Denver refers to the horse and that this is the Speedway. We will expand the caption for this photograph when we update. Thanks again!

Very interesting and detailed article, thanks. The church, attended by the Rockefellers, was replaced by a newer building in 1930, and was on West 57th Street, near Carnegie Hall. White's action (with 20 of his followers) at the church was in response to the Ludlow Massacre in Colorado, which had taken place on April 20th. A more sympathetic account of White's actions that day (for which he served 6 months in jail) is told here: www.archive.org/stream/fromprisoletters00whitrich/frompri... When supporters petitioned Governor Glynn for his pardon, he wrote the governor to assure him that he was not sorry for his actions: "" Repentant ! " I am, sir, the most unrepentant pris- oner a New York City jail ever sloughed into a cell. Let another Ludlow massacre happen, I would repeat my deed to-morrow. So far from life in prison having wrought in me a penitential work, it has tightened and reenforced in me a remonstrant mood."

Clarence Hungerford Mackay (1874-1938), American financier; his wikipedia entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clarence_Mackay The children are John William Mackay, Ellin Mackay, and Katherine Mackay: Ellin Mackay (1903-1988) married Irving Berlin in 1926; Clarence disapproved, and he threatened disinheritance. Ellin Berlin became a novelist: www.nytimes.com/1988/07/30/obituaries/ellin-berlin-85-a-n... Her papers are at the University of Nevada Reno: knowledgecenter.unr.edu/specoll/mss/90-87.html John William Mackay married Josephine Gwendolyn Rose in 1929. Katherine Mackay married twice, to judge Kenneth O'Brien (divorced in 1937), and to lawyer Robert Ziemer Hawkins (1903-1979) in 1939; she lived in Reno, Nevada. Her papers are at UC Berkeley: www.oac.cdlib.org/search?style=oac4;titlesAZ=k;idT=UCb112...

Photo taken likely on the return to the United States of the Chicago White Sox and New York Giants upon the Cunard Liner RMS Lusitania in March 1914, after concluding a five-month long Around The World tour promoting baseball. "Mrs. Comiskey" being Nan Comiskey, wife of White Sox owner Charles Comiskey, and "Mrs. McGraw," Blanche McGraw, the wife of Giants manager John McGraw. GIANTS HOME TO-DAY FROM WORLD'S TOUR; Lusitania Will Bring Baseball Party Up the Bay This Morning. New York Times March 6, 1914 The Cunard Line officials announced at midnight that the Lusitania would reach Ambrose Lightship about 2 o'clock this morning, and if there was no fog would continue to Quarantine, reaching there at 3 o'clock. The liner will dock at 8:30 this morning at Pier 56 at the foot of Fourteenth Street. See also: SOX AND GIANTS ON WORLD'S TOUR; Comiskey-McGraw Party Leaves Chicago Oct. 19 and Arrives in New York March 6. New York Times July 27, 1913 Preliminary plans for the world's baseball tour of the New York Giants and the Chicago White Sox have been completed, and now that the National League pennant is practically in the hands of the New York club, Manager McGraw has already started to pick his players.

Misspelled: Canadian Forces Base Valcartier is a Canadian Forces Base located in the municipality of Saint-Gabriel-de-Valcartier, approximately 25 km (16 mi) north of Quebec City. It is home to the 5th Canadian Mechanized Brigade Group. CFB Valcartier was originally erected as a military training camp in August 1914 as part of the mobilization of the Canadian Expeditionary Force at the onset of World War I. The site was also used as an internment camp for "enemy aliens", mainly eastern Europeans. The name Valcartier comes from the town of Saint-Gabriel-de-Valcartier, of which a large section was expropriated in order to create the military training camp. Due to its proximity to the Port of Quebec, Valcartier became the largest military camp on Canadian soil, including some 32,000 men and 8,000 horses. John Franklin "Home Run" Baker (March 13, 1886 – June 28, 1963) was an American third baseman in Major League Baseball from 1908 to 1922, and was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1955. As a member of the famed $100,000 infield, Baker helped the Philadelphia Athletics win the 1910, 1911 and 1913 World Series. His legacy has grown over the years, and he is regarded by many as the best third baseman of the pre-war era.

[edit]Professional career

[edit]Philadelphia Athletics


Home Run Baker
He was born in Trappe, Maryland, was a butcher by trade, and broke into the major leagues in 1908 with the Athletics.
Baker, who led the American League in home runs in 1911, earned the nickname "Home Run" during the 1911 World Series in which he hit a go-ahead home run off Rube Marquard in Game 2, and a ninth-inning game-tying home run off Christy Mathewson in Game 3. His home run crown would be the first of four consecutive seasons leading the American League in home runs. He hit 11 home runs in 1911, 10 home runs in 1912, 12 home runs in 1913, and nine home runs in 1914. In two of those seasons he also led the American League in runs batted in.
In seven seasons with the A's he hit .321 with 48 home runs, 612 RBIs and 88 triples in 866 games played.
Baker played third base for the Athletics until 1915, when he sat out the entire season in a contract dispute with Connie Mack. He remained in baseball, playing for Upland, Pennsylvania in the semiprofessional Delaware County League.[1]
[edit]New York Yankees
Mack sold Baker's contract in 1916 to the New York Yankees, with whom he finished his career. He led the league in games played with 141 games in 1919
Initially, Baker retired in 1920, but came back to play two more seasons with the Yankees, seasons that took him to two more World Series. He finished his tenure with the Yankees with a .288 batting average, 46 home runs and 375 RBIs in 676 games.
[edit]Managerial career
Following his retirement, Baker managed for two seasons (1924-1925) in the Eastern Shore Baseball League, and was credited with discovering Jimmie Foxx and recommending him to Athletics manager Connie Mack.
[edit]Legacy
In addition to his 1955 election to the Baseball Hall of Fame, in 1981 Lawrence Ritter and Donald Honig included him in their book The 100 Greatest Baseball Players of All Time.
Home Run Baker was laid to rest in Easton, Maryland.
There is a statue of Home Run Baker in the southwest area of UMass-Amherst. It was erected by a University of Massachusetts student.

Likely Clarence Kraft, with a "K," a minor league ballplayer, whose major league "rights" were owned by the Brooklyn Dodgers. After Kraft briefly played in the major leagues early in 1914, Charles Ebbets and the team sought to send Kraft to the Newark Indians AA league team. However, Kraft's minor league rights were claimed by the Nashville Volunteers A league team. The dispute concerning where Kraft should play would almost lead to a player's strike. The matter was eventually resolved when Ebbets paid the Nashville A team $2,500 compensation to rescind their claim, and Kraft's designation to Newark was approved. For more details, see: Baseball: The Golden Age, by Harold Seymour, Oxford University Press, 1971 (Pages 228-229)

There was never an Empress of Germany. The title is German Empress and Queen of Prussia. The Kaiser is German Emperor and King of Prussia. These titles were scrupulously observed in Germany and elsewhere, e.g., by Queen Victoria when the pair stayed at Windsor. The title underlines a major political point. The Kaiser was first among equals, there being four royal houses in the German empire - Prussia, Bavaria, Saxony and Wurttemmberg. Hence - German Emperor and not Emperor of Germany. If this is hard to grasp then imagine a King of England, a King of Scotland, a King of Wales, and a King of Ireland. The King of England is the British Emperor, being first amongst equals. Bismarck instituted this arrangement, much to the annoyance of Kaiser Wilhelm's grandfather who wanted to be called Emperor of Germany.

It brings back good memories.
As a boy growing up in London during WW2 - particularly towards the end and soon after - I remember the presence, the warm and friendly presence, of so many American service personnel.  Their smart uniforms (as here), their easy manner, their openness, that contrasted greatly with a tired and weary Britain, where bomb sites were our rough adventure playgrounds. In this colourless world of shortage, utility products, clothes coupons, food and sweets rationing, we were fascinated by these young people who appeared in our midst, from a land so exotic - to us - as the USA.
I see all this captured in this photograph.

This must be a photograph of a photograph. There is a large nail at the top edge, center, and a transparent plastic push-pin at the bottom edge, center. The shanks of other nails are visible in three corners (top L and R; bottom L) and there are many other holes along the bottom and top edges.
Well, of course: it's a scan or image from a print. As in the notes, it was a glass negative and my understanding is that those were often reused by scraping off the exposed substance.
To clarify: it's not a scan of a print made directly from a negative. There was an extra step, in which someone photographed the mounted print. Otherwise, we wouldn't see the fasteners.

Igor himself spelled his name as Sikorsky lccn.loc.gov/mm82040014. I believe the Russian Knight is the first multi-engine, fixed wing aircraft, and a later version became the first 4 engine aircraft. Sikorsky immigrated to the U.S. in 1919, developed the first practical helicopter in 1939, and later designs of the Sikorsky Aircraft Company were chosen to serve the U.S. President. These include the VH-3D seen here with Rosalynn Carter www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2005696417/ Several of these shiny, dark green and white VH-3Ds are still operated by the Marine Corps as official helicopters of the President, and can frequently be seen flying around Washington D.C.
Thank you for the information, very interesting.
Thanks, L, we'll touch up the record.

Sikorsky built this aircraft during the winter of 1912-13. He named it "Russkiy vityaz" (Russian Knight) but it soon became known as the "Grand" or "Le Grand." A giant machine at the time, it had a wingspan of 88 ft. 7 in. and a length of 65 ft. 7 in. The fuselage was covered with plywood for greater rigidity. Initially the airplane had two 100-horsepower Argus engines, but two more were added for the first historic flight near St. Petersburg on May 26, 1913. 

(Source: D. Cochrane et al. "The Aviation Careers of Igor Sikorsky." Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1989.)

The image above shows a half-tone print of the original. It is usually dated February 1913.

Robert Edgar "Ed" Willett

Birth: Mar. 7, 1884, Norfolk, Virginia, USA
Death: May 10, 1934 Wellington, Kansas, USA


Major League Baseball Player. He was a right-handed pitcher who spent 10 seasons in the majors, mostly with the Detroit Tigers. Purchased by the Tigers from the Wichita Jobbers of the Western Association in August of 1906, he made his major league debut in September of that season in a 2-0 complete game loss to the White Sox at Bennett Park in Detroit. He appeared in just 13 games his first two seasons, pitching to a 1-8 record during that time. 1908 would be his breakout season, as he pitched to a 15-8 record and 2.28 ERA. He did all of this despite an ankle injury that threatened to curtail his season. Exceptionally strong and powerfully built, Detroit manager Hughie Jennings once remarked, "Ed is always out there keeping the boys steady. He takes the ball whenever he's told and never seems to tire." His best season was 1909 when he had a 21-10 record with a 2.34 ERA. A fellow southerner like his teammate Ty Cobb, Willett nonetheless chose to socialize with teammates such as George Mullin, Ed Killian and Matty McIntyre, who were part of an anti-Cobb faction on the club. Pitching out of the bullpen, he appeared in 2 games during the 1909 World Series, allowing 3 hits and 1 unearned run in 7.2 innings of work. After 8 seasons and 96 wins in a Detroit uniform, he jumped his contract and signed with the newly formed Federal League's St. Louis Terriers. Unlike many players who's stats improved by moving to the new league, Willett digressed. He would go a combined 6-19 during his two year stay in St. Louis. Given his release in September of 1915, he would go on to pitch in the minors for 4 more seasons, making stops with Memphis and New Orleans of the Southern Association and Salt Lake City of the PCL. After his retirement, he worked as a carpenter and continued to coach amateur baseball teams. He died from a raptured aortic aneurysm at the age of 50. Over the course of his career, he accrued a 102-99 record with a 3.04 ERA and 5 saves in 274 games. (bio by: Frank Russo)

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ward_Miller_%28baseball%29 Ward Taylor Miller (July 4, 1884 in Mount Carroll, Illinois - September 4, 1958 in Dixon, Illinois), was a professional baseball player who played outfielder in the Major Leagues from 1909-1917. He played for the Pittsburgh Pirates, Chicago Cubs, Cincinnati Reds, St. Louis Terriers, and St. Louis Browns.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delos_Drake Delos Daniel Drake (December 3, 1886 - October 3, 1965) was a Major League Baseball player who played 83 games in the Detroit Tigers outfield in 1911 beside Ty Cobb and also played in the Federal League in 1914 and 1915 for the St. Louis Terriers.

Hugh Stanley "Hughie" Miller (December 22, 1886 to December 24, 1945) was a Major League Baseball player. Miller played for the Philadelphia Phillies in 1911 and the St. Louis Terriers of the Federal League in 1914 and 1915. He batted and threw right-handed.

He was born in St. Louis, Missouri and died in Jefferson Barracks, Missouri.

HMS Achilles was a Duke of Edinburgh-class armoured cruiser built for the Royal Navy in the mid-1900s. She served with the 2nd Cruiser Squdron for most of the First World War. Achilles did not participate in the Battle of Jutland in 1916, but did sink the German raider Leopard in 1917. Achilles became a training ship in 1918 and was sold for scrap in 1921.

as an armoured cruiser, she and her ilk were quickly rendered obsolete by the battle cruiser.  Although the British armoured cruisers largely avoided their fate, the German East Asia Squadron's cruisers were destroyed within the first few months of the war by British battle cruisers.

USS Powhatan (ID # 3013), 1917-1919. Originally S.S. Hamburg (German Passenger Liner, 1899). Later named Red Cross, Hudson and President Fillmore USS Powhatan, a 18,026-ton troop transport, was originally the German passenger steamer Hamburg, which had been built in 1899 at Stettin, Germany. Caught at New York when World War I began in August 1914, she was soon chartered by the American Red Cross to take medical personnel and supplies to Europe. Renamed Red Cross, she left New York in mid-September and called at Falmouth, England; Paulliac, France; and Rotterdam, The Netherlands, before recrossing the Atlantic in October with American refugees on board. She remained at New York for the next two and a half years. Also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Powhatan_(ID-3013) On the "Red Cross": [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6011905580/in/photostream] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6011905410/in/photostream/]

Freddie Welsh (5 March 1886 – 29 July 1927) was a Welsh lightweight boxing champion. Born in Pontypridd, Wales, and christened Frederick Hall Thomas, he was nicknamed the "Welsh Wizard". Brought up in a tough mining community, Welsh left a middle-class background to make a name for himself in America. He turned professional as a boxer in Philadelphia in 1905, and spent the best part of his career fighting in the United States, leaving many in Britain to incorrectly believe he was an exponent of an ungentlemanly style of American boxing. Olsztyn [ˈɔlʂtɨn] (German: Allenstein; Old Polish: Holstin; Old Prussian: Alnāsteini; Lithuanian: Olštynas) is a city in northeastern Poland, on the Łyna River. Olsztyn has been the capital of the Warmian-Masurian Voivodeship since 1999. It was previously in the Olsztyn Voivodeship (and in other units in 1945–75 and 1975–98). The city has county status. Shortly after the outbreak of World War I, troops of the Russian Empire captured Allenstein in 1914, but it was recovered by the Imperial German Army in the Battle of Tannenberg.

Lille (French pronunciation: [lil]; Dutch: Rijsel) is a city in northern France (French Flanders). It is the principal city of the Lille Métropole, the fourth-largest metropolitan area in the country behind those of Paris, Lyon and Marseille. Lille is situated on the Deûle River, near France's border with Belgium. It is the capital of the Nord-Pas de Calais region and the prefecture of the Nord department. Between 4–13 October 1914, the troops in Lille were able to trick the enemy by convincing them that Lille possessed more artillery than was the case; in reality, the city had only a single cannon. Despite the deception, the German bombardments destroyed over 2,200 buildings and homes. When the Germans realised they had been tricked, they burned down an entire section of town, subsequently occupying the city. Lille was liberated by the British on 17 October 1918, when General Sir William Birdwood and his troops were welcomed by joyous crowds. The general was made an honorary citizen of the city of Lille on 28 October of that year.

Pope Benedict XV (Latin: Benedictus PP. XV, Italian: Benedetto XV; 21 November 1854 – 22 January 1922), born Giacomo Paolo Giovanni Battista della Chiesa, reigned as Pope from 3 September 1914 to 22 January 1922. His pontificate was largely overshadowed by World War I and its political, social and humanitarian consequences in Europe. Between 1846 and 1903, the Church experienced its two longest pontificates in history, up to that point. Together Pius IX and Leo XIII ruled for 57 years. In 1914, the Cardinals choose Della Chiesa at the age of 59, indicating their desire for another long-lasting pontificate at the outbreak of World War I, which he labeled “the suicide of civilized Europe.” The war and its consequences were the main focus of Benedict. He declared the neutrality of the Holy See and attempted from that perspective to mediate peace in 1916 and 1917. Both sides rejected his initiatives. German Protestants rejected any “Papal Peace” as insulting. French politician Georges Clemenceau regarded the Vatican initiative as anti-French. [The current] Pope Benedict XVI showed his own admiration for Benedict XV following his election to the Papacy on 19 April 2005.

Miraflores is the name of one of the three locks that form part of the Panama Canal and the name of the small lake that separates these locks from the Pedro Miguel locks upstream. In the Miraflores locks, vessels are lifted (or lowered) in three stages totalling 8 m, allowing them to transit to or from the Pacific Ocean port of Balboa (near Panama City). Ships cross below the Puente de las Américas (Bridge of the Americas) which connects North and South America. Newsworthy because the Panama Canal was opened on 15 August 1914. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6011348077/in/photostream/]

Gatun Lake (Sp. Lago Gatún) is a large artificial lake situated in the Republic of Panama; it forms a major part of the Panama Canal, carrying ships for 33 km (20 miles) of their transit across the Isthmus of Panama. Newsworthy because the Panama Canal was opened on 15 August 1914.

SS Ancon was an American steamship that became the first ship to officially transit the Panama Canal in 1914. Ancon and her sister ship Cristobal played a crucial role in building the canal, bringing workers and supplies, notably massive amounts of cement, from New York to Panama for the construction project The steamer began life as the SS Shawmut, built for the Boston Steamship Line in 1902.[1] About 1910 she was purchased by the Panama Railroad Company to provide shipping required for the construction of the Panama Canal. The name was changed to Ancon after Ancon Hill and Ancon township in Panama, home to the head of the Canal Commission. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Ancon

another Bain Collection photo of the general: Some background: "Unlike the Germans, the French could not agree on the best plans for war. In the years before the war, prominent generals had argued over how to prepare for a war with Germany. One-time commander in chief General Victor Michel guessed that the German attack would come through Belgium and proposed that the first French action should be to cut off the Germans in Belgium before they could reach French territory. Michel's plan, which was unpopular with political leaders but turned out to be absolutely correct, cost him his job. His replacement, General Joseph Joffre (1852–1931), called instead for a direct attack on German positions in the formerly French territories of Alsace-Lorraine. (He called for a smaller force to monitor German activities in Belgium.) Joffre's plan was adopted by his country, and it left France highly vulnerable to the German Schlieffen plan. Joffre also underestimated the number of German troops the French armies would face and overestimated the impact that Russian battles would have on the conflict. Joffre's faulty vision of how the war would unfold cost the French dearly in the early stages of the conflict." find.galegroup.com/gic/infomark.do?contentSet=EBKS&do...

poor Alsace, torn between France and Germany between 1870 and WWII. In various periods, Germans and French each oppressed the other. It declared independence for 11 days after the Armistice only to be occupied by French troops yet again and went through a period of Frankification and expulsion of Germans. Like Quebec, some regions had comfortably had signs in both French and German before WWI and people generally got along. It still has some legal differences distinct from the rest of France. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alsace-Lorraine#During_World_War_I

At the time, there were two William Kissam Vanderbilts. The father was born in 1849 and died in 1920. At the time of WWI he was married to his second wife, the former Miss Anne Harriman, who had previously been widowed twice. The son, by WKV's first wife, was born in 1878 and died in 1944. He married Virginia Graham Fair in 1899; they separated after ten years and were divorced in 1927. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Kissam_Vanderbilt en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Kissam_Vanderbilt_II

Following the Anne Harriman track, I find www.faubourgmontmartre.com/grannyww1.html which confirms that the older Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt (and her husband) were active in war relief for the French, and in hospital work in particular. I find plenty of evidence that she worked in the American Ambulance Hospital in Neuilly (which was established in a large school building), but so far nothing to indicate that she turned her home into a hospital. There is no indication that the younger Mrs. Vanderbilt ( en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_Fair_Vanderbilt ) was involved in the same sort of activities, although she did have Paris connections.

The caption written on the photo indicates that it was taken in Paris.  Looking at the high-res TIFF, I think I see the strip across the near lower window reading AMBULANCE ?? VANDERBILT -- although I'm more certain about the first word.
NYT of Nov 10, 1907 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10C17F93B5A15738... does indicate that she funded, built, and furnished a hospital near Place Victor Hugo. Perhaps this is that one.

Popular US anti-war song of the time "I Didn't Raise My Boy to Be a Soldier". (Of course a few years later the tide of public opinion turned, with the sinking of the Lusitania being a major turning point.)

Ten million soldiers to the war have gone,
Who may never return again.
Ten million mother's hearts must break
For the ones who died in vain.
Head bowed down in sorrow
In her lonely years,
I heard a mother murmur thru' her tears:

I didn't raise my boy to be a soldier,
I brought him up to be my pride and joy.
Who dares to place a musket on his shoulder,
To shoot some other mother's darling boy?
Let nations arbitrate their future troubles,
It's time to lay the sword and gun away.
There'd be no war today,
If mothers all would say,
"I didn't raise my boy to be a soldier."

What victory can cheer a mother's heart,
When she looks at her blighted home?
What victory can bring her back
All she cared to call her own?
Let each mother answer
In the years to be,
Remember that my boy belongs to me!

I didn't raise my boy to be a soldier
To go fighting in some far-off foreign land.
He may get killed before he's any older
For a cause he'll never understand.
Why should he fight in some rich man's battle
While they stay home and while their time away?
Let those with most to lose
Fight each other if they choose;
For I didn't raise my boy to be a soldier!

Andrew Hamilton Gault (18 August 1882 – 28 November 1958) was the founder of the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry and a Conservative Party politician in the United Kingdom. He was born in England, of Canadian parents. Gault attended McGill University. Commissioned in the 2nd Canadian Mounted Rifles, he served in the Second Boer War and joined the Canadian Militia on return to Canada. On the eve of the First World War he offered the Canadian government $100 000 to help raise and equip an infantry battalion for overseas duty, leading to the formation in 1914 of the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry. Gault accompanied the regiment overseas as second-in-command, fighting until the loss of his left leg. On retirement in 1920, he was elected as Member of Parliament (MP) for Taunton at the 1924 general election, and held the seat through two further elections until he retired from the House of Commons at the 1935 general election. Recalled to active duty in the Second World War, he served on staff with the Canadian Army in England (colonel, 1940; brigadier, 1942) and returned to Canada in 1945. Appointed honorary colonel (1948) and colonel (1958) of his regiment, he showed a keen interest in it until his death in 1958.

In 1966, I visited a Gault House that belonged to McGill University, a beautiful house on a lake on Mont Saint Hilaire, an estate that had been given to the university as a nature reserve. Reading the bio that trialsanderrors provided, I couldn't resist seeing if the association might be with this Gault, and it is. From www.mcgill.ca/gault/sainthilaire/human/ "In 1913, the Campbell family sold 890 hectares of its mountain property to a wealthy young man, Andrew Hamilton Gault. By 1920, the 522 inhabitants of the town of Mont-Saint-Hilaire had electricity, a luxury not enjoyed by the 802 rural members of the parish. The population of the vicinity grew steadily, with about 5,000 people drawing water from Lac Hertel in 1941 when an aqueduct from the lake was constructed. Gault enjoyed many wonderful days on his mountain property as development continued in the region through the early part of the 20th century. He loved the wild nature of the mountain and became committed to preserving its special character. Others were not so respectful. Prospectors searched for uranium and diamonds, posing a threat of expropriation, and others exploited mineral deposits on the flanks of the mountain. Gault remained vigilant and firm in his commitments to protect the mountain during this period, agreeing only to provide water from Lac Hertel to the city of Beloeil beginning in 1940. In 1957, Gault began construction of a manor house on the shore of Lac Hertel to which he planned to retire, but he died before its completion. He had left his property to McGill University in the hope that this well-established institution of higher learning could continue his efforts to protect the mountain for future generations. " www.mcgill.ca/gault/ describes how the estate is used now as a resource for research and public access.

In The Story of My Life, Hank Greenberg wrote of Moriarty: Much later in my career George Moriarty and I became very good friends. Back in the early 1900s he played third base for Detroit, and he used to steal home. Somebody wrote a poem about him, and the title was “Never Die on Third Moriarty.” All through the rest of his life George felt he knew something about stealing home. When he was umpiring on third base, and on occasion when I’d get on third, he coached me on how to take a lead so I could steal home. I never had the guts enough to try, because I didn’t think I could make it. I’d run down the line, and he’d keep insisting that I take a bigger lead. I was always afraid that I was going to get picked off. But it was interesting to see Moriarty, who was umpiring at third base, coaching me on how to steal home for the Tigers. It became a joke among the players, but I never got up the nerve to try it. www.baseballlibrary.com/excerpts/excerpt.php?book=hank_gr...

George Moriarty (1884-1964) would not only play Major League Baseball for 13 years (1903-1916), he also continue in the game as a manager, an umpire, and then a scout. His grandson is actor Michael Moriarty (1941- ). See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Moriarty

Dinant is a Walloon city and municipality located on the River Meuse in the Belgian province of Namur, Belgium. [...] The city suffered devastation again at the beginning of the First World War. On 23 August, 674 inhabitants were summarily executed by Saxon troops of the German Army — the biggest massacre committed by the Germans in 1914. Within a month, some five thousand Belgian and French civilians were killed by the Germans at numerous similar occasions. Among the wounded was Lieut. Charles de Gaulle. Qingdao (simplified Chinese: 青岛; pinyin: Qīngdǎo; Mandarin pronunciation: [tɕʰíŋtɑ̀ʊ̯]) also known in the West by its postal map spelling Tsingtao, is a major city with a population of over 7.5 million (2009) in eastern Shandong province, Eastern China. It borders Yantai to the northeast, Weifang to the west and Rizhao to the southwest. The character 青 (qīng) in Chinese means "green" or "lush", while the character 岛 (dǎo) means "island". Qingdao is administered at the sub-provincial level. After a minor British naval attack on the German colony in 1914, Japan occupied the city and the surrounding province during the Siege of Tsingtao after Japan's declaration of war on Germany in accordance with the Anglo-Japanese Alliance. The failure of the Allied powers to restore Chinese rule to Shandong after the war triggered the May Fourth Movement.

Toronto is misspelled. The 48th Highlanders of Canada is a Canadian Forces Primary Reserve (i.e., part-time militia) infantry regiment based in Toronto, parading out of Moss Park Armoury. The regiment is part of Land Force Central Area's 32 Canadian Brigade Group. 12th Infantry likely refers to ... The Sherbrooke Regiment (or Sherbrooke Hussars) was initially formed in 1866 as the Sherbrooke Battalion of Infantry, becoming the 53rd (Sherbrooke) Battalion in 1867. The regiment provided volunteers for the 12th Battalion, Canadian Expeditionary Force in 1914. Today's Royal Regiment of Canada (...) evolved from the 10th Royal Grenadiers and thus inherited British traditions.

On the placards: "Groupe des chanteurs des rues" Le chanteur de rue est une personne (homme ou femme) qui chante sur la voie publique dans l'espoir de recueillir quelque argent de la part de ses auditeurs. Le principe est de captiver le maximum d'auditoire en un temps très court. Pour ce faire, le chanteur s'appuie sur une musique mélodieuse et/ou un texte accrocheur. Très populaires avant l'invention des média modernes (radio, télévision, enregistrement sonore), ils ont largement contribué à la diffusion d'idées ou d'informations au même titre que les journaux. En effet, en dehors de quelques grands standards de la musique populaire, leur répertoire s'inspirait souvent de faits majeurs ou de faits divers remarquables, assurant une publicité à ces évènements.

The presence of a flag of known colors clearly visible in the image gives us a rare opportunity to reasonably determine what filter was used over the camera's lens. Assuming that the color pattern is correctly oriented towards us, the stripes would be blue-white-red. From the relative shades of these colors on the flag, and based on my limited filter experience, it seems reasonable this photo was taken with a green filter, which is normally reserved for portraits. 

But please correct me if I'm wrong!

Interesting idea! I see two problems: 1. the flag might be hoisted on the wrong (red) side – even though the bearer looks like a gendarme, so he should know what he is doing, and 2. the colors might not be standardized as today, in particular the blue might be lighter. I did a little crude test with digital filters off today's standardized tricolore, and in all cases the blue came out darker than the red.
Just sayin' -- the caption says "Vera Cruz" instead of "Arkansas."

The Princess Mary, Princess Royal and Countess of Harewood (Victoria Alexandra Alice Mary; 25 April 1897 – 28 March 1965) was a member of the British Royal Family; she was the third child and only daughter of King George V and Queen Mary. She was the sixth holder of the title of Princess Royal. Mary held the title of princess with the style Highness from birth as the then great-granddaughter of the British Sovereign, and later Her Royal Highness, as the granddaughter and finally daughter of the Sovereign. After her marriage she held the title of Countess of Harewood. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3575397291/]

what a wonderful ship shot.  She was Germany's first battle cruiser, and first turbine powered capital ship, Unlike Britain's battle cruisers, Germany's were required to be able to fight in the "line" with battleships.  her hull and machinery comprised 47.4% of her weight, vs 57.3% for  HMS Indefatigable, 30% for armor vs 20, and each used about 13.75 for armament.  Consequently, the German battle cruisers took enormous amount of punishment in the WWI battles without sinking.  On her trials she achieved a speed of 28.124 knots, making her the fastest dreadnought in the world.  In the battle of Jutland, she fired 52 large shells at Indefatigable, scoring 5 hits that caused her to explode and sink.  She suffered multiple large hits causing all 4 turrets to be out of action at one point, but remained in the battle line.   She was ultimately scuttled at Scapa Flow by her crew. Her name should be corrected to "von der Tann"  (info from Gary Staff, German Battle Cruisers 1914-1918, Osprey Publishing)
Ein wunderschönes Schiff!

SMS Von der Tann[a] was the first battlecruiser built for the German Kaiserliche Marine, as well as Germany's first major turbine-powered warship. At the time of her construction, Von der Tann was the fastest dreadnought-type warship afloat, capable of reaching speeds of more than 27 knots. Built by Blohm & Voss in Hamburg, Von der Tann was the workhorse of the High Seas Fleet Scouting Squadron.

Von der Tann was designed in response to the British Invincible class. While the German design had slightly lighter guns—28 cm (11 in),[b] compared to the 30.5 cm (12 in) Mark X mounted on the British ships—Von der Tann was faster and significantly better-armored. She set the precedent of German battlecruisers carrying much heavier armor than their British equivalents, albeit at the cost of smaller guns.

The ship participated in a number of fleet actions during the First World War, including the Battle of Jutland, where she destroyed the British battlecruiser HMS Indefatigable within minutes of the engagement. Von der Tann was hit several times by large-caliber shells, but the damage was quickly repaired and the ship returned to the fleet in two months.

Following the end of the war in 1918, Von der Tann, along with most of the High Seas Fleet, was interned at Scapa Flow pending a decision by the Allies as to the fate of the fleet. The ship met her end when the fleet was scuttled in 1919 to prevent them falling into British hands. The wreck of Von der Tann was raised in 1930, and scrapped at Rosyth from 1931 to 1934
Von der Tann carried eight 28 cm (11 in) SK L/45[d] guns, mounted in four twin turrets: one fore, one aft, and two staggered wing turrets. The guns were emplaced in the Drh.L C/1907 turntable mount, which was traversed electrically, while the guns themselves used hydraulics to change elevation.[8] The guns could be elevated up to 20 degrees, which enabled a maximum range of 18,900 m (20,700 yd). A refit in 1915 increased this to 20,400 m (22,300 yd). The main guns fired a 302 kg (670 lb) armored-piercing shell that had a muzzle velocity of 875 m/s; the main propellant charges were encased in a brass cartridge. A total of 660 projectiles were stored in four shell rooms, each containing 165 shells. The wing turrets were staggered in such a way that all eight guns were able to fire on broadside on a very wide arc.
Unlike her British contemporaries, Von der Tann also carried a heavy secondary battery, consisting of ten 15 cm (5.9 in) SK L/45 guns, casemated in MPL C/06 pivot mounts, each with 150 high explosive and armor-piercing shells. At construction, these guns could fire their 45.3 kg (100 lb) shells at targets up to 13,500 m (14,800 yd) away; after the 1915 refit, their maximum range was extended to 16,800 m (18,400 yd).She was also armed with sixteen 8.8 cm (3.5 in) SK L/45 guns, to defend against torpedo boats and destroyers. These were also emplaced in pivot mounts, of the MPL C/01-06 type, with a total of 3,200 shells for these guns. These guns fired a 9 kg (20 lb) shell at the high rate of 15 rounds per minute, up to a range of 10,694 m (11,695 yd), which was quite long for a smaller caliber weapon. In late 1916, following repair work after the damage sustained during the Battle of Jutland, Von der Tann had her 8.8 cm (3.5 in) guns removed and the firing ports welded shut. Two 8.8 cm flak guns were installed on the aft superstructure.

As was customary for capital ships of the time, Von der Tann was equipped with four 45 cm (18 in) torpedo tubes, with a total of 11 torpedoes. These were located in the bow, the stern, and two on the broadside. The torpedoes carried a 110 kg (240 lb) warhead, and had an effective range of 2 km (1.04 nmi) when set for a speed of 32 kn (59 km/h), and 1.5 km (0.81 nmi) at 36 kn (67 km/

Marie Louise Bottineau Baldwin (1863-1952), Chippewa lawyer; she was the first Native American student and first woman of color to graduate from the Washington College of Law, in 1914. She worked in the Bureau of Indian Affairs, and was an officer in the Society of American Indians. Because she was a fluent French speaker, she offered her skills as a translator to the War Department during WWI. www.scribd.com/doc/27658436/Marie-Bottineau-Baldwin

Antoine Nottar was a French reservist shot by a Sgt. Hooten of the 5th Royal Highlanders in Montreal on August 14th, 1914 near the Craig Street Armoury. Hooten claimed that Nottar was about to pull a revolver on him. Accounts differed of whether the shooting took place on the street or in a restaurant.
He was a French reservist or French Canadian? Either way, Montreal has always been a tough town.
I think French. But the story disappears almost immediately. Curious.

Some more information thanks to Dr. Jim Wood at the University of Victoria: It appears that Nottar was shot while having his picture taken in front of an armoury, and it appears that a bystander was also wounded by the same bullet. Obviously the sentry was caught up in the hysteria of August 1914 and was acting on the orders that had been given shortly before this: 

The orders for the 9,000 militiamen on guard duty were the same from coast to coast:– Militiamen employed in the protection of public works, buildings, etc. will not hesitate to take effective measures to prevent the perpetration of malicious injury; and should sentries, piquets, or patrols be obliged to use their weapons and open fire, their aim will be directed at and not (to the danger of peaceable citizens) over the heads of offending parties.

John R. Jellicoe, 1859-1935, British Admiral en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Jellicoe,_1st_Earl_Jellicoe and www.historyofwar.org/articles/people_jellicoe_john.html "In July 1914 Jellicoe was sent back to sea as second-in-command of the Grand Fleet, with the expectation that he would replace Admiral Callaghan when he retired in October. The First World War broke out two months too soon for this neat transition to take place, and on 4 August he was appointed as commander-in-chief of the Grand Fleet. It could be argued that the change took place too soon, and that Callaghan should have remained in charge until October. He was certainly a more experienced admiral, well known in the fleet and popular, and Jellicoe made four attempts to turn down the promotion. This perhaps rather under-plays the importance of public opinion around the world – to replace the commander-in-chief of the Grand Fleet two months into a world war, before any clash at sea, and during the period of the Race to the Sea, would not have been seen as a confident move. "

LWyman, Thanks for the heads up. You are right, this is indeed the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills, Long Island. The event taking place is the Davis Cup Match between the American and the Australasian teams. This photograph shows the doubles match between Anthony F. Wilding and Norman E. Brookes of Australia and the American pair of Maurice E. McLoughlin and Thomas A. Bundy. The Australians would go on to win this match in straight sets, and eventually take the Davis Cup. The Davis Cup itself is pictured at left on a table, and the scoreboard reveals it is early yet: tied at one game apiece in the first set. More about this match can be found in this article from the New York Times of August 15, 1914. We will expand the description for this photograph when we update.

Everyone, Thanks for all the comments! It's a good suggestion that this unidentified man could be Theodore Roosevelt based on the location and his general appearance, but the date of the photograph doesn't support it, unfortunately. The date of this image has been determined to be 1888, based on Pinkey's Blue Book, as trialsanderrors points out. (Pinkey was a nickname for Frances Benjamin Johnston.) While this particular image is not part of Pinkey's Blue Book, you can see that the cover image was taken at the same time, and the book is dated to 1888 by the writing just below it. Theodore Roosevelt was appointed Assistant Secretary of the Navy in 1897 by President McKinley. In 1888, he was still living with his family at Sagamore Hill in Oyster Bay, New York.
Also, in the 1880s Teddy Roosevelt still looked noticeably younger than his well-known presidential self... www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2009633128/

an extensive history of the company and details about this machine: gasengine.farmcollector.com/Tractors/Midwest-Utilitor.aspx The tractor was powered by a one cylinder, 4 cycle, L-head vertical type motor, with a 3? bore and 4?' stroke. The normal speed was 1200 r.p.m., with 4 HP at the pulley and 2 HP at the drawbar. All working parts of the motor were enclosed, and were water-cooled. Ignition was accomplished with an Eisenman high tension magneto. The Utilitor had a total weight of 700 pounds, measured 84 inches long, 17? inches wide, and 3 feet high. Speed range was 1 to 4 miles per hour, with 2? m.p.h. being the recommended plowing speed. The body color was red, with yellow bull wheels and green flywheels. The Utilitor, with standard equipment (magneto, air cleaner, 16 inch castor wheels, standard or cultivating quick detachable rims, handles, belt pulley and double clutch), sold for $345 complete.

No Wikipedia entry. From thePeerage.com: Admiral Henry Craven St. John was born on 5 January 1837. (...) He died on 21 May 1909 at age 72. Admiral Henry Craven St. John held the office of Naval Aide-de-Camp to HM Queen Victoria between 1887 and 1889. Notably, he was dead by the beginning of WW1. His son's biography (and rank) is a better match, but the initials don't match. Vice-Admiral Francis Gerald St. John was born on 22 December 1869.1 He was the son of Admiral Henry Craven St. John and Catherine Dora Rodney. (...) He died on 15 February 1947 at age 77. Vice-Admiral Francis Gerald St. John fought in the Boer War. He fought in the Boxer Rebellion in 1900. He fought in the First World War, where he was mentioned in despatches twice. He was invested as a Member, Royal Victorian Order (M.V.O.) in 1914. He was invested as a Companion, Order of the Bath (C.B.) in 1917. He held the office of Aide-de-Camp to HM King George V between 1920 and 1921.

Admiral of the Fleet Sir Arthur Knyvet Wilson VC, GCB, OM, GCVO (4 March 1842 – 25 May 1921) was an English Admiral and briefly First Sea Lord who was awarded the Victoria Cross for gallantry during the war in Sudan. An early expert on torpedoes, he twice commanded HMS Vernon, and he was an early proponent of submarines in the Royal Navy. Wilson reached the rank of Admiral of the Fleet in 1907, and became First Sea Lord in 1910. Wilson "was abrasive, inarticulate, and autocratic. He was selected as Fisher's successor because he was the potential protector of his legacy; Wilson's seniority would enable him to control the twelve full admirals on the active list, at least five of whom belonged to the 'syndicate of discontent' committed to dismantling Fisher's reforms if given the opportunity. But by 1910 Wilson had been retired three years. Furthermore, although his reputation had been gained at sea rather than in the corridors of the Admiralty, he had never commanded Dreadnoughts. Wilson survived for even less time than was intended by the stopgap nature of his appointment. His successor in November 1911, Sir Francis Bridgeman also got the job by default." "The combination of frequent change and weak appointees [Wilson, Bridgeman and Battenberg] ensured that the professional leadership of the Royal Navy lost its direction in the four years preceding the war." Wilson retired in 1911, and received the Order of Merit in 1912
Made a CB in 1894 but a KCB in 1902 so the photo must pre-date the latter.

Colonel Henry Elliott Chevallier Kitchener, 2nd Earl Kitchener (5 October 1846 - 27 March 1937), was a British soldier and peer. He saw his first action in Burma with the British Army where he was Chief transport officer of the Field Force's during the Manipur Expedition in 1891. His was posted to Jamaica in December 1898 where he was appointed Deputy Assistant Adjutant General for the British colony before receiving his final posting in the Army when he was appointed commander of the Depot for the West Indies Regiment. He retired from the Army in 1903 with the rank Colonel.

Given the dates of the Bain photos, this could be the second Columbia built by Mr. J. Harvey Ladew. The first Columbia, built by William Cramp & Sons, was seized by the U.S. Government in 1898 and renamed the U.S.S. Wasp for service during the Spanish American War. The second Columbia caused a bit of a international incident when she put in at the closed port of Wakayama for repairs. [1]<a href="http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F04E4D6143FE633A25756C1A9609C946296D6CF"[2] Journal of the American Society of Naval Engineers, Vol. 11

USS Wakiva II (SP-160), often referred to as USS Wakiva, was an armed yacht that served in the United States Navy from 1917 to 1918 and saw combat in World War I. She was originally the yacht SS Wakiva II built for Lamon V. Harkness in Scotland. Wakiva II served as a convoy escort out of Brest, France, and had several encounters with German submarines. The ship received credit for a "probably seriously damaged" submarine in November 1917. She was lost in a convoy collision in fog en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Wakiva_II_%28SP-160%29

General Sir Edward Francis Chapman KCB (1840-1926) was a British Army officer who commanded the Army in Scotland. Chapman was commissioned into the Royal Artillery in 1858. He served in Abyssinia between 1867 and 1868 and was a member of a mission to Yarkand in China in 1874. He also served in the Second Anglo-Afghan War from 1878 to 1880. He was appointed Military Secretary to the Commander-in-Chief, India in 1881 and went on the Burma expedition in 1885. He was Quartermaster-General for India from 1885 and then became Director of Military Intelligence at the War Office in 1891. He was made Commander Scottish District in 1896, a post he held until 1901; he retired in 1906. The picture in the Wikipedia article is the color version of this one.

an early Dreadnought, with an unusual gun placement that caused a variety of issues precluding all 10 actually being fired except in certain circumstances. She was present at the Battle of Jutland as part of Admiral Jellicoe's Battle Fleet. She fired only 48 12 inch (305 mm) shells but is credited with scoring several hits on the German battlecruiser Lützow. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Neptune_(1909)

If anything, HMS Neptune was a retrograde step for the Royal Navy, the big gun arrangement was unusual and in practice was found to limit the guns effectiveness to a major degree.....in theory, she had a broadside of all ten 12" guns, but the two staggered centrally mounted turrets only had very small arcs of fire so the actual maximum number of guns that could be fired simultaneously as a broadside,  was therefore only eight, the three turrets mounted on the centre line plus the "wing' turret actually on the side towards which the ship was firing, the turret on the opposite side of the ship was effectively silenced! Had all ten been fired, as was supposed to be possible, there was also the detrimental effects of the blast on the ships superstructure to take into account.......the likelihood and effects of blast damage to superstructure also effectively prevented the wing turrets from firing directly ahead or astern too, again reducing potential fire power in either direction.
  It seems strange to note that, despite the handicaps imposed by these turret arrangements, which must have been glaringly obvious to many senior naval officers and ship designers of the day, the layout was repeated in the next class of battleship, the Colossus class, ordered and laid down the same year!
Very interesting. I was just reading a WWI book that briefly discussed the Battle of Jutland, and it mentioned the Neptune didn't fire many shots, but it did not say why.

the unusual arrangement of the midships big gun turrets allowed for two "flying bridges" to be constructed above them. This cumbersome arrangement was also a feature of the later, similar Colossus class, but it was discontinued after these ships because there was a very real fear that if the structures took damage from incoming fire, they could collapse and obstruct or damage or jam the gun turrets underneath them. The whole layout of wing turrets and flying bridges was ill-conceived and badly thought out, and was never repeated(thankfully). the Colossus class also incorporated another retrograde step in capital ship design, by having the mainmast stepped abaft the fore funnel. With a head wind, or at high speed, this meant the spotting top on the mainmast was rendered completely unusable and uninhabitable, due to the heat and smoke and exhaust gases from the forward funnel which enveloped it.

it was a difficult time being a ship designer, new classes came out almost yearly between 1909 and the end of the war.  Superfiring/centerline guns were just being designed even as the guns themselves were being made larger and heavier.  Oftentimes the original design was modified even after the keel was laid, and England and Germany each modified designs on the ways as each side unveiled their latest creation, and both treasuries were continually stretched to the limit., ultimately leading to the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922.

Around the time the Neptune and Colossus classes were being built,  the RN and the Admiralty, while maintaining the apparent lead over its potential rivals,  saw much of British naval design became obsessed and obscured by arithmetic. For example, as we have seen, the Neptune and Colossus classes did not have a broadside of all ten 12" guns, the gun layout precluded this and eight was the maximum actually possible. Their maximum armour belt thickness was actually less than that of HMS Dreadnought herself, built five years earlier!  Needless to say, this fact was NOT made public knowledge!  At the same time, the scanty armour protection of the latest battlecruisers was deliberately and greatly exaggerated, so that on paper, at least, the RN was a  vastly superior force in all respects to any and all of its potential enemies.  The only thing that mattered, it seems, with the benefit of hindsight, was numbers,  bigger ships with bigger guns. British capital ships of this period were not faulty, or ineffective, but their true fighting value was somewhat disguised by arithmetical inaccuracy, and this was only exposed to public scrutiny under the rigours of war, and as we all know, the catalogue of battleship and battlecruiser losses between 1914-18 brought this into very sharp focus.........

Apparently... S.S. City of New York was a British built passenger liner of the Inman Line that was designed to be the largest and fastest liner on the Atlantic. When she entered service in August 1888, she was the first twin screw express liner and while she did not achieve the westbound Blue Riband, she ultimately held the eastbound record from August 1892 to May 1893 at a speed of 20.11 knots. City of New York, and her sister City of Paris are considered especially beautiful ships and throughout their careers were rivals to the White Star Teutonic and Majestic. In February 1893, the Inman Line was merged into the American Line and by act of Congress, the renamed New York was transferred to the US flag. Beginning in the mid 1890s, New York and Paris were paired with St Louis and St Paul to form one of the premier Atlantic services. New York continued with the American Line until 1920 and was broken for scrap in 1923. She served the US Navy as Harvard during the Spanish American War and Plattsburg in World War I. She is also remembered for nearly colliding with the Titanic.

The Bass-Curtiss Airboat was a Curtiss Model F Flying Boat that was modified at Ernest C. Bass's request in 1914 to use a 125 horsepower Anzani 10 radial engine (mistakenly described as a "Lingazani" engine in the New York Times story cited below), instead of the standard Curtiss OX-5 engine. See: flyingmachines.ru/Site2/Crafts/Craft29829.htm and, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20712FB345F13738... CURTISS OCEAN FLIGHT? Aviator Asked About Designing a Boat to Win Daily Mail's Prize. New York Times January 4, 1914 "The New York Times correspondent in Paris reports that Ernest Bass, a cousin of Lord Burton, who recently inherited $500,000 from his father's estate, lately ordered a Curtiss boat, but will have the Curtiss engine taken out and install a ten-cylinder Lingazani [sic] of 120 horse power. Mr. Bass declined to say whether he intended to compete for the Daily Mail prize."
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5853169420/]

Mechelen (locally pronounced [ˈmɛxələ(n)], French Malines, English traditional name Mechlin) is a Dutch-speaking city and municipality in the province of Antwerp, Flanders, Belgium. The municipality comprises the city of Mechelen proper, some quarters at its outskirts, the hamlets of Nekkerspoel (adjacent) and Battel (a few kilometers away), as well as the villages of Walem, Heffen, Leest, Hombeek, and Muizen. The Dijle flows through the city, hence the term 'Dijlestad' ("City on the river Dijle"). Mechelen lies on the major urban and industrial axis Brussels-Antwerp, about 25 km from each city. This seems to be the Schepenhuis.

Sir James Key Caird, 1st Baronet (7 January 1837 – 6 March 1916) was a Scottish jute baron and mathematician. He was one of the city's most successful entrepreneurs, who used the latest technology in his Ashton and Craigie Mills. James Caird was born in Dundee, and was the son of Edward Caird (1806–1889) who had founded the firm of Caird (Dundee) Ltd in 1832. Edward Caird was one of the first textile manufacturers to weave cloth composed of jute warp and weft. As the use of jute became increasingly popular, the Caird business expanded and thrived. No picture in the Wikipedia article.

commissioned in 1911, Colossus and her sister ship HMS Hercules fought at the Battle of Jutland ,  during which HMS Colossus was slightly damaged. Eventually broken up in 1922. The ships were coal fired, and the masts were not intended for sails, the last British battleship to be equipped with masts intended for a sailing rig, was HMS Inflexible, commissioned in1881. HMS Devastation, commissioned in 1869, was the first British ocean going ironclad to be completed without a sailing rig.

Actually the Maison Kammerzell. It still exists (and still mostly looks the same)... Photochrom from the LOC P&P Collection: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/trialsanderrors/481033556/]
LOC: Your caption and Bain's both misspell the name "Gutenberg," but yours also adds an extra "t".
Also, even though Johannes Gutenberg worked in Strasbourg (Strassburg), there is no connection between him and the Kammerzell House.

It's probably a situation like that which prevailed in Bonn, former capital of the Federal Republic of (West) Germany, and the hometown of Beethoven. In 1956, I bought a ticket and was given a tour of "Beethovens Geburtshaus" in Bonn. I found out later that the tourist people there were simply trying to answer public demand. Tourists wanted to see the great man's birthplace, but it no longer existed, so officials had opened a half-timbered old pile, and filled it with furniture that Beethoven's parents might have liked. I don't know if they are still running that scam there, or perhaps have found a different "birthplace" to fill the need. . . .

From all I know (and I just visited a few weeks ago) it isn't the city of Strasbourg that claims the connection. It seems to me that Bain made the connection "old + Strasbourg = Gutenburg [sic]". The photochrom I posted is from the same era, and it simply calls it "La vieille maison", the old house.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/13877179@N00] Is that because one of the tenants was a manufacturer of undergarments? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8623220@N02] Btw, it's noteworthy that both merchants on the ground floor advertise in French, even though from 1871 to November 1918 Strasbourg was part of the German Reich. Full-sized version on Wikimedia Commons: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Gutenberg_House_(Maison_K...

Wystan and trialsanderrors:

Thanks for the comments.  Agreed that there is no apparent Gutenberg connection to this house. It's not far from Place Gutenberg, and there is, of course, a Johannes Gutenberg connection to Strasbourg, but not to this building as far as I can tell. We will amend the record to note this is the Maison Kammerzell (so named in the mid-19th century). It was referred to as Altes Haus or Maison Vieille as well.

This particular photo is the Olympic. The electric cranes and white band on her poop deck give her away. She must have been docked when the Adriatic departed.

The RMS Olympic is of course the sister ship of the Titanic. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/trialsanderrors/3015565255/] RMS Olympic was the lead ship of the Olympic-class ocean liners built for the White Star Line, which also included Titanic and Britannic. Unlike her sisters, Olympic served a long and illustrious career (1911 to 1935), including service as a troopship during World War I, earning the nickname "Old Reliable." For a short time she was the largest ocean liner in the world. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163900354/] RMS Adriatic (1907–1935) was an ocean liner belonging to the White Star Line. She was the fourth of a quartet of ships measuring over 20,000 tons, dubbed The Big Four, and the only one of the four which was never the world's largest ship. But she was the fastest and the biggest of all Big Four. She was as big as her sister, RMS Celtic, and nearly identical in outward appearance. She was the first ocean liner to have an indoor swimming pool and Turkish bath. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5818139846/]

S.S. Minnehaha was a 13,443-ton ocean liner built by Harland and Wolff and launched on 31 March 1900. Operated by the American-owned Atlantic Transport Line, she was the sister ship of SS Minneapolis, SS Minnetonka, and SS Minnewaska. In her first year of operations, the Minnehaha collided with and sank a tug in New York Harbor on 18 September 1900. The tug suffered two fatalities. On 18 April 1910, the liner grounded on rocks on Bryher in the Isles of Scilly while en route from London to New York; she remained stranded until 13 May when two tugs managed to pull her off the rocks. The cattle on board were saved by swimming them onto the island of Samson, Isles of Scilly where there was temporary pasture; no lives were lost. On 7 September 1917, Minnehaha sank within four minutes after being torpedoed by German U-boat U-48, with 43 fatalities. Her sister ships Minneapolis and Minnetonka were scuttled while in use as troop transports during World War I. Named after the fictional American Indian woman: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/trialsanderrors/3959138560/]

This is Hanns Heinz Ewers, a German writer. He was marooned in NY and couldn't go home to Germany after the outbreak of WWI. "Germany cannot lose" he said, see New-York tribune., August 07, 1914, Page 9, with photo. "Hanns Heinz Ewers (3 November 1871 in Düsseldorf – 12 June 1943 in Berlin) was a German actor, poet, philosopher, and writer of short stories and novels. While he wrote on a wide range of subjects, he is now known mainly for his works of horror, particularly his trilogy of novels about the adventures of Frank Braun, a character modeled on himself. The best known of these is Alraune (1911)" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanns_Heinz_Ewers He didn't go back to Germany until 1920. In 1918, he was arrested in the United States as an "active propagandist". I doubt that the statement in the NYT, that he was president of the Society of German Authors, is true (hanns-heinz-ewers.com says that he was co-founder of the "Schutzverband deutscher Schriftsteller"). According to the German wikipedia site the only prize he ever won was in a beauty pageant for men.

French Line Steamship used CAMOUFLAGE COLORS during World War I service  - " LA LORRAINE ", Paquebot de la Compagnie Transatlantique M.D. The S.S. LA LORRAINE 
used WWI Camouflage  while traveling at Sea. Outstanding Compagnie Generale Transatlantique Steamship history. La Lorraine (1899-1922 - 11,146gt) 
The La Lorraine was scrapped in 1922.

LA LORRAINE / LORRAINE II 1899 
Built in 1899 by CGT, St Nazaire, the LA LORRAINE was a 11,146 gross ton ship, length 563.1ft x beam 60ft, two funnels, two masts, twin screw and a speed of 20 knots. There was accommodation for 446-1st, 116-2nd and 552-3rd class passengers. Launched on 20/9/1899 for the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique (French Line) she sailed on her maiden voyage from Havre to New York on 11/8/1900. On 25/7/1914 she started her last voyage on this route before the war and between 1914 and 1917 was used as an Armed Merchant Cruiser and renamed LORRAINE II. In 1918 she reverted to her original name and commenced her first voyage in May 1918 when she sailed between Bordeaux and New York. Her last sailing on this route commenced on 19/1/1919 and on 22/2/1919 she resumed the Havre - New York service. In May 1922 she was refitted to carry cabin and 3rd class passengers only and on 1/10/1922 commenced her final Havre - New York sailing. In December 1922 she was scrapped at St Nazaire. [North Atlantic Seaway by N.R.P.Bonsor, vol.2,p.658]

Built in 1899 by CGT, St Nazaire, the LA LORRAINE was a 11,146 gross ton ship, length 563.1ft x beam 60ft, two funnels, two masts, twin screw and a speed of 20 knots. There was accommodation for 446-1st, 116-2nd and 552-3rd class passengers. Launched on 20/9/1899 for the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique (French Line) she sailed on her maiden voyage from Havre to New York on 11/8/1900. On 25/7/1914 she started her last voyage on this route before the war and between 1914 and 1917 was used as an Armed Merchant Cruiser and renamed LORRAINE II. In 1918 she reverted to her original name and commenced her first voyage in May 1918 when she sailed between Bordeaux and New York. Her last sailing on this route commenced on 19/1/1919 and on 22/2/1919 she resumed the Havre - New York service. In May 1922 she was refitted to carry cabin and 3rd class passengers only and on 1/10/1922 commenced her final Havre - New York sailing. In December 1922 she was scrapped at St Nazaire. [North Atlantic Seaway by N.R.P.Bonsor, vol.2,p.658]

John William "Johnny" Bates (August 21, 1882 in Steubenville, Ohio - February 10, 1949 in Steubenville, Ohio), is a former Major League Baseball outfielder. He played nine seasons in the majors from 1906 until 1914. Bates played for the Boston Beaneaters, Cincinnati Reds, Philadelphia Phillies and Chicago Cubs in the National League, and finished his career with the Baltimore Terrapins of the Federal League. In 1154 games, Bates recorded 1087 hits, 25 home runs and 417 RBI with a .278 batting average.

He was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1945. Bresnahan introduced the use of the catcher's shin guard in 1907. Bresnahan played for the Chicago Cubs from 1913–15. George Washington (Zip) Zabel (February 18, 1891, Wetmore, Kansas—May 31, 1970, Beloit, Wisconsin) was a Major League relief pitcher for the Chicago Cubs. He came into the game in relief for Bert Humphries with two out in the first inning, and pitched the final 18⅓ innings to earn the win over the Brooklyn Dodgers and opposing pitcher Jeff Pfeffer, who pitched the complete game. James Leslie "Hippo" Vaughn (April 9, 1888 – May 29, 1966) was an American left-handed pitcher in Major League Baseball for the Chicago Cubs during the 1910s. He had some good years for the Cubs during a time when they were not always competitive, winning over 20 games in five seasons, including a National League-leading 22 in 1918, when the season was ended a month early due to government restrictions brought about by World War I. Vaughn was born in Weatherford, Texas. Aside from the unflattering nickname (at 6-foot-4 and 215 pounds, he was only slightly less heavy than 1970s Cubs star Rick Reuschel), he is best remembered for his participation in what the record books used to refer to as a "double no-hitter". On May 2, 1917, at the ballpark now known as Wrigley Field, Vaughn dueled with Fred Toney of the Cincinnati Reds for nine hitless innings. In the top of the 10th, the Reds scored on a couple of hits after Vaughn had retired the first batter, while Toney continued to hold the Cubs hitless in the bottom of the inning, winning the game for the Reds. With changes to the scoring rules in recent years, this game is no longer considered as a no-hitter for Vaughn; but it is still the only occasion in major league history in which a regulation nine innings was played without either team logging a hit.
