Cecilie of Mecklenburg-Schwerin (Cecilie Auguste Marie; 20 September 1886 – 6 May 1954) was a Crown Princess of Germany and Prussia as the wife of German Crown Prince William, the son of German Emperor William II Victoria Louise of Prussia (Viktoria Luise Adelheid Mathilde Charlotte; 13 September 1892 – 11 December 1980) was the only daughter and the seventh child of William II, German Emperor and Empress Augusta Victoria. She was their last surviving child. Princess Victoria Louise is the maternal grandmother of Queen Sophie of Spain and the former King Constantine II of the Hellenes. She was the Duchess of Brunswick by marriage. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5793149715/]

I agree. I'm fairly sure the uniforms are from the same country. In addition, the pictures look like they come from the same photosession. There is also a date stamp on the original picture which I'm reading as 9/15/14—which means the young princess could at the most be 14 years old. If the Bain practice of using archive photos of individuals for current events hold here too she's less than that, and the girl in the bottom photo is likely the young princess with her brother Carol II. Which leaves us with the mother as the person depicted in the original photo.

Alix of Hesse and by Rhine later Alexandra Feodorovna Romanova (Russian: Императрица Александра Фёдоровна Романова Imperatritsa Aleksandra Fyodorovna Romanova) (6 June 1872 – 17 July 1918), was Empress consort of Russia as spouse of Nicholas II, the last Emperor of the Russian Empire. Born a granddaughter of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom, she was given the name Alexandra Feodorovna upon being received into the Russian Orthodox Church, which canonized her as Saint Alexandra the Passion Bearer in 2000. Alexandra is best remembered as the last Tsarina of Russia, as one of the most famous royal carriers of the haemophilia disease and for her support of autocratic control over the country. Her notorious friendship with the Russian mystic Grigori Rasputin was also an important factor in her life. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4332082611/]

The Armoured Cruiser Fürst Bismarck (per www.kbismarck.com/otherbis.html) This cruiser was laid down on 1 April 1896 at the Kaiserliche-Werft in Kiel. She was launched on 25 September 1897 and later commissioned on 1 April 1900. The Fürst Bismarck served abroad in the East-Asian Squadron until 1909. Between 1910 and 1914 she was refitted at Kiel Dockyard and used as a coastal defence ship. In March 1915, the ship was disarmed and converted to an engine training ship. In 1919 she was used as an naval office ship until she was stricken on 17th June and sold to Brand & Son, Audorf. She was scrapped in 1919-20 at Audorf-Rendsburg. Displacement: standard 10,690 mt, full load 11,460 mt. Dimensions: overall length 127 meters, water line 125.7 meters, beam 20.4 meters, draft 7.8 meters forward, 8.46 aft. Armament: 4 x 24cm/L40, 12 x 15cm/L40, 10 x 8.8cm/L30, 5 x 45cm TT. Protection: deck 30-50 mm, belt 100-200mm, main turrets 200 mm max, conning tower 200 mm max. Propulsion Plant: Three vertical 4-cylinder engines, 8 Dürr burners boilers, three screws, power 13,622ihp max. Speed: 18.7 knots. Crew: 621 men.
The photo should be titled "Fürst Bismarck" or "Fuerst Bismarck."

SMS Fürst Bismarck was Germany's first armored cruiser.  You can see the more graceful lines that distinguished most German capital ships throughout the first half of the 20th century, in contrast to many ships of the UK and US which often had casements for the smaller guns which interfered with a smoother hull facade.

HMS Bellerophon was a dreadnought of the Royal Navy. She was the lead ship of the Bellerophon class, and the fourth Royal Navy vessel to bear the name of the mythic Greek hero. Built at the Royal Dockyard in Portsmouth and completed in 1909, Bellerophon first joined the 1st Battle Squadron and then upon the outbreak of war joined the 4th Battle Squadron where she remained until 1919. She was present at the Battle of Jutland where she fired sixty-two 12 inch rounds and received no damage. With the end of the war she was placed in the Reserve Fleet and sold for scrap in 1921 before being taken to the breakers two years later.

They were originally known as armoured cruisers until they were redesignated as battlecruisers by an Admiralty order of 24 November 1911. The confusion seems quite common as they were also known as cruiser-battleship, dreadnought cruiser and battle-cruiser before the admiralty decree.  The date may be 8/10/1915. The picture shown is the the HMS New Zealand (1905-1911) which was a pre-dreadnought battleship of the King Edward VII class (4-12",4-9.2",10-6",16,350 tons, 18-19 knots). She was re-named HMS Zealandia on Dec 1, 1911; releasing the "HMS New Zealand" name for a new battlecruiser that was completed in January 1912 (not pictured). The HMS Zealandia and her 7 sisters made up the 3rd Battle Squadron with the home fleet at the beginning of WWI, but because of their slower speed were soon relegated to serving in other theaters of the war where faster German dreadnoughts were not potential advesaries.

The Russian Imperial Yacht Standart (Штандартъ), serving Emperor Nicholas II and his family, was at her time (late 19th/early 20th century) the largest Imperial Yacht afloat. gold was frequently shipped by liner because of the gold standard.  These folks are outside JP Morgan

Morgan saved the gold standard in 1895 by convincing European bankers to buy US T-bonds. US reserves of gold had been sinking at the rate of $2 million a day and reached a low of $40 million at one point. By 1914 things were in pretty good shape but then war broke out and everyone went off the gold standard. The gold standard wasn't restored until 1925 and didn't last much longer after that. Today of course gold and silver are a distant memory and none of our coins are worth the zinc they're made of.

on Lusitania's 3rd westbound voyage, Nov 3, 1907, she carried a record gold shipment of $12,361.150  (approx $250,000,000 today)  the largest gold shipment on a ship at that time, because of a sudden US Treasury demand. The shipment is described as gold bars, so it's interesting to see small barrels here.  It makes you wonder what form it has inside them.

These appear to be US dry half barrels (a full dry barrel is 28x17 inches). I found a couple references to shipping gold bars in dry barrels. A half barrel holds about 55 l, and the density of gold is around 19, so if you filled one of these it would weigh over 1000 Kg! I suspect they put a few bars in each barrel and the rest is empty space. A standard gold bar today is 400 troy ounces or 12 Kg and measures 7 x 3-5/8 x 1-3/4 inches.
On second thought these are too small even for half barrels.

A note on Marcella Andrews.  She was the socialite daughter of Matthew Andrews of Cleveland Ohio, born March 18th, 1895 in that city.  In 1917 she married Charles McGhee Baxter, a New York businessman and the son of former Tennessee governor, George White Baxter.  The couple resided in Cleveland and had several children, including 2 sons, Charles Jr., and Matthew, and a daughter, Nancy.

On May 16th, 1927, Marcella died at the Hotel Royal Manceau, in Paris France.  The cause of death was given as an embolism.

In 1930, the Italian government purchased the Baxter New York townhouse at 173 E 70th St from the estate of Marcella Baxter to use as a consulate.
The Japanese consul general, Takashi Nakamura. Source: Boston Evening Transcript, 1 September 1914

Edmund K. Stallo, a lawyer from Cincinnati; his father John Bernard Stallo (1823-1900) was US Ambassador to Italy; his wife Beatrice McDonald was the only surviving child of Scottish-born oil baron Alexander McDonald. They had two daughters, Helena and Laura, before Beatrice died in 1895. Edmund didn't handle his daughters' inheritance very well: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dalvay-by-the-sea Edmund married again, to Mrs. May Harrington Hanna, and divorced in 1912. He married a third time, in 1919, to Mrs. Clarissa Cook, a shipbuilder's daughter. Helena Stallo married a French nobleman, and Laura married an Italian prince. But both daughters' husbands left when their fortunes were lost, and Helena died at 38, from cancer, in straitened circumstances. Edmund's father's Wikipedia entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Stallo

The former Laura McDonald Stallo (1890-1972), daughter of lawyer Edmund Stallo and Laura Beatrice McDonald (d. 1895), granddaughter of Ambassador John Bernard Stallo and oil baron Alexander McDonald. Laura and her sister Helena both married European princes on the promise of their status as oil heiresses; but when the money was less than expected, and what they did inherit was lost to bad management, both sisters were divorced, and left with little to live on. Helena died from cancer at age 38; Laura's daughters were Francesca (1921-1998) and Camilla (b. 1922). Her granddaughter was patients' rights advocate Laura Schmidt Pizzarello (1952-2004): www.gazette.net/gazette_archive/2004/200410/olney/news/20...

A story worthy of a Wikipedia entry? Dr. Edwin Carman was a dentist in Freeport, Long Island, N.Y. On 24(?) June 1914, a patient, Mrs. Louise Bailey was shot and killed in his waiting room. The shot was fired through a window. Carman's wife Florence Conklin Carman was later tried for murder. Helen M. Angle of Stamford CT was accused of killing Waldo R. Ballou.  Her studio apartment in the Rippowam Building was at the top of a flight of stairs; Waldo's body was found at the bottom of those stairs, dead from a skull fracture.  The theory was that she pushed him down the stairs.  The building belonged to Helen's father, Leonard Blondel, who proposed that perhaps the man fell, or a thug attacked Waldo on the stairs, and Helen's dress became bloodstained when she tried to help him.

She was acquitted.  In the process she became reacquainted with her ex-husband.  They were divorced in 1910, but remarried in 1915, after the trial.

Built in 1898 by Harlan and Hollingsworth, Wilmington, DE; Purchased by the Navy, 10 August 1917 and converted to an armed patrol yacht; Commissioned USS Niagara (SP 136), 16 April 1918 at Brooklyn, NY; Reclassified as a Patrol Yacht, PY-9, 17 July 1920; Decommissioned, 21 April 1922 at Philadelphia, PA; Recommissioned, 24 June 1924; Decommissioned, 3 March 1931 at Philadelphia, PA; Struck from the Naval Register, 10 December 1931; Sold for scrap, 13 September 1933. www.navsource.org/archives/12/1309.htm

David Lewis (Dave) Fultz (May 29, 1875 - October 29, 1959) was a center fielder in Major League Baseball who played in the National League with the Philadelphia Phillies (1898-1899[start]) and Baltimore Orioles (1899[end]), and for the Philadelphia Athletics (1901-1902) and New York Highlanders (1903-1905) of the American League. He batted and threw right-handed. In a seven-season career, Fultz posted a .271 batting average with 223 RBI and three home runs in 644 games played. In 1912, he created a furor in baseball by unionizing major league players in an organization called the Players Fraternity. Ty Cobb and Christy Mathewson were among its officers. The group threatened to strike in 1917, but the walkout was averted after Fultz obtained some concessions for the players. The union was disintegrated during World War I. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Fultz

LOC: There is no apostrophe in the town name, Buzzards Bay.
The 8-mile long, sea-level Cape Cod Canal opened on July 29, 1914.

>> There is no apostrophe in the town name ... Some Yankees are possessive about their apostrophes ;) The Gray Lady has written the words Buzzard’s Bay for over 150 years ... President Cleveland had a summer home at Gray Gables mansion in Buzzard’s Bay (located about a mile and a half from the site of the railroad bridge pictured above). Bain News got it right methinks.

This was the first railroad bridge built to cross the new Cape Cod Canal. It was a single-span bascule drawbridge. The 160-foot bridge was completed in 1910, and, as technogeo said, the grand opening of the Cape Cod Canal was July 29, 1914, [1] "The bridge was able to pivot and a double track ran across it. Because of the anticipated heavy loads, the bridge itself had the [an] immense weight of 1200 tons. Only two, 65-horsepower electric motors were needed to open and close the bridge in only one minute." [2] Unfortunately the original 100-foot wide canal was hopelessly too narrow and too shallow, and did little but lose money for its investors. As a result, the Cape Cod Canal was purchased by the U.S. Government in 1928. The canal was widened and deepened to nearly 500 feet wide and 32 feet deep. A new 544-foot wide vertical lift bridge, known as the Cape Cod Canal Railroad Bridge (also known as the Buzzard's Bay Railroad Bridge), was completed in 1935, and is in use to this day.[3]   The new bridge weighs in at almost twice the weight of the old: 2,050 tons. A 1987 photo by photographer Martin Stupich of the "new" vertical lift bridge, from the collection of The Library of Congress, is shown below:   "General View of Cape Cod Canal Railroad Bridge" by The Library of Congress

"Unfortunately the original...canal was hopelessly too narrow and too shallow...."

This seems to be the case with every canal ever built.

NYT spelling was inconsistent before WWI. See for example "The Clevelands Leave Buzzards Bay," 10 Oct 1898 p. 5, spelled without the apostrophe. For at least the last 20 years every search result I could find spelled it without. And the Post Office spells it without.

I would retain the apostrophe in the photo title here, since that's how Bain's spelled it. But note the photographer's imprint in the lower right corner seems to be missing the apostrophe.

A quick skim through Google Books suggests that the apostrophe was standard through most of the 19th century and started being dropped around the time this photo was taken.

Pixel Ranger: "Because of the anticipated heavy loads, the bridge itself had the immense weight of 1200 tons." 

What heavy loads would be going to Cape Cod? Vacationers in Pullman coaches?

"Maybe because it was a double track bridge, it anticipated the weight of two steam engines at the same time?"

I guess they figured it was better to over-engineer the thing. A ten-wheeler from this period with a fully loaded tender could weigh up to 177 tons (12 tons coal; 21 tons water). Each Pullman coach weighed about 80 tons without passengers.

and it's hard for me to find anyone skilled enough to help me build decks and remodel homes...
These guys (meaning ALL involved in every aspect) were Amazing to say the least.

"Because of the anticipated heavy loads, the bridge itself had the [an] immense weight of 1200 tons." With inappropriate editorial license, I inserted the weight of "1200 tons" from the caption of the photograph, into the quote concerning the "massive weight" of the bridge in my original comment (above). This insertion may have brought extra attention to the "massive weight" of the bridge. In any event I have corrected the text in the original comment. I also found a New York Times article from June 16, 1912, that mentioned the 1200 tons:
"The counter balance of the section of the bridge which is lifted hangs at the south end and is filled with 1200 tons of cement."
I gotta say, I dunno how much the bridge weighs! ;-)

Commercial America, Volume 11 puts the weight at 2000 tons but doesn't say whether that includes the counterweight. It says the bridge can be opened in 57 seconds. Also that the US government at the time considered paying for a longer span so battleships could go under it, but apparently decided against it.

A 1200 ton counterweight would be about right for a 800 ton leaf, making the total 2000 tons.

Jean Harold Edward St. Cyr was involved in a scandal alleging he was merely posing as a member of a wealthy French family, but was, in fact from Texas.

With the following citation, I would imagine this photo is from 1914.

Special to The New York Times. 
April 28, 1915,
Section , Page 13, 

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- Jean H. E. Saint Cyr, whose pink silk sweater and sky-blue shirts attracted much attention in Bar Harbor last Summer,
So, was he found to be really a St. Cyr, or was he truly insincere?

According to this newspaper article news.google.com/newspapers?id=OQAdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IpsEA... St Cyr died in 1967 in La Jolla California, still claiming to be a French aristocrat. However, he left money in his will to Hugh Thompson of Waco, Texas who in 1916 told the New York Times St. Cyr was not his brother Jack. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10C1EF6355C1373...

Uniforms appear to mimic European hunting costumes of the period, leading me to suspect that these are what the Germans would call Jaeger (hunter) troops.  Jaegers were/are light infantry, usually employed ahead of or to the flanks of the line of battle.

Serbia was called Servia then.

This is likely a photo of the Cavan football team at the time of their Gaelic football match against Leitrim in 1914. The New York Times reported the match as part of the Fifteenth Annual Games of Local 20, International Union of Steam and Operating Engineers, held at Celtic Park (Queens) on Sunday, July 26, 1914. The next photo in the LOC stream, captioned "Leitrim football (soccer) teams (LOC)" depicts the Leitrim team photographed at the same time. In the background of the Cavan team photo (above) is a Leitrim player in a striped LYM shirt, looking on.

William, Prince of Hohenzollern (German: Wilhelm August Karl Joseph Peter Ferdinand Benedikt Fürst von Hohenzollern) (7 March 1864, Schloss Benrath, near Düsseldorf - 22 October 1927, Sigmaringen) was the eldest son of Leopold, Prince of Hohenzollern and Infanta Antónia of Portugal. His maternal grandparents were Maria II of Portugal and her King consort Ferdinand II of Portugal. On 20 January 1915 he married Adelgunde of Bavaria in Munich. William V. Cleary, for the last fourteen years Town Clerk of Haverstraw, shot and instantly killed, in his office in the Town Hall here this afternoon, Eugene M. Newman, 18 years old, of this place, who secretly married Mr. Cleary's 17-year-old daughter Anna last Saturday. Source: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00A1FF6345D1373...
Newman was killed by his unwilling father-in-law in Haverstraw, New York, twenty miles from NYC, on July 23, 1914.
Alas! Mr. Newman was the murder victim. Let's pay attention.
Well, now I'm curious.  What became of murder Mr. William V. Cleary?

Check out the link to the nytimes article in Richard Arthur Norton's post, chicadee3. Also the wikipedia article about the murder gives some clues as to what became of Mr. Cleary after the jury acquitted him of murder, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleary-Newman_murder

I wrote the Wikipedia article. Eugene Newman was my great-uncle (father's father's brother). I and my father were both named after him, but I knew nothing of him or his murder until I was almost 40 years old and had moved to Chicago. The whole thing was a secret that nobody in my family, or in the town of Haverstraw, ever spoke about.

They blended their whisky to make it more appealing to the international palate and Dewar demonstrated particular skills in marketing, travelling the world to find new markets and promote his product, exploiting romantic images of Scotland and tartan in his advertising.

Found in Wikipedia:
Querido Moheno y Tabares (1873-1933). Nació en Ixtacomitán, Chiapas el 3 de diciembre de 1873. Licenciado por la Escuela Nacional de Jurisprudencia. Fue secretario del Comité Anti-Reeleccionista de Estudiantes que encabezó el movimiento de 1892 en contra de un nuevo período de Porfirio Díaz como Presidente de México. Herido por la policía, estuvo preso y recluido en la cárcel de Belén. Después de su liberación trabajó en 1893 en la redacción del diario "El Demócrata", junto con los hermanos Flores Magón. Fue abogado en Ensenada, juez de primera instancia en Córdoba, diputado federal suplente y miembro de la Comisión organizadora del Partido Democrático. Como diputado propietario a la XXVI Legislatura, junto Nemesio García Naranjo, Francisco Olaguíbel y José María Lozano formó parte del llamado "cuadrilátero", que se distinguió por la virulencia de sus ataques al gobierno maderista. Asimismo, junto con César Castellanos (padre de la escritora Rosario Castellanos), Rómulo Farrera, Adolfo E. Grajales, Jesús Martínez Rojas (fundador de la camarilla “La Mano Negra” san-cristobalense) y Manuel Rovelo Argüello, fue miembro de la diputación chiapaneca en la XXVI Legislatura Federal autora de la iniciativa de ley para que el petróleo y sus derivados fueran nacionalizados.1
 
En 1911, en sustitución de Manuel Rovelo Argüello, fue designado gobernador interino de su estado natal pero no llegó a ocupar el puesto. Fungió como subsecretario y, luego, como titular de la Secretaría de Relaciones Exteriores en el gobierno golpista de Victoriano Huerta. Luego estuvo al frente de la Secretaría de Fomento. A la caída de la dictadura huyó a los Estados Unidos de América y, después, a Cuba. Volvió a México y trabajó como abogado defensor en los tribunales populares de la cárcel de Belén. Muere en el Distrito Federal el 12 de abri de 1933

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvey_D._Hinman Harvey DeForest Hinman (1865–1954) was born in Pitcher, New York. In 1893, Hinman, who had come to Binghamton in 1889, went to work as a clerk for a lawyer named George F. Lyon. Later that same year, Lyon took on another law clerk, Archibald Howard, just out of Lafayette College. In 1894, Thomas B. Kattell went with Lyon as a law clerk. In 1901-1902, the three joined together to form Hinman, Howard & Kattell, an upstate New York law firm that continues under the same name today.

This is a picture of my maternal grandfather, Myrl Tremelin.  He flew lighter-than-air ships in WWI and helped develop the Goodyear blimp in WWII.  He lived in Akron,Ohio.

diana Roose
Oberlin, Ohio

He apparently also held the rank of Lieutenant Colonel during the Second World War. Here, he's cited (albeit with his first name misspelled) in The Evening Independent (Massillon, Ohio) of November 7, 1942, at the bottom of Page 7: "Two service men from Akron were the reviewing officers for the band's military review which followed. They were Lieut. Col. Merle D. Tremelin, army air force resident representative at the Goodyear Aircraft Corp., and Lieut. Fred Ongley of the United States navy. . ." See: www.newspaperarchive.com/SiteMap/FreePdfPreview.aspx?img=...
Thanks for finding this information TVL 1970. We'll add some of it to the caption the next time we update the record.

Myrl David Tremelin lived in Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio.  He served in the Naval Reserves stationed in Pensacola, Florida during World War I (whenthisphoto was taken) and flew hot air balloons for Goodyear.  In World War II, he served as a Lieutenant Colonel in the Army with responsibility for liaison with Goodyear for procurement of rubber goods and other products.  
He was my maternal grandfather and I have care of the Tremelin family history.  happy to provide cites and further details.
Diana Roose, Oberlin, Ohio.   (droose@oberlin.edu)

Perhaps Anthony Gustav de Rothschild -- he'd have been about 27 in 1914. He and his companions stand before a half-timbered building that could be Medieval, or Elizabethan.
I assumed M for Monsieur, but I dunno.  And the building has a very tall door, like a barn.

If this is Anthony Gustav, it is an interesting coincidence that his son, Sir Evelyn Robert Adrian de Rothschild (born in 1931, and named for the uncle who died in WWI), happens to be a member of the board of the Globe Shakespeare Trust: admirers of the Bard, who recently reconstructed Shakespeare's half-timbered Globe Theatre, on its original site, in London.

Anthony Gustav in 1939 inherited his father's estate, Ascott House, a pseudo-Tudor fantasy built in the nineteenth century, in the half-timbered style:

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Andrew_Witherspoon Samuel Andrew Witherspoon (May 4, 1855 – November 24, 1915) was a U.S. Representative from Mississippi. Born near Columbus, Mississippi, Witherspoon attended the public schools. In 1872 he moved with his mother to Oxford, Mississippi. He graduated from the University of Mississippi at Oxford in 1876 with a degree in law. He became a professor at the University of Mississippi from 1876-1879. He was admitted to the bar in 1879 and commenced practice in Meridian, Mississippi, the same year. Witherspoon was elected as a Democrat to the Sixty-second, Sixty-third, and Sixty-fourth Congresses and served from March 4, 1911, until his death in Meridian, Mississippi, November 24, 1915. He was interred in Rose Hill Cemetery.
Canoe racer?  A Ralph B. Britton of the Gananoque Canoe and Motor Boat Club of Ontario, Canada, was champion of the American Canoe Association's New England race off Sugar Island, 1913.

Planned to cross the Atlantic in his motor lifeboat with his new bride, Signe Holm Sivard, July 1914.  He was a naval architect.  (They also traveled with a navigator, a wireless operator, and other crew members.)

with his (by then) wife:

Starting their voyage on July 25, 1914, hey made it all the way from New York to Boston, when the attempted Atlantic crossing had to be aborted, upon receipt of news that World War I had broken out in Europe.
Full name: Einar Lars Magnus Sivard. He was born on 30 Nov 1881 in Stockholm, Sweden.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Stanley,_1st_Baron_Ashfield Albert Henry Stanley, 1st Baron Ashfield, PC, TD (8 August 1874 – 4 November 1948), born Albert Henry Knattriess, was managing director, then chairman of the Underground Electric Railways Company of London (UERL) from 1910 to 1933 and chairman of the London Passenger Transport Board (LPTB) from 1933 to 1947.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_Brookes Sir Norman Everard Brookes (14 November 1877 – 28 September 1968) was an Australian tennis champion and president of the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia. Brookes was born in Melbourne. Brookes' father (William Brookes) had become rich from gold mining in the Bendigo area, and Norman Brookes received a private education at Melbourne Grammar School. On leaving school, he went to work as a clerk at the paper mill where his father was managing director, and was on the board himself within eight years. Brookes married 20-year-old Mabel Balcombe Emmerton, the daughter of Harry Emmerton, a solicitor, on 19 April 1911 at St Paul's Cathedral in Melbourne. They had three daughters.
In this photo, they are on board a ship.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Dunlop Alfred Dunlop (12 January 1875 – 7 April 1933) was an Australian tennis player, born in Christchurch, New Zealand. He won the doubles title at the Australasian Championships, the future Australian Open, alongside Fred Alexander in 1908. He also reached the singles finals at the tournament that year, losing to Alexander.

A photo of Herman Fisher, apparently murdered by Edgar Murphy in July 1914. The motivation for the murder was reportedly Murphy's jealousy concerning Fisher's relationship with Miss Ida Wilhelm. (See also State v. Murphy, 87 N.J.L. 515, 94 A. 640 (E. & A. 1915)). Photos of Murphy and Wilhelm are also included in this group of Bain LOC photos. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5715529129/in/photostream/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5715528999/in/photostream/] query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50C1EFB385A12738... CONFESSES FISHER MURDER Edgar Murphy, Who Reported Finding the Body, Was Jealous. New York Times July 15, 1914 MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 14. - A complete confession of the murder of Herman Fisher near the home of his sweetheart, Ida Wilhelm, at New Albany, on Saturday night, has been made by Edgar Murphy, who was arrested yesterday afternoon.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ella_Flagg_Young She was born in Buffalo, New York to Theodore and Jane (Reed) Flagg in 1845. She didn't attend school until the age of ten, after teaching herself how to read and write at age 10. After only a few months she dropped out because she wasn't being intellectually challenged and the lack of support from her parents. At age 15 Ella took the certification examination to become a teacher and passed but was told she was too young to be a teacher. Ella was told she would never make it as a teacher by her mother but persevered on decided to set up her own practicum to test her potential in the classroom. Ella decided the classroom was right for her and she graduated in 1862 from the Chicago Normal School. She later studied at the University of Chicago under John Dewey at age 55 and received her Ph.D. in 1900.
On board the Lusitania, which was sunk by German torpedoes a year later, May 7, 1915.

Pince-nez type eyeglasses were the most popular eyewear in the USA, Canada and much of Europe during the period 1885 to 1920. A pince-nez had no arms or temples and clipped on the bridge of the nose. It was held in place by either spring powered nose guard grips in the fingerpiece type or a spring bridge with nose guard grips in the hoopspring or C bridge type. Properly fitted and adjusted to each individual, a pince-nez remained securely attached to the bridge of the nose at all times and was very comfortable even during full time wear. Eyeglasses (pince-nez) and spectacles (glasses with temples) : were unisex then. The terms eyeglasses and spectacles had distinct meanings. The rimless pince-nez was the most popular and stylish for all ages. For soldiers,it was great for wear under a gas mask or goggles and army officials stated the a pince-nez was the ideal eyewear. 
See pincenez1.blospot.com Pince-nez Renaissance blog/site the only place on the web or anywhere for very detailed,accurate info re: pince-nez.Click on table of contents. Many of the photos can be enlarged by clicking on them. The site encourages people to wear a pince-nez.

Rhinelander Waldo (May 24, 1877 – August 13, 1927) was appointed the 7th New York City Fire Commissioner by Mayor William Jay Gaynor on January 13, 1910. He resigned on May 23, 1911 (less than two months after the deadly Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire) to accept an appointment as the 8th New York City Police Commissioner. On December 31, 1913, he was dismissed by the outgoing Acting Mayor, Ardolph Kline. Among other achievements in office, Waldo contributed to the motorization of both departments. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhinelander_Waldo

His mother was a Rhinelander; she married his father, a Waldo. So Rhinelander Waldo was named for both parents.

Jimmy Cagney potrayed him in the movie version of E. L. Doctorow's novel, "Ragtime."

From Wikipedia:
Waldo was portrayed by James Cagney in the 1981 film, "Ragtime," despite the age difference (Cagney was 81 years old when he filmed this movie; the real Rhinelander Waldo was only 32 at the time in which the movie was set and died at age 50.) However, in E.L. Doctorow's original novel "Ragtime" (published in 1975), Waldo's role is minor while Charles S. Whitman, the real-life Manhattan District Attorney at the time, performs most of the fictional words and deeds that the film based on Doctorow's book would later assign to Waldo.

Thanks so much to both of you for giving us a good picture of this character. We'll fill in the name the next time we update the record. Waldo was also immortalized in a few of the library's political cartoons of the time. Here's one example: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2009617169/
This photo was likely taken aboard the RMS Olympic on which Mr. and Mrs. Rhinelander Waldo arrived in New York from Southampton on July 8, 1914, — The New York Times

The photo shows Miss Noel Johnston (left) and Miss Marie Tailer of New York City, aboard the RMS Olympic, departing New York.. Another photo taken at the time by photographers Underwood & Underwood was published in The Washington Times on July 09, 1914 (Home Edition, Page 3) — LOC Chronicling America The caption reads: "Miss Tailer has been motoring abroad for the last ten weeks, driving her own car upwards of 5,000 miles. She said she was looking forward to an athletic summer in the Berkshires. Miss Tailer said the best feature of Europe are the roads, which are better than the ones in this country. She also denied she was engaged." Her engagement was announced five months later. Marie Tailer (c.1895-1937), daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lee Tailer, was married November 3, 1915, to S. Bryce Wing (c1890-1975), son of Mr and Mrs L. Stuart Wing of New York.  Marie died of a heart attack in 1937, and her husband remarried in 1939. [1] [2] [3] Noel Johnston (d.1979), daughter of Mr and Mrs J. Herbert Johnson, was married April 14, 1915, to William H. Appleton (b.1883). He was the son of William Worthen Appleton and the late Anna Dublois Sargent Appleton. Mr. Appleton, a Harvard graduate, was in the cotton brokerage business with Stephen M. Weld & Co. He later joined the insurance firm of John C. Paige & Co. Inc. Miss Johnston was the granddaughter of the late John Taylor Johnson, who for many years was President of the Central Railroad of New Jersey. Their engagement was announced in September, 1914, immediately after Noel returned from Europe. [4] [5] On December 31, 1915, they gave birth to a son, William Worthen Appleton, II., who, after graduating from Harvard, taught at Columbia for more than thirty years. [6] [7] Some years later Mrs. Noel Johnston Appleton married D. Wooster King, of New York City, on September 24, 1932. [8]

Marie Tailer – "The Most Beautiful Girl in the World" During his visit to Newport, Rhode Island in 1913, His Imperial Highness, The Grand Duke Alexander Mikhailovich of Russia (1866-1933), was struck by the beauty of American women. According to published reports, The Grand Duke "collected photographs of the women he met in Newport, especially at The Casino and Bailey's Beach." The Grand Duke was particularity smitten by Miss Marie Tailer of New York City, who was visiting Newport at that time, and he was "anxious to obtain a photograph of her". He declared that Miss Tailer was "The Most Beautiful Girl in the World". [1] This pronouncement was picked up by newspapers across the country (if not the world), and photos of Miss Tailer were published for some years afterwards -- always with the "Most Beautiful Girl in the World" moniker in the caption. [2] IMNHO more flattering photos of Miss Tailer than the one above can be found in The (San Francisco) Call and The (Georgia) Evening Ledger. There are several photos of The Grand Duke in the Bain Collection on Flickr:                     "Grand Duke Alexander Michaelovitch"   From Bain / LOC

This appears to be the cab in which chauffeur Pierre Clop and his female passenger, Mme. Lavolti, were killed when his taxicab fell into a hole on the Rue St. Augustin. The incident occured during a three-hour storm "of phenomenal violence" on the night of Monday, June 15, 1914. Eyewitnesses saw the hand of a woman waving from one of the windows of the cab before it was covered by an avalanche of loose earth. Fourteen people died during the storm as sections of streets collapsed in several parts of the city. Seven thousand cab drivers attended Clop's funeral on Friday, June 19. According to the papers, "Further subsidences occur daily, the latest, 200 feet long and 10 feet wide, being in Rue Moncey." References: New York Times, June 16, 1914 New York Times, June 20, 1914 et al.

Born Jessie Gregg in 1865, she married composer Edgar Stillman Kelley (note spelling) on 1891, in San Francisco. Jessie was also musical: she was involved in various organizations for music teachers, and headed the piano department at Western College for Women in Ohio. She was widowed in 1944. staff.lib.muohio.edu/westernarchives/kelley/wife-bio2.php

Mae Sullivan was the young woman who accused Arthur Hoe of breach of promise.  In June 1914, she went on stage to capitalize on the interest in the scandal--she carried a garden hoe (as a reference to his name), sang a little song, and said a few words, at Hammerstein's Victoria Theatre.  And then she was arrested for contempt of court.

A repeat appearance: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2515737945] Amos Richards Eno Pinchot (December 6, 1873 – February 18, 1944) was an American reformist. He never held public office but managed to exert considerable influence in reformist circles and did much to keep progressive ideas alive in the 1920s.

Amos and his his older brother Gifford Pinchot, who were very wealthy, were major supporters of Theodore Roosevelt's run for the presidency in 1912 and contributed substantial funds to the unsuccessful campaign.

New York Times, 10 March 1915: C.C. Madison, former owner of the Kansas City club of the Federal League, testified before Judge Baldwin in the Circuit Court here today, where owners of this club are seeking to enjoin the transfer of its franchise to Newark, N.J. He was cross-examined by Edward E. Gates, attorney for the league, which is defendant in the suit. The Federal League baseball team was the Kansas City Packers.

Ada Comstock (December 11, 1876-December 12, 1973) was an American women's education pioneer. She served as the first dean of women at the University of Minnesota and later as the first full-time president of Radcliffe College. I added the picture to the Wikipedia article, the big version is now at commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Ada_Comstock_(LOC_ggbain....
Her papers are at Harvard: oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00104 And at Smith College (where she was also on the faculty): asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/smitharchives/manosca15...

George Grantham Bain, the man "driving" the Stutz, was the head of the Bain News Agency, and the agency's office was in one of the highrise buildings facing Union Square, in New York City -- which is visible in these photos.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5642877605/in/photostream/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5642877465/in/photostream/]
The good old days. No safety glass. No seat belts. Smooth tread tires on cobble stone streets. Best to sit in the back and let the chauffeur do the driving.

this is the tourer;-  Stutz became famous later more for their 'Bearcat' which was a more racy affair altogether, an early form of thunderbird idea.  Looked like a low version of the above longer bonnet less seats and some had a 'monocle' circular windscreen.

This and other photos of Harold Kantner and Albert Heinrich in the latest batch of Bain photos are from the July 4, 1914 air race staged from and near Governor's Island. AERIAL RACE TODAY TO BE RECORD EVENT; Flying Boats to Compete with Landgoing Machines for First Time Here. New York Times July 4, 1914 Eight airmen are entered for a mixed aeroplane and flying boat race which will be held over an all-water course above the Hudson River and New York Bay this afternoon. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F7081EF83A5B13738... >>> Due to rough seas, none of the seaplanes were able to take off for the race. That left only Kantner and Heinrich (both flying land-based aircraft) able to compete, with Kantner winning the $1,000 prize for 1st place and Heinrich winning a $500 prize for 2nd. ONLY TWO PLANES FLY IN AIR RACE; Three Waterplanes Weather-bound at Sea Gate, Unable to Rise from the Heavy Waves. New York Times July 5, 1914 The aeroplane race, by which the Mayor's Fourth of July Committee planned to give the people something to make up for the lack of firecrackers and skyrockets, turned out yesterday afternoon to be a hollow victory for Harold Kantner, pilot of a 50-horse power Schmidt monoplane, the smallest air machine ever raced in America. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10814FB3E5B17738...

Katharine Dexter McCormick (August 27, 1875 – December 28, 1967) was a U.S. biologist, suffragist, philanthropist and, after her husband's death, heir to a substantial part of the McCormick family fortune. She is remembered for funding most of the research necessary to develop the first birth control pill. Notably, her husband does not have a Wikipedia entry (yet)...

She was the granddaughter of Judge Samuel William Dexter, the founder of Dexter Village, MI (about ten miles west of my hometown of Ann Arbor), and the daughter of Wirt Dexter, prominent Chicago attorney and financier. (The Louis Sullivan-designed Wirt Dexter Building, a Chicago landmark, burned to ashes a few years ago.) Katharine's husband was the fabulously wealthy Stanley McCormick of Chicago, a member of the family that invented the McCormick Reaper and founded the International Harvester Company. Unfortunately, Stanley McCormick went mad.
She's also familiar as one of the main characters in TC Boyle's Riven Rock, a novel based on the story of Stanley McCormick's madness and retreat to an estate near Santa Barbara.
episodesandaccidents, Wystan and pennylrichardsca--thank you for identifying Katherine Dexter McCormick. We will add some of these details to the record when we update.

This is a photo of the unsuccessful attempted flight of the Langley Aerodrome from a houseboat on the Potomac River on October 7, 1903. It is likely this photo is in with the 1914 group of Bain photos because the Langley Aerodrome would actually play a role in the patent fights between the Wright Brothers and Glenn Curtiss. This is not one of the 1914 flights, as is apparent by comparing October 7,1903 photos of the attempted flight with this one. As per Wikipedia: With Smithsonian approval, Glenn Curtiss extensively modified the Aerodrome and made a few short flights in it in 1914, as part of an unsuccessful attempt to bypass the Wright Brothers' patent on aircraft and to vindicate [Samuel] Langley. Based on these flights, the Smithsonian displayed the Aerodrome in its museum as the first heavier-than-air manned, powered aircraft "capable of flight." This action triggered a feud with Orville Wright (Wilbur Wright died in 1912), who accused the Smithsonian of misrepresenting flying machine history. Orville backed up his protest by refusing to donate the original 1903 Kitty Hawk Flyer to the Smithsonian, instead exiling it to Science Museum of London in 1928. The dispute finally ended in 1942 when the Smithsonian published details of the Curtiss modifications to the Aerodrome and recanted its claims for the aircraft. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Langley_Aerodrome

TVL 1970:  Thank you for identifying this aircraft as the Langley Aerodrome, developed by Smithsonian Institution secretary Samuel P. Langley. This photo shows the aerodrome's attempted flight on October 7, 1903, which ended when it fell into the water upon launch. This same photograph, credited to the Smithsonian Institution, is shown in an article "Langley's Flying Machine" in Aviation and Aeronautical Engineering magazine (Vol. III, Nov. 15, 1917, p. 528) which is available at Google Books. The article also contains information and photos of  Glen Curtiss's later modification of the Aerodrome.   We will add more details when we update this image description.

Curtiss Model M Flying Boat, a monoplane flying boat ordered by aviator Raymond V. Morris (the "M" in "Model M" is for Morris), the manager of the Curtiss Aviation School at North Island, San Diego. The Model M was powered by a 90-H.P. Curtiss OX-5 V-8 engine. The New York Times published a short item regarding the aircraft's first flight in January 1914. ICE INCRUSTS FLYING BOAT.; New Craft Designed by Curtiss Makes 100-Mile Speed. New York Times January 13, 1914 HAMMONDSPORT, N.Y., Jan. 12. - Traveling at the rate of 100 miles an hour with the temperature close to zero, Raymond V. Morris of New Haven, Conn., made four flights here to-day in the smallest flying boat ever built in America. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60611F73F5912738...

The machine on the picture is a design of Giuseppe Bellanca , actually his third design - a parasol wing construction - dating from the fall 1911, built in New York. The machine was used as a trainer, that is the trainee was in the plane actually flying and the instructor was on the ground (!), as the machine was a single seat one. A pupil became later very famous, Fiorella H. LaGuardia in later times the mayor of New York. Reference: Spencer, Jay P. 1982. Bellanca C.F. The emergence of the cabin monoplane in the United States. ISBN 0-87474-881-X. p. 12-15. A Smithsonian production. This study shows two other pictures (one in flight !) of the machine. Kees

www.loc.gov/resource/sn83030180/1899-06-22/ed-1/ This June 22 1899 issue of The New York Journal has a front page article about Murphy's attempt to cover a mile in a minute, drafting behind a train, including "an instantaneous photograph taken for The Journal." Riding on boards laid down over several miles of railroad ties between the tracks, this is one of the more extreme daredevil attempts imaginable with a basic bicycle. Whether Murphy was simply crazy or extremely brave or both is hard to say.

trialsanderrors and Richard Arthur Norton: Thanks for looking into Roy Shattuck. I checked Chronicling America: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/ and the Proquest historical newspapers subscription databases but could not find out too much more. According to the Phildelphia Public Ledger (Feb. 25, 1915) Roy Shattuck pleaded not guilty to charges that he conspired with other unsuccessful candidates to corrupt the elections. The Baltimore Sun (April 13, 1915) reported that some those accused of corruption received prison sentences, but some were given suspended sentences as they had agreed to testify in the trial of Roy Shattuck. The Ogden (Utah) Standard (Nov. 30, 1915) reports four of the indicted who were going to testify against Shattuck in his trial, had now received their jail sentences because "Shattuck since has died".

Present at the decennial Great International Congress of the Salvation Army, in 1914.

The Salvation Army's Great International Congress was held in London, England, beginning June 11, 1914. The congress was held every 10 years, and this was an auspicious opportunity to share experiences and enthusiasms with thousands of people from 58 countries including England, Australia, New Zealand, United States and Canada.

The largest delegation, outside of England, was from the United States, which sent 600 men and women and 100 children. The American delegation included four bands, from New York; Chicago; Worcester, Massachusetts; and Flint, Michigan. The 55 band members from Flint were auto workers, and their expenses were paid by local businessmen. Elsewhere, American delegates paid their own expenses.

AKA: MAry of Teck, Queen consort of the United Kingdom and the British Dominions, and Empress of India, as the wife of King-Emperor George V. By birth, she was a princess of Teck, in the Kingdom of Württemberg, with the style Serene Highness (Per Wiki).
So she would be the present queen's grandmother?
Yes.  For about 3 years, England technically had 3 queens once Elizabeth II took the crown.
she was a very pretty lady

I dunno -- if this picture is current with the others, Queen Mary would have been about 50 yrs old by this time (and frankly, was never this pretty). I think the lady in the photo might be this one: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Somerset,_Duchess_of_Beaufort , who would have been Queen Mary's niece, and daughter of the Prince of Teck in the next photo.
But between 1910-15 there was only one Princess of Teck (Mary) who would have been in her 40's at the time.

According to Wikipedia -- maybe not authoritative, but I don't know enough to argue -- Mary Somerset was baptized Princess Mary von Teck in 1897, and thus would have been about 17 years old in 1914, which I can believe in that photo. The other Mary was exactly thirty years older and already Queen Consort in 1914, so unless this was an old photo they wouldn't have referred to her as "Princess." I'm certainly no authority on European royalty, but I don't think the woman in this picture is the same as the one in these: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_of_Teck

John Cyril Porte, a retired Briish aviator, and George Hallett, were pilot and co-pilot on a project to attempt a non-stop Atlantic crossing by air.  They were to fly the Rodman Wanamaker airship, America, from Newfoundland to Ireland in the summer of 1914.  The original plan had been to fly in June, but  problems with the plane's design led to postponement well into July.  Porte insisted on flying at night during the full moon so that he could navigate by the stars.  By the time the America was ready to fly, the next avialable date that met Porte's criteria was in August 1914.  Unfortunately, the outbreak of The Great War that month caused the ocean crossing to be cancelled.

Victor Herbert (1859-1924), Irish-born German-educated composer: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Herbert

Actually, not German: Victor Herbert was born in Ireland, to English-speaking parents. His mother's second husband may have been German, but Victor wasn't. He was educated in Germany, but had his career in America, where he wrote his operettas in English. He was regarded as an American composer.
So corrected!

The photo above was taken in April, 1914, aboard a ship in New York harbor, when Herbert was embarking with his family for Europe. Arriving in London, he was conducted on a tour of Buckingham Palace, when he suddenly became ill with an attack of appendicitis. An emergency operation soon put him back to rights. This April 26, 1914, story about his illness, in the New York Times, notes that he had arrived from New York only a week earlier: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=940DE7D6163AE6...

As per Glenn Curtiss - Pioneer of Flight (1991), by Cecil R. Roseberry, this photo depicts the christening and launching of the Curtiss Model H Flying Boat "America" on June 22, 1914 in Hammondsport, New York, just adjacent to Keuka Lake. From left to right, aviators John Cyril Porte, George E.A. Hallett, and (builder) Glenn Curtiss stand below 16-year old Miss Katherine Masson. Miss Masson, the daughter of Leon Masson, an official with the Pleasant Valley Wine Company (and granddaughter of Jules Masson), was chosen to christen the America with a bottle of champagne (which proved to be a fitful task). The aircraft's construction by Glenn Curtiss was commissioned by Rodman Wanamaker, the son of department store founder John Wanamaker, in order to compete for the ₤10,000 prize offered by the Daily Mail newspaper for the first non-stop aerial crossing of the Atlantic Ocean. The Curtiss Model H-1 flying boat was Initially known as the "Rodman Wanamaker Transatlantic Flyer," but the name "America" was chosen for the aircraft by Wanamaker. Ultimately, the outbreak of the the First World War would intercede and "America" would never make its planned transatlantic flight. Here's a link to British Pathe newsreel film of the assembly and christening of the America, along with footage of a stubborn bottle of champagne. www.britishpathe.com/record.php?id=80471 Another Bain photo of the trio and Miss Masson: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5621411353/in/photostream/]

As per Glenn Curtiss - Pioneer of Flight (1991), by Cecil R. Roseberry, this photo depicts the christening and launching of the Curtiss Model H Flying Boat "America" on June 22, 1914 in Hammondsport, New York, just adjacent to Keuka Lake. From left to right, aviators John Cyril Porte, George E.A. Hallett, and (builder) Glenn Curtiss stand below 16-year old Miss Katherine Masson. Miss Masson, the daughter of Leon Masson, an official with the Pleasant Valley Wine Company (and granddaughter of Jules Masson), was chosen to christen the America with a bottle of champagne (which proved to be a fitful task). The aircraft's construction by Glenn Curtiss was commissioned by Rodman Wanamaker, the son of department store founder John Wanamaker, in order to compete for the ₤10,000 prize offered by the Daily Mail newspaper for the first non-stop aerial crossing of the Atlantic Ocean. The Curtiss Model H-1 flying boat was Initially known as the "Rodman Wanamaker Transatlantic Flyer," but the name "America" was chosen for the aircraft by Wanamaker. Ultimately, the outbreak of the the First World War would intercede and "America" would never make its planned transatlantic flight. Here's a link to British Pathe newsreel film of the assembly and christening of the America, along with footage of a stubborn bottle of champagne. www.britishpathe.com/record.php?id=80471 Another Bain photo of the trio and Miss Masson: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5621411663/in/photostream/]

Martin Henry Glynn, native of Valatie, New York, was the editor, publisher and owner of the Albany Times-Union newspaper. Member of Congress, State Comptroller and then Lieutenant Governor, he ascended to the governor's office when William Sulzer was impeached and removed from office in 1913. Glynn was New York's first Catholic governor. He was not re-elected in 1914, so his term of office was brief. Suffering from chronic pain, he committed suicide in 1924. 

John Huston Finley was New York's Commissioner of Education from 1913-1921, among many other prominent academic posts.

These could be former Yale football players of the Class of 1908, in a skit at commencement, 1914, satirizing reports of injuries sustained by lightly-padded players of the era in rough-and-tumble play. In 1902, for example, college play was so rough that several players died, while others were severely injured -- a crisis that provoked intervention by then-President Theodore Roosevelt. (The 18th-century militia outfits were 1908's costume du jour, and had no connection with the gridiron theme.)

The pictures are from 1913 depicting Kanno's "Creation Dawn" play at the Forest Theater in Carmel. This was the first public appearance of Henry Cowell who performed the music for the performance. Two years later, Gertrude went to New York with Eitaro Ishigaki. She divorced Kanno in 1919 but then remarried him in 1929 after Ishigaki left her for Ayako Ishigaki "Restless Wave". Takeshi and Gertrude met at Joaquin Miller's "hights" and lived there for 8 years. The photos may have been by Louis J. Stellman who spoke at Gertrude's memorial in 1937.

US ambassador to Iran in 1914. John Lawrence Caldwell (1875-1922) — also known as John L. Caldwell — of Fort Scott, Bourbon County, Kan. Born in Bourbon County, Kan., July 16, 1875. Son of Thomas Anderson Caldwell and Mary Alice (Hamman) Caldwell; married, June 11, 1902, to Evelyne de Lambert. Democrat. School teacher; lawyer; member of Kansas state senate 8th District, 1901-04; Bourbon County Prosecuting Attorney, 1907-11; candidate for U.S. Representative from Kansas 2nd District, 1910; delegate to Democratic National Convention from Kansas, 1912; U.S. Minister to Persia, 1914-21. Member, Freemasons. Died December 6, 1922 I started a Wikipedia entry for him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Lawrence_Caldwell

Mrs. Samuel R. Burgess, chess champion! Eveline Burgess won the US women's chess title in 1907, when she won it from Mrs. Clarence Frey. She held the title for 30 years. She was from St. Louis, and was taught chess by her father when she was a young teen; apparently Mr. Samuel Burgess (1851-1916) was also a chess player of some note. They had five children; only the oldest son took up chess. (That oldest son, Samuel A. Burgess, was a lawyer by training, and president of a small college in Iowa.) blog.chess.com/view/a-woman-champ Her grandson Walter R. Evans (1920-1999), an engineer, remembered learning to play chess from her: www.bpb-co.com/articles/04proceded.php en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_R._Evans

I wrote a short biography of her for Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eveline_Burgess Eveline Allen Burgess (September 19, 1856 - July 10, 1936) of Lamoni, Iowa was the women's American chess champion from 1907 to 1920. Biography: She was born as Eveline Allen on September 19, 1856 in Ogden, Utah to James T. Allen, and Elizabeth Pidd. She married Samuel Rostron Burgess (1851–1918) on July 4, 1876. She won her chess title in a match with Mrs. Clarence Frey in 1907. She taught her grandson, Walter Richard Evans, to play chess. She died on July 10, 1936 in Independence, Missouri.

LOC -- your caption to the photo is incorrect. Bain's minions placed the "X" on the negative merely to indicate Wilson's position in the photo -- the "X" is above his head, more or less. Although he was the ex-president of Princeton University, he was not, in 1914, the ex-President of the United States.
But he was the ex-President of Princeton.

A Mrs. Arthur Randolph (widow, the former Edith May) married William C. Whitney (widower) in 1896, at Bar Harbor. Whitney's grown son, Harry Payne Whitney, was by then newly married to Gertrude Vanderbilt (and Harry Payne Whitney has appeared recently in the Commons uploads, too). "In her youth she was a famous beauty, and she is still a tall, handsome, and graceful brunette," noted the New York Times about Edith May Randolph Whitney, when she married Whitney. Maybe this is an old photograph of her, revived in connection with a story in 1914? Edith May Randolph Whitney (1858-1899) was in a riding accident in 1898, and died in 1899 from the injuries sustained, at age 41. There's a picture of her and a story about the circumstances surrounding her brief marriage to Whitney here: www.newyorksocialdiary.com/node/750

A sad story apparently: New York Times, 12 June 1914: Mrs. Elizabeth A.C. Holman of Waterville, Me. who is seeking in the United States Court here $50,000 damages for alleged conspiracy and abduction against two Hartford physicians and her former husband, the Rev. Cranston Brenton of Yonkers, N.Y., head of the Social Service Commission of the Protestant Episcopal Church in New York State, scored strongly this afternoon when her counsel obtained startling admissions from the star witness of the defense.

Mrs. Elizabeth Alden Curtis (Brenton) Holman was institutionalized at Brattleboro (VT) Insane Asylum in 1912, apparently in connection with their divorce. Her first husband (a professor at Trinity College) found two doctors to attest that she was insane. She sued them all for damages, accusing Brenton of using hypnotism to convince her to sign away her liberty. In June 1914, she won a verdict against Rev. Brenton and one of the doctors (Paul Waterman), and was awarded $4000. But Elizabeth Alden Curtis (Brenton) Holman (b 1879--corrected 3/20) wasn't just an aggrieved spouse; she was a writer. In 1902 she published a version of The Lament of Baba Tahir, a Persian text, under the name Elizabeth Curtis Brenton; in 1912, she and Holman (not yet married) filed for copyright for a play she wrote, based on Alice in Wonderland. Also in 1912, she published a play called The Norseman. She also published poetry in the Connecticut Magazine, The Crisis, and other literary periodicals. In 1900, she's mentioned in a Nation article as an American poet working on a "thoughtful, pure, and even pleasing" version of the Rubaiyat. books.google.com/books?id=yAYDAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA264&l... As "Elizabeth Curtis Brenton," she had letters that appeared in the New York Times Saturday Review of Books in 1901 and 1905. She may have married again after Holman; I find two listings for an "Elizabeth Alden Curtis Tidd" of Connecticut, filing for copyright on plays she wrote in 1929 and 1933. She seems to have used the pseudonym "Alden Curtis" too.

"ROCKEFELLER'S MONOLITH "Tarrytown Hears a Stone Weighing 250 Tons is Coming" Story in "The New York Times," March 15, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F00D16FD3D5E13... ROCKEFELLER'S ROCK HALTS New York Times, June 10, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=FA0B11FB3A5B13...
Wikipedia story on Kykuit, the John D. Rockefeller estate near Tarrytown: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kykuit

Thanks Wystan for the links to the articles, and for determining the date, which will add some certainty to the image.  We'll add that to the record the next time we update it. I'm still not sure what we are looking at in this image: a freight car built to hold and transport the stone?

No, that appears to be a gigantic stoneboat, perched on rollers,  with a massive framework surrounding the stone, probably to prevent accidental breakage or chipping while in transit. The stories suggest that it was Rockefeller's plan to move the stone in one piece, and to have it carved into an  ornamental fountain on the site. The words "George Brown & Co., N. Y.," have been painted on the sides of the wooden cribbing that surrounds and protects the stone.

The stone was both quarried and carved in Stonington, Maine, before being shipped down to Tarrytown. The "vertical striations" are actually the wooden support structure surrounding the stone and you can't see the stone at all in this picture. Once the stone made it up the hill to the estate it became the upper basin of the Oceanus Fountain in the forecourt. (see this photo: www.flickr.com/photos/tomchatt/4170893041/) You can see an indication of the shape of the stone underneath the wooden protection in this photo - the narrower rim on the left side and angle below. Hope this sheds some more light on the photo.

jbops59: You bet we still have these glass negatives! Scans of the almost 40,000 plates in the collection are online at the LOC, www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/ggbain/ This baseball scene shows two techniques for writing on glass negatives. Keep in mind that the original negative is different from what you see here -- the white or clear areas of the original negative display here as black, and the darker areas of the negative display here as lighter areas. The digital image reverses the polarity of the negative, like making a print from a negative. (1) The Bain News Service staff scratched letters into the emulsion on a glass plate using a sharp-pointed tool. They wrote the letters backwards, so that the words read correctly left-to-right when the negative is printed. The Bain staff made a lot of prints from the same negative and many prints every day. The etching technique made it easy to label each print and to tell one print from another -- the basic identification information was right there on the front of each print. "Etching" letters backwards can also be hard to do, so the etched text tends to be brief. Example: "SMITH, BKLYN" consists of black letters here, but the letters are clear on the original negative--lines where the emulsion has been scratched off. (2) The Bain News Service staff also wrote with black ink on the glass side of a negative--the light letters in this image. That way their notes could be made more quickly (without writing backwards). In the scan, these words and dates appear in "mirror image" because they are on the glass side rather than the emulsion side of the plate. The benefit of writing dates and ids on the glass? It's a quick way to note the basic ID info for negatives as they arrived at the news photo service--the paper sleeves and index cards came later. Also, when pulling a negative from the files to print, you had a quick confirmation right on the plate that you had the correct negative. Examples: "SS 4/20/14" on the side of the negative and "Smith 3rd baseman Brooklyn" at the top of the negative

John E. Aldred was director of United Railways & Electric Co., Baltimore. Before that he was president of Consolidated Gas, Electric Light & Power in Baltimore, and the Pennsylvania Water & Power Co. I'm a little puzzled. Robert Low Bacon would have been about 32 at the time -- which could make him the younger man, with the young wife. But Harry Payne Whitney would only have been about 44, and the older man looks older than that. One possibility is that the older man is Robert Bacon, father of Robert Low Bacon, and former Secretary of State. Seen at:
A 1924 picture of Harry Payne Whitney is at: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/npcc.25360 This looks like the younger man in the Bain photo.

If the young woman is Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, she is the former Virginia Murray and they were married in April 1913 in New York City. See Washington Herald of March 31, 1913 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/beta/lccn/sn83045433/1913-03-3... for an announcement and the New York Tribune of April 15, 1913 for a report on the wedding. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/beta/lccn/sn83030214/1913-04-1...

Thanks, all, for the likely place and date of the photo, and clues about the identities of the people. From checking our Biographical File of pictures in the reading room, it appears that this is Harry Payne Whitney (left) with his hand on the shoulder of Robert Bacon (1860-1919), who was briefly Secretary of State in 1909, then Ambassador to France until 1912. We have other photographs of Robert Bacon in the Bain Collection. Here's one that appears in our Biographical File with a news article copied on the back about his departure from the ambassador's post: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.20701 . The young woman is apparently Robert Bacon's daughter-in-law, Virginia Murray Bacon, married to his son, Robert Low Bacon (1884-1938) who became a Congressman from New York (seen in this photographic print, also from the Bain Collection: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3a42131 - one for which we apparently do not have an original negative). We'll add some identifying information when we update the record.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_Rosenzweig Jacob Rosenzweig (1875 - October 4, 1947) was an American gambler and underworld figure in New York City. He was one of several star witnesses in the Becker-Rosenthal trial, among these being fellow gamblers Bridgie Webber, Harry Vallon, and Sam Schepps. Rose's testimony was the most damaging because he directly implicated Becker in arranging the murder of Herman Rosenthal. As Becker's debt collector, Rose confessed to hiring the Lenox Avenue Gang, providing the getaway car. He testified he did it all on the orders of Charles Becker.

The Tampico Affair started off as a minor incident involving U.S. sailors and Mexican land forces loyal to General Victoriano Huerta during the guerra de las facciones phase of the Mexican Revolution. Handwritten caption looks more like "A. I. Hoe & Wife." An Arthur I. Hoe was being sued in 1914 (and again in 1916) for refusing to pay a woman he promised to marry and support. He was president of a book publishing house. His wife was Evelyn Perry Hoe (b. 1886), of Rhode Island. They married in 1910 and had at least one daughter, Caroline Phelps Hoe. Mrs. Hoe favored suffrage. The Hoes were art collectors; there's at least one Botticelli at the Cleveland Museum of Art with their name in its history. www.clevelandart.org/provenance/prov_search.asp?artist=W
NYT of May 26, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20B11FC345D13738... reports on a day in court. Gives his name as Arthur Ingersoll Hoe.

According to obits.oregonlive.com/obituaries/oregon/obituary.aspx?n=la..., they had five children, the last being twins, who died a few days apart in November 2010. "Harris, Laura, March 30, 1920 to Nov. 7, 2010 Pelling, Thyrza, March 30, 1920 to Nov. 11, 2010 Born March 30, 1920, in New York City, the twins were the last of Arthur Hoe and Evelyn Perry's five children. " Lots more family history at nigelquest.blogspot.com/2010/11/twins-obituary.html

There is a "tell all" article published in 1921 in the Pittsburgh Press news.google.com/newspapers?id=Vh8bAAAAIBAJ&sjid=u0kEA... by Bernard Francis Seraph Gregory, a con man who called himself "Count Gregory" in which he claims he discovered Alma in Toronto, where she was the wife of a British Army Captain, and coached her on her princess act. Now how much you can believe anything in a confession by a self described swindler published in a sensational newspaper is a good question. It would be interesting to know her real background and what happened to her poor son.

Thanks for the photo. Alma was the grandmother of my stepfather and i have been fascinated by her life, it was indeed dramatic. No one has been able to ascertain her true beginnings. She first shows up in 1907 in her first marriage, with the Name Alma Irene Zetkous, claiming Austrian birth and deceased parents in Toronto, Ontario.

Just to add, the poor son was taken under the wing of a Baron in England and sent to Sandhurst Academy.  He flew a trans-African flight during the 1930's and he was given a commision and was stationed in Southern Africa during WWII, well away from action in North Africa and claims the only thing he shot was a pod of whales, mistaking them for U-Boats.  He then married and emigrated to Canada after the war having a small farm in BC and three sons.

In 1914, the Marconi Wireless Station at Father Point played a role in the rescue of 400 passengers of the doomed ship, "RMS Empress of Ireland." Here is the story, from the website of the Southgate Amateur Radio Club: www.southgatearc.org/news/october2010/empress_of_ireland.htm "John Bowen, G8DET, Chair of the Chelmsford Amateur Radio Society (CARS) brings news of a TV show on the Yesterday channel that covers the last voyage of the Empress of Ireland, which involved a UK radio amateur Ron Ferguson who was later to become G4VF. "John G8DET writes: "I happened to be looking through the “What’s on TV” section and noted that on Monday, October 11 at 5PM (1600 UT) there is a show on the UK Freeview Channel “Yesterday” called “Last Voyage of the Empress of Ireland” [may also be available on the web]. It is for one hour. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RMS_Empress_of_Ireland and www.sea-viewdiving.com/shipwreck_info/ empress_home/thetragedy.htm "This is another story involving Marconi Wireless Telegraph company personnel. What the two links above do not say is that Ron Ferguson, G4VF, was the Senior Wireless Officer aboard the Empress of Ireland and had just retired for the night when the collision occurred. Ron became President of the Chelmsford Amateur Radio Society (CARS) and lived in Chelmsford, Essex. "His Second in Command was on duty. On feeling the collision, Ron dressed and took over the Wireless Room and told him to get into a lifeboat, which he did. "Ron hammered out a SOS which was picked up by the Marconi shore station at Father Point. They informed the marine people who launch 5 boats. These were tugs and what were available at short notice. "Officially Ron should have waited to receive instructions from the Captain but took it unto himself to send the SOS as he rated (quite correctly as it turned out) to be a desperate situation. "Ron stayed at his post giving directions, points to aid the rescuers until after only 12 minutes or so the Wireless failed and a huge wave swept him out of his Wireless Room. He grabbed a large deck-chair that swept past him and was then washed overboard. "He was rescued by the Collier. Either the Collier had a Wireless but no Wireless Officer or Ron was transferred to one of the rescue ships. "One way or another Ron found himself on a ship with a Marconi Wireless but no Wireless Officer. He was given permission by the Captain to break the lock and for many hours continued to coordinate the rescue. "2 years later Ron visited the Shore Station at Father Point and someone said “Hello Ron, that is your jacket”. It had been hanging on a peg all that time. "In the early 1970s I said to Ron one evening at a CARS Meeting “Ron, weren’t you involved with the Empress of Ireland?” not really knowing anything of the story. “'Well that was a long time ago, lad – let’s get on with tonight’s meeting' "That was as much as I ever got from Ron. "I do not think Ron was ever awarded any medal or citation for his involvement with saving the lives of over 400 persons. "Do you know more or different to my story above? "This is another story we will commemorate in 4 year's time when it is the Centenary. Every year the Canadians have a commemoration day to remember the 1,012 or so who died in that dreadful accident. "See what the TV show tells us about the event. "Regards John G8DET"

From The Tragic Story of the Empress of Ireland, An Authentic Account of the Most Horrible Disaster in Canadian History... by Logan Marshall (L. T. Myers 1914): 69-70.
HERO SAVED WEE GIRL The description of the wreck and the heart-rending scenes that followed, given by Robert W. Crellin, of Silverstone, British Columbia, was graphic. Crellin is a prosperous farmer. He was one of the heroes of the wreck. He saved Florence Barbour, the eight-year-old daughter of a neighbor, by swimming with the child on his back, and, with the aid of another rugged passenger, pulled two women and several men into a collapsible boat. Clad only in a night shirt, Crellin said the water and air were as cold as winter, chilling all hands to the bone. Despite the peril and exposure, flaxen-haired Florence Bar- bour clung to Crellin's neck and never even cried. "The child was pluckier than a stout man/' said Crellin. "She never even whimpered, and complaint was out of the question. You should have seen how the girls and women in the little village of Rimouski hugged her when we got ashore. "Time and time again I feared Florence would lose her hold, and I would speak to her when my mouth and eyes were clear. Each time her little hands would clutch me tighter, until it seemed she'd stop my breath, but I welcomed the hold be- cause it showed she had the pluck and courage needed. "Poor child! She lost her mother and sister, and only a year ago her father, William Barbour, of Silverstone, was killed. She's alone in the world, but Florence will never need a friend or home while I have breath in my body." Big and rugged as he is, Crellin's eyes grew moist as he recalled how the child's mother and three-year-old sister Evelyn were drowned.

Thinking their names might be Anna Hammer, Hilma Kallio, and Hilma Tousettill--the handwriting isn't very clear, but certainly the surname in the middle has two Ls. Also, a Hilma Kallio is mentioned among the survivors in a NYTimes story dated 3 June 1914:
This afternoon a small group stood around a coffin in the Morgue where the victims have lain since Sunday morning. A photograph was bring passed from hand to hand, and as each received it, he glanced at the face in the coffin. 'Yes, I am sure it is she,' said the owner of the photograph, and he gave the name to the clerk who had charge of the section. 'Hilma Kallio of Sault Ste. Marie, Mich.,' said he. Then he gave his own name, Vincent Kallio of Kinross, Mich., and stated that he was her brother. 'Hilma Kallio,' said an official in a puzzled voice. 'Why, she's not missing, is she?' Hastily they examined the list. And then they found the name among the saved. A ticket had been provided to send the girl back to her home in Michigan. The man broke into tears of joy. Soon he was smiling. He thanked the officials who had helped him and left the Morgue.

There's a Hilma Kallio mentioned in an obituary here; she died in 1948, according to her husband's Jack Hill's obituary from 1961; they seem to have lived in Nolalu, Northern Ontario, Finnish Lutherans, her surviving brothers in 1961 are listed as Richard and Emil. freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~jmitchell/obit...

There's a Hilma Taavettila listed among the Finnish survivors in this document: www.migrationinstitute.fi/articles/008_Tuominen.pdf The woman on the right might be Hilma Taavettila--it would be an easy name to misspell.

Maneckji Nusserwanji (MN) Dhalla (1875-1956) was an Indian-born theologian, writer, and Zoroastrian priest; in 1914, he and his wife were in the US, because he was on a lecture tour and publishing his book "Zoroastrian Theology." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maneckji_Nusserwanji_Dhalla Professor A. V. Williams Jackson of Columbia, an expert on Indo-Iranian languages, hosted Dhalla on his 1914 trip to the US. Djelal Munif Bey was the Turkish Consul General in New York. British polo team that won the International Polo Cup in 1914: Maj. Frederick W. Barrett, Capt. Leslie St. Claire Cheape, Capt. Vivian N. Lockett, Capt. H. A. Tomkinson, and John Traill. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Polo_Cup

Cheape (c1882-1916) died in WWI; has a wiki entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leslie_Cheape His sister, Mrs. C. P. Kay, was one of the victims of the 1914 "Empress of Ireland" disaster, which is also part of this week's LOC uploads to Flickr Commons.

They arrived on May 31, 1914 on the Cunarder Carmania according to next day's NYT query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30A13FB3A5B13738... The competition between the national teams was in decided on June 16. See NYT of June 17, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60811FF3F5E13738...

The University of Hawaii had separate baseball teams for Chinese and Japanese players. The Chinese team toured the US in 1910, 1912, 1914, 1915, and 1916, at least, playing exhibition games with various college teams, industrial teams, and black teams. This would probably be from their 1914 game with Columbia University's team. (The Chinese won.) See Harold Seymour, Baseball: The People's Game Vol 3 (Oxford University Press 1991): 173-174 for mention of this team and coverage of their game with Columbia.
I'll bet these guys got a kick out of the choosing up for Chinese and  Japanese teams.  The name "Akana" is Hawaiian, about as Chinese as "Jones."

pennylrichardsca: Thanks for the research on this interesting story! It is even more tangled than it seems at first! It appears that referring to this team as the Chinese team of the University of Hawaii is not quite accurate, despite the use of that phrase in the Seymour text you reference. From Dan Cisco's Hawaii Sports: History, Facts and Statistics (University of Hawaii Press, 1999), baseball did not debut at the College of Hawaii until 1917. The College of Hawaii was not known as the University of Hawaii until 1920, according to the University of Hawaii's website. Since this event took place in 1914, it seems that the story told by Joel S. Franks in Asian Pacific Americans and Baseball: A History (Jefferson, N.C.: McFarland & Co., Inc., 2008) might be closer to accurate. He indicates that a baseball team formed of Chinese Americans was sent to the mainland in 1912 to play against university teams, and this endeavor was supported by "Chinatown business interests in Honolulu", amongst others, in an attempt to bolster tourism and provide a connection "between Chinese Americans and European Americans". The mainland press publicized them as representatives of the Chinese University of Hawaii, even though that did not exist. It was later speculated by Honolulu sportswriter Red McQueen that they wanted it to seem like the college teams on the mainland were playing against other college students when facing the Chinese American team, though that was not actually the case. This team played Columbia University's team on May 31, 1914, and beat them by a score of 4-2, per this New York Times article. We will expand the description when we update this record. rjones0856: Very true that many on the Chinese team were of varying ancestry. Lang Akana's birth name was Fong Lan Akana. His father was Chinese born and his mother was Hawaiian.
