May 28, 1914 was the date of the annual garden party at Governors Island. See NYT of May 29, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B05E0D8173AE633A...

The occasion for this photo was an annual event on Governors Island, the lawn party of the Army Relief Society. The party was a fundraiser for the organization, which provided succor to widows and orphans of officers and enlisted men of the Regular Army.

The Bain agency's photographer also recorded the May 25, 1911, party, which was hosted by General Frederick Dent Grant, the son of U. S. President Ulysses S. Grant. Frederick Grant at that time was the resident officer on Governor's Island, but he died a year later (of cancer), on April 12, 1912.

Here is Fred Grant with Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, at the 1911 shindig:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163471766/]

From Wikipedia:
The Brooklyn Tip-Tops were a team in the short-lived Federal League of professional baseball from 1914 to 1915. The team was named by owner Robert Ward, who owned the Tip Top Bakery. They were sometimes called the Brooklyn Feds due to being the Brooklyn team of the Federal League. The Tip Tops played in old Washington Park, which the Brooklyn Dodgers had abandoned after the 1912 season to move to Ebbets Field.

From Baseball Encyclopedia.com:
"With Harry Sinclair, Ward was one of the main backers of the Federal League. As owner of the Brooklyn franchise, he poured more than a million dollars into the cause. He offered to share any team profits with his players, but there was never anything to share. A month after Ward died, the league also succumbed. (NLM) "

Former President Theodore Roosevelt stands on the deck of the steamship Aidan, in New York harbor, on May 19, 1914. The ship had docked minutes earlier, after returning Roosevelt from an eight-month ordeal in South America where, with his son Kermit and others, he had explored a hitherto unknown river through the Amazon jungle -- called "The River of Doubt," but afterwards named "Rio Roosevelt." The harrowing adventure was told recently in the bestselling book "The River of Doubt," (2006) by Candice Millard.

Barratt O'Hara (1882-1969) was the young lieutenant governor of Illinois (1913-1917); much later in life, he served in Congress: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barratt_O%27Hara bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=O000053 His papers are at the University of Illinois Chicago: www.uic.edu/depts/lib/specialcoll/services/rjd/findingaid... Mrs. O'Hara was the former Florence Hoffmann; they married in 1906, and had at least three sons. In 1913, Lt. Gov. Barratt O'Hara was in a scandal, accused of immorality after meeting a woman at a hotel. O'Hara was head of the Vice Committee at the time, making this an especially juicy story for the newspapers. He also seems to have written a history of heavyweight boxing (published in 1909). books.google.com/books?id=ZXg9AAAAYAAJ&dq=Barratt+o%2...

George Nathaniel Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston, KG, GCSI, GCIE, PC (11 January 1859 – 20 March 1925), known as The Lord Curzon of Kedleston between 1898 and 1911 and as The Earl Curzon of Kedleston between 1911 and 1921, was a British Conservative statesman who was Viceroy of India and Foreign Secretary. The Curzon Line, now the eastern boundary of Poland, is named after him.

It's not clear what he was in the news for in April of 1914, unless it was his antagonism to giving women the vote. As a n example, NYT of May 6, 1914. Vote Would Injure Women, Says Curzon. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C07E2DD173AE633A... reports on a debate in the House of Lords, where Curzon was the leading voice against giving women who already a vote in municipal elections (on the basis of property and paying taxes) a vote in Parliamentary elections. Also in May, he was in the news because his daughter was a debutante and he gave a ball for her. .

nudecowboy:  Thanks for the New York Times article (May 10, 1914)  which reports that the ship "City of Macon" was one of the fleet moving the Second Army Division from Texas City to Veracruz, Mexico.

When we last saw her, the "City of Macon" was being used in February, 1914, to transport the Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team to its spring training quarters in Georgia:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4909926247/]

USS Macona (ID # 3305) 1918-1919. Originally S.S. City of Macon (American Coastal Passenger Ship, later Freighter, 1903). Later renamed Macona S.S. City of Macon, a 5252 gross ton coastal passenger-cargo ship, was built in 1903 at Chester, Pennsylvania, for the Ocean Steamship Co. of Savannah, which operated a passenger and freight service between Savannah, Georgia, and New York. She was configured like many other coastal passenger ships of her era, among them her near-sister City of Savannah (ID # 4514), with a single smokestack, two raked pole masts, and a long, low superstructure extending from a bridge forward of amidships to the stern. In 1916 the ship was sold to the Barber Steamship Co., renamed Macona, and possibly reconfigured as a freighter by her new owner. Taken over by the Navy and commissioned at New York as USS Macona (ID # 3305) on 19 August 1918, she sailed in a convoy on 25 August with a cargo of 4,470 tons of general supplies, which she delivered to St. Nazaire, France, on 12 September. She was then assigned to service in European waters, carrying a cargo of potatoes from Ireland to France for the American Expeditionary Force. In late December Macona loaded a cargo of Navy stores, then moved to Cardiff, Wales, to bunker for the voyage back to the United States. She left Cardiff on 15 February 1919 but had to stop at the Azores for more fuel before arriving at Hampton Roads, Virginia, on 12 March. USS Macona was decommissioned and delivered to the Shipping Board on 25 March 1919 for simultaneous return to her owners. On 18 January 1920 S.S. Macona struck a rock and sank near Gotenborg, Sweden. In port, possibly when inspected by the Third Naval District on 19 August 1918. This relatively elderly former coastal passenger and cargo ship was in commission as a freighter from 19 August 1918 to 25 March 1919. U.S. Naval Historical Center Photograph from http://www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-m/id3305.htm

Torreón was taken during the evening between March 30 and April 1 to 3, 1914. Gen. José Refufigo Velasco and his federal troops abandoned the city, during a chocking dust storm on April 2, at 4 pm. So by April 4th "Fererals were not going to battle", they WERE ON RETREAT TOWARDS SAN PEDRO DE LAS COLONIAS (northeast from Torreón) where they had a clash on April 7 with Villa´s fore troups. Is it Lerdo Avenue in Ciudad Juarez or Ciudad Lerdo, State of Durango, Laguna District? Lerdo, Durango is a relatively old town located in the northern edge of Nazas River, that makes the landscape look no so deserted (in fact is nicknamed "Ciudad Jardín" [Garden City]), the streets are narrower.  Although it was shelled and burned, it was not as Gómez Palacio and Ciudad Juarez did. There´s a picture taken by Hartford H. Miller on September 9, 1913 showing the shelling on Madrid Hotel in Lerdo, Durango. (Hidalgo and Reforma [currently Madero] Streets).  This landscape is likely to be Ciudad Juárez.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

If it is Lerdo, Durango, should be the outskirts facing (the long sidewalk) towards west-east. 
By call nr. it may be dated on april 1914, after La Batalla de Torreón.  La División del Norte (Northern Division) commanded by Francisco Villa came from north, making a claw movement, surrounded Laguna District by march 23rd.  Encircling Lerdo from north-west, Gómez Palacio  (which had the heaviest shelling) from north-south and Torreón from north-east (which eventually fell on april 1rst, 1914).
jerodamor@yahoo.com.mx:  Thank you for the detailed information about the two possible locations for this photograph. We will include some of your information in the description.

En la madrugada del 22 de marzo de 1914 tomaron posiciones las fuerzas villistas.  La Brigada Juárez de Durango quedó al pie del Cerro de la Cruz  al suroeste de Gómez Palacio, viendo hacia Lerdo.  Por el sur y el poniente de esta ciudad (orilla norte del río Nazas, por la Boca de Raymundo y la Presa de San Fernando) estaban las Brigadas Primera de Durango y Carranza.  Estas fuerzas, al mando de Maclovio Herrera, debian tomar Lerdo.  Al atardecer del 23, los villistas, viniendo del norte se aproximaron en orden frente a las fuerzas huertistas de Gómez Palacio, formando una línea apoyada en el panteón al poniente y en la vía de Monterrey al oriente.  Toda la noche se disparó contra las trincheras huertistas para que la Brigada Benito Juárez y la Brigada Juárez de Durango 
terminaran de tomar posiciones y que la artillería villista  se colocara al pié del Cerro de San Ingancio, (al noroeste de Lerdo).  El objetivo de esas acciónes era mantener al grueso del enemigo enclavado en Gómez, mientras Herrera asaltaba Lerdo por el suroeste.
(Texto en Pedro Salmerón, La División del Norte, Editorial Planeta Mexicana, S. A. de C.V., segunda reimpresión 2008, pp 420-421)

There's an article in New York Tribune, issue September 28, 1913 (The Library of Congress, Chronicling America) that mentions the failure of Generals Trucy Aubert and Ocaranza to aid the Torreón garrison when Aubert was near San Pedro de las Colonias (State of Coahuila) with fifteen-hundred troops and Ocaranza in San Pedro with 800 men.
When both generals learned that Villa was close, they fled eastward  to Hipólito with their troops and civilians.

(3069-3) might be linked to pictures call nrs. 3069-4, 3069-6 and 3069-7 that are most likely corraled last days of March or beginning April, 1914 .  It seems that the wrecked house on the back ground is the same seen in "HOUSES DESTROYED BY HAND GRANADES, LERDO  3069-6" in Bain's collection.  
In 1913 Ocaranza probably was second in command to General Ignacio A. Bravo and in 1914 to General José Refugio Velasco, for the federal operations in Torreón garrison, (Laguna District) where the powerful División del Nazas was stationed. 
Also there's another article in New-York Tribune, issue March 29, 1914 that says:
"General Eduardo Ocaranza, reported killed, was fatally wounded in Lerdo battle..."

Jan Christiaan Smuts OM CH ED KC FRS PC (24 May 1870 – 11 September 1950) was a prominent South African and British Commonwealth statesman, military leader and philosopher. In addition to holding various cabinet posts, he served as Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa from 1919 until 1924 and from 1939 until 1948. He served in the First World War and as a British field marshal in the Second World War.
Smuts was the only person to sign the treaties ending both WWI and WWII, and was a strong proponent of the League of Nations.

Clara Butt (1872-1936) was an English contralto; both the boys here died before Clara did, the elder son Roy from meningitis at school, the younger, Victor, by suicide. Butt would use a wheelchair in her later years, when spinal cancer was taking hold. The daughter here was named Joy. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clara_Butt This is video of this same moment! www.britishpathe.com/record.php?id=61490 Here's baby Joy Rumford with her parents, looks like about ten years earlier: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/w77t/4077976187/]

The boy on the left inherited mom's teeth.

She sang at the Met in the season-ending concert on April 26, 1914, according to NYT of April 27, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9501E2DF173AE633A... Perhaps the picture was taken when she was leaving for England.
I assumed it was arrival because of the bouquets!  But I looked again at the video, and it says they're getting ON the ship, as you suggest, swanq.   Thanks!

pennsylrichardsca: Thank you for identifying English opera singer Clara Butt and including the additional  photo of her and the film from Pathe. However, I am not sure if the film was taken at the same time as the photo.  Their clothes look similar, but the locations may be different and perhaps these are their traveling outfits. Could the Bain photo been taken in NYC and the Pathe film in England?  The Pathe film archive is fascinating, and may be helpful for identifying other Bain images.  Thanks for including it in your post.

Well, I've looked at them side-by-side a few more times now.  Can't match up any backgrounds, except that both seem to be taken at a ship.  The clothes are almost identical--even the fob-like thing attached to Roy's breast pocket, and the arrangement of Clara's furry stole--but I'm looking again right now and see that Joy's coat is different--could be a lighter layer under the heavier coat here, but maybe it really is just a different day.  Same traveling clothes for most of the party, but a different day.

I like the theory that they're taken at both ends of the same trip, New York and England.  That would make a lot of sense.  The children look the same age/size and are wearing the same hats, etc., so the photo and the footage have to be taken in the same year or so, even if they're not from the same moment.  I assume the children didn't cross the Atlantic more than once or twice a year (but maybe that's my own parenting experience talking!).

Former President Theodore Roosevelt stands on the deck of the steamship Aidan, in New York harbor, on May 19, 1914. The ship had docked minutes earlier, after returning Roosevelt from an eight-month ordeal in South America where, with his son Kermit and others, he had explored a hitherto unknown river through the Amazon jungle -- called "The River of Doubt," but afterwards named "Rio Roosevelt." The harrowing adventure was told recently in the bestselling book "The River of Doubt," (2006) by Candice Millard.

Arranger/band leader Justin Stone is apparently still living (he was born in 1916.) He has music copyrights dating from at least as recently as 2001. In the 1970s, he developed a form of Tai Chi, and has had a successful career promoting it. I found two biographies of him on the Internet, the most recent on a page updated on February 21, 2010. The earlier one, here, says that he formed his first orchestra in 1940. I also found an item in a 1948 issue of Billboard that said he was then forming a second orchestra. Assuming that he is still with us, if somebody who knows him sees this page, maybe they can show him this photo and he can identify the singer for us.
